Content: Everything possible has been done to better the sanitary conditions and to

Heading: make
Content: things more cleanly and home-like for the "SemiteH." First, all the fixtures
    were re- moved and the former unsanitary wooden flooring was taken out. All
    the phimhing under the floors was removed and the

Heading: new
Content: system built in. Then a "mineral floor" tho latest thing in sanitary
    installation I was constructed. Tliat consists of a | two-inch basic layer
    of concrete, ii one-inch layer of firfer concrete next, and above that the
    actual floor, a I three-inch layer of a compositional

Heading: made
Content: up of fine cement and whit- marble-dust.

Heading: The
Content: walls were built up for a distance of five feet above the floor with hard
    plaster and the re- mainder of the walls and the ceilings were constructed
    of ordinary plaster. Another item which will be regard- ed with mingled
    feelings of joy and .sorrow is the complete renovation of the reception-hall
    and parlor of the main huIUUnp; of the

Heading: Wnm^n's
Content: coU<<>>Re Formerly they were separated by a wall, but that has been torn out and
    a colonade slubstituted.

Heading: Two
Content: beauti- ful

Heading: new
Content: rugs adorn the floor. The walls and celling of the entire lower floor have been
    painted in pale buff and white. It looks a hundred per- cent better, but
    several chronic *fu.ssers* will note with regret thn pa.sslng of that
    private spot, espec- laly slncel the "Holy Sanctuary" or "Lover's Retreat."
    that little room Just off the second-floor parlor is closed while In the
    process of renova- tion. Another welcome improvement Is the installation of
    a

Heading: new
Content: system of postal distribution consisting of three hundred and sixty-five lock-
    boxes. Previously the mall was just

Heading: dumped
Content: on the table and the girls found their mall as best as possible.

Heading: A
Content: complete

Heading: new
Content: outfit of china an'l glass-ware has been purchastxl and is

Heading: now
Content: in use in the dlning-hall. The heating system in the Wolfe house was
    unsatisfactory last year, and during the

Heading: summer
Content: the house was attached to the university stean\- heatlng system at the cost of
    over $3,000. It has been proml.sed that things will be kept

Heading: warm
Content: for the girls at the Wolfe House this winter. If present plans are carried out.
    Im- provements of

Heading: much
Content: the same nature will be carried out in the

Heading: New
Content: build- ing next summer. There were also several Improve- u>"nts for the benefit
    of the entire student body. Professor Smith, assis- tant librarian, built In
    thirty tiers of six shelves each a hundred and eighty shelves altogether

Heading: --
Content: which only takes care of about half of the books whi<h were laying (Ui the floor
    of the library at the end of last term. More thYin as

Heading: many
Content: shelves again are needed to take proper care of the re maindf r. In the

Heading: Academy
Content: annex the entire lower floor has been changed Into Biology class rooms acocrding
    to the plans of Mr. Davis In order to acco- modate the overflow of the
    Increased enrollment In the Biology course. The basement is

Heading: now
Content: devoted to the Doc- tor's guinea-pig farm.

Content: University of Pennsylvania de- feated the Orange and Blue on Frank lin Field,
    Philadelphle, Saturday, October 2, by a .score of 7-0, The score does not
    tell the story of the game, because the most conservative of the reports
    admitted that Bueknell play- ed as well as the big Red and Blue team, while
    every loyal Biuknelllan

Heading: who
Content: witnessed the

Heading: game
Content: asserts that Bucknell outplayed Its heavier op- ponents. There are also those

Heading: who
Content: in- sist that the penalties imposed upon Bucknell by the referee were unjust. At
    any rate, it was a

Heading: game
Content: that

Heading: mado
Content: the Peen

Heading: men
Content: feel dubious about th*^ outcome until the final whistle had blown.

Content:

    advantage. The lin-^ plunging of Bow.<<er, and the hard woric of McDermott
    at end featured the name from the Bucknell stand- point, although every

Heading: man
Content: on the team played such a steady, consistent

Heading: game
Content: that it is hardly fair to mention any particular

Heading: man
Content: as an indivldul star. The Orange and Blue line held like a -tone wall, and

Heading: made
Content: the cele- brated Helsman shift look like the

Heading: German
Content: line in the Argonne. Our backfield was a steady grovind gain- er, and matched
    Penn In the totals of first downs. Taken as a whole, our team was equal in
    every respect to the Red and Blue eleven, and only the breaks of the

    fumbles, one

    85 yards .setback be- o;...;.>.- of penalties for alleged oft-sld play.s and

    In the opening period

Heading: game
Content: in itself was not a real test of Bucknell's btrength, as the first (juurter, In
    which the first team took a very active part, was just a con- tinuous march

Heading: down
Content: was

Content: In exactly 3

Content: min- utes after the

    outstanding feature of the

    aa well as the opponents by surprise. The game started

Heading: To
Content: the

Heading: members
Content: of the Freshman class .the BucknelUan extends a hearty welcome.

Heading: To
Content: you ha.s been ex- tended a great opportunity, and it is our earnest desire to
    see you

Heading: make
Content: the most of it. for by so doing, you will bring honor to the

Heading: name
Content: of Old Bucknell. Keep in mind that the more you put into your college life th^'
    more you will get out of it. Get into a>>

Heading: many
Content: activities as possible, and never fail to support the athletic teams of the
    university. Live up to the rules laid

Heading: down
Content: by Senior council, as obedience to them is a test of your manhood. Perhaps it
    will seem to you that life during your first year at Buck- nell is not a
    smiling path of roses. Yet uluiuni

Heading: who
Content: come back are un- animous in saying that the years spent in college are the best
    enjoyed of a whole lifetime, and that the

Heading: Freshman
Content: year is the best of all.

Heading: You
Content: are really privileged by being In col- lege, so try to do your best, and work
    for the honor and glory of Old Bvick- nell.

Content: even more active and bet- ter year than last season proved to be. Profes.sor

    Hartz is the manager.

Heading: Any
Content: students desiring to try out for the club should attend the rehearsels as
    annoiniced from lime to time on the bulletin boards and consult with Prof.
    Stolz or Manas>'r Ilartz. There should be a wealth of material in the
    Freshmen class,

Heading: and
Content: these new men, added to the remaining

Heading: members
Content: of last year's club as a nucleus, should develop into a wonderful organiza- tion
    to represent Bucknell for the coming .sea.son. Students who can play the
    trombone, clarinet and flute are especially needed for the orches- tra work
    under the direction of "Bobby " Hartz. Plans for the year, as announced by
    Manager Hartz. include trips that cover practically the same ground as last
    year with (luite a

Heading: number
Content: of

Heading: new
Content: cities added to the list. The usual local dates will be secured, too, for
    already the surrounding towns are asking for concerts and are anxious to
    hear the club again.

Heading: The
Content: coast to coast trip looks very favorable ac- cording to the management, and will
    no doubt be taken. Plans of the club also include a minstrel

Heading: show
Content: to be given In the near future.

Content: Interclass track and relay meet has been scheduled for the 16th of. October. The
    following events will be included in the meet: 100 yard dash. 220 yard dash,
    440 yard dash, S8i> ! yard dash, 1 mile run, 2 mile run and 1 mile relay.
    Prof Bromley Smith will have general supervision of the arrangements.
    Williams, track cap- tain, and the class managers and captains have been
    asked to cooperate with

Content: Sigma House was the scene of a very delightful dance, Sat- urday evening
    September 25. Danc- ing began at eight thirty and con- tinued thru tin
    twelve o'clock. Very good cider was to be had during the course of the
    evening and during th<' intermission which came at about ten o'clock fruit
    salad and pimento sand- wiches were served. The music was provided by the
    "Sterling Six" of Williamsport. The majority of the members of the orchestra
    are nieni- bers of the Williamsport post of the American Legion. Tlie
    members of the Kappa Signui fraternity were par- ticularly plea.sed to have
    their friends from other houses accept their invi- tation to drop in and

Content: ganic In itself was not a real test of Bucknell's strength, as the first
    quarter, in which the first team took a very active part, was just a con-
    tinuous march

Content: the field for four touchdowns.

Content: first touck-

Content: more touchdowns were secured in the remaining eight min- utes of the quarter.

Heading: men
Content: were put in,

Content: the scoring did not pile up as fast as It had before. The one outstanding
    feature of the

Heading: game
Content: was Bowser's goal from placement from the 46 yard line, which took the crowd, as
    well as tho opponents by surprise.

    first dov.u and then Bowser tarried it over the line for a touchdown.

Content: Published weekly during the col- lege year by the Hucknellian Board, Repre-
    senting the student body of Bucknell University. Sub.scrlptions $1.50 per
    year.

Heading: Make
Content: all checks pay- abel to the Manager. Entered at the Lewisburg post of- fice as
    second class matter. Contributions from students and alumni are earnestly
    solicited. They tihould be written in a legible hand and on but one side of
    the paper. Ad- dress all articles to the Editor.

Content: 

Heading: ATTENTION.
Content: 

Heading: FRESHMEN
Content: To the

Heading: members
Content: of the Freshman class ,the

Heading: BuckmUian
Content: extends a hearty welcome.

Heading: To
Content: you has been ex- tended a great opportunity, and it is our earnest desiie to see
    you

Heading: make
Content: the most of it, for by so doing, you Avill bring honor to the

Heading: name
Content: of Old Bucknell. Keep in mind that the more you put into your college life tlu-

Heading: more
Content: you will get out of it. Get Into S8

Heading: many
Content: activities as possible, and never fail to support the athletic teams of the
    university. Live up to the rules laid

Heading: down
Content: by Senior council, as obedience to them is a test of your manhood. Perhaps it
    will seem to you that life during your first year at Buck- nell is not a
    smiling path of roses. Yet alumni who ccnie l)uck are un- animous in saying
    that the years spent in college are the best enjoyed of a whole lifetime,
    and that the

Heading: Preshman
Content: year is the best of all.

Heading: You
Content: are really privileged by being in col- lege, so try to do your best, and work
    for the honor and glory of Old Buck- Jiel)

Content:

Content:

Heading: a

Content: in- deed be proud.

Content: the two garnet- which have already been played, even the most pessimistir" aro
    unable to pro diet anything but the most promit-.ing outlook ffir the rest
    of th;,' sca.-^on. Under the careful coaching of "Pete" Reynolds,

Heading: we
Content: 

Heading: may
Content: be sure thai the Orange and Blue warriors will bring the greatest of credit on
    the instltti- tion whose

Heading: name
Content: and colors they bear. It is the duty of every loyal Buck- nellian to support the
    team to the beat of his ability by attending mass meetings and practices on
    the athle- tic field.

    prepare for tlie hi;

Heading: PENN
Content: 

Heading: GAME
Content: 

Heading: The
Content: Bucknelllan offers no alibis or excuses for the loss of the Penn game. It is
    over now, and there is no use crying over spilled tailk.

Heading: We
Content: insist, however, that Bucknell outplayed

Heading: Penn
Content: in almost every feature of the game, and that if the

Heading: game
Content: were to be played over again on a neutral field. With neutral officials.
    Bucknell *would be the winner. The Buckncllian, in behalf of the etudent
    body, wishes to express the deepest sympathy to Perkins, '24, *who was
    called

Heading: home
Content: because of the death of his father. ! , .

Content: 

Heading: SAYS
Content: -rvAm NsKw vN>*o DOE<%vvf ^ e.v.<<.<<>>HPvt>>*T

Heading: '"^>N.
Content: With soinewliat of the same "pep"

Heading: shown
Content: during the season last year, the Bucknell Glee Club Is fast reor- ganizing for
    Viuit looks like the best season yet

Heading: known
Content: at BucknoU, Last season brought forth the best club that has represented the
    university in years and this year the prospects point to an even more active
    and bet- ter year than last season proved to be. Professor Stulz, dean of
    the Music School, is again director of the club and Italph Hartz is the
    manager.

Heading: Any
Content: students desiring to try out for the club should attend the rehear.sels as
    announced from time to time on th.< bulletin boards and consult with Prof.
    Stolz or Manager Hartz. There should be a wealth of material in the Freshmen
    cla.^s, and these

Heading: new
Content: men, added to the remaining members of last year's club as a nucleus, should
    develop into a wonderful organiza- tion to repret^ent Bucknell for the
    coming season. Students

Heading: who
Content: can play the trombone, clarinet and flute are especially needed for the orches-
    tra work under the direction of "Bobby" Hartz. Plans for the year, as
    announced by Manager Hartz. include trips that cover practically tlie same
    ground as last year with (juite a number of

Heading: new
Content: cities added to the list.

Heading: The
Content: usual local dates will be secured, too, for already the sunounding towns are
    asking for concerts and are anxious to hear the club again. The coast to
    coast trip looks very favorable ac- cording to the management, and will no
    doubt be taken. Plans of the club also include a minstrel show to t)e given
    in the near future. The

Heading: members
Content: of the club are practicing

Heading: now
Content: for this event, which will prove of unusual interest to the college and the
    town. Rehearsals be- gin this week. Every student should be on the look-out
    for the date and back the event.

Heading: made
Content: up for it in true school spirit. The line up was as follows: Part of the
    prepapration of Buck- nell for the big

Heading: game
Content: with

Heading: Penn
Content: was the super mass meeting held in Buck- nell Hall last Thursday evening. For an
    hour the cheerleaders, Florin and Bcchlell and a

Heading: number
Content: of speaker.s, instilled confidence and enthusiasm into the minds of the nuMubers
    of the team and of the student body. The cheering threatened to tear off the
    roof and break out the sides of the building, while the stamping of feet
    would have completed the destruc- tion. I'opular songs were roared out from
    lusty throats in the early part of the meeting. "Ray, Bucknell" and
    "Bucknell Warriors" were repeated more than once. Cheers and yells for the
    team and for the speakers as they were intro- duced cau.sed

Heading: many
Content: a hoar.se voice. The Bucknell Band was on hand with plenty of harmonious racket.

Heading: When
Content: the Hall

Heading: was
Content: practically filled, the members of the team who were not afraid to face the
    music marched up the aisle, while the stu- dent body exercised their lungs.
    Mason, Prc-^idenl of the Senior Class, introduced as the first speaker, C.
    E. Gla:s, this year's graduate manager. Mr. Glass appealed to the students
    for their entire cooperation, telling them that his work and the woik of all
    athleltic promoters would be in vain without loyalty from the stu- dent
    body.

Heading: A
Content: 

Heading: number
Content: of the team spoke more or le.^s briefly. One anJ all e\pres,^<<'d confidence In
    the downfall of Penn.

Heading: The
Content: 

Heading: men who
Content: spoke were Dooley, Captain Ivnstos, Reed, McDerniolt. Morrett, and Blehl, in the
    order named. Tlie two feature addresses f)f the evening were

Heading: made
Content: by Prof. Leo Rockwell and Registrar B. F. Thomas. Prof. Rockwell called up some
    of BuckneH's old record.^ and reviewed them in the light of pre- sent day
    events.

Heading: He
Content: told of a team of twenty-five years ago. and of its hopes, .successes, and
    failures.

Heading: He
Content: concluded with the statement that Leuisbur^; re,-icUnts were rumored to be
    taking out h'avy insurance on all their movable wooden property. Reg- istrar

Heading: Thomas
Content: centered his talk upon a plea for fair, clean football all tho time; and cited
    instances of dirty playing. Honesty, faithfulness, and clean playing were
    the points he em- phasized. It was announced that on Friday students were to
    as.semble at the Pennsylvania station to give the team a rousing send-off.
    It was al.so an nounced that in case of a Bucknell victory, .'chool v.ould
    be "out" on .Vionday. and thai in the evealiiK a big bonfire would be built
    on th" .Athletic field.

Heading: Freshman
Content: 

Heading: The
Content: following are the rules which the Freshies must obey or pay the penalty:

Heading: FRESHMAN
Content: 

Heading: RULES
Content: 1920 1 Freshmen must at all times be courteous and show respect to teach- ers.
    uppercla.ssmen and sophomores. >

Heading: The
Content: 

Heading: Alma
Content: Mater must be learn- ed within a week by all freshmen. 3.

Heading: No
Content: high school, prep or other school insignia is to be worn. 4. Silk hose are not
    to 1*

Heading: worn
Content: except on Sunday. 5

Heading: A
Content: green ribbon, one half Incn wide is to be worn tied around the neck with a bow,
    consisting of loops three Inches long and streamers eighteen Inches long.
    Attached to one end of this ribbon must be the fresh- man's name card. 6
    Freshmen must give precedence to all sophomores wishing to use the tdeph.me
    or to enter the post office. 7. Freshmen must not cut <

Heading: ampus
Content: or cut corners

Heading: when
Content: out walking. 8. Freshmen,

Heading: when
Content: addressinR sophomores, must say "Yes. Miss." or "No, Miss." as the case
    requires. " 9.' Freshmen must not be heard discussing men. 10. Freshmen must
    wear hats ,.,.i.,.n off campus. 11. Hair nets or veils must not be worn
    except on Sunday. 12. All violations of the above rules shall be dealt with
    accordingly.

Heading: The
Content: following regulations govern- ing class absences were adopted by the faculty: 1.
    Only absences caused by the ap- pointments of the University

Heading: may
Content: be excused by the Dean. Students should present to the Dean in writing a Just
    and sufficient rea.-^on for the absence It is understood that no Professor

Heading: may
Content: grant an excuse of any charac- ter. 2. The total

Heading: number
Content: of absences In each Semester shall be reported at the close of each Semester. 3.
    Grades shall be presented to the Dean at the close of each Semes- ter
    showing the standing of the stu- dent for work done In class on a basis of
    100 as provided for in the Catalog page 86. 4. Whenever a student shall have
    accumulated a total of IS unexcused absences from class and chapel dur- ing
    a Semester, the Dean shall deduct one semester-hour from the student's total
    credits for graduation.

Heading: He
Content: .shall notify the student of such deduction and require

Heading: him
Content: to register for addi- tional work for the succeeding Sem- ester. 5. If. in
    meeting the above re- quirements, the student must carry work beyond that
    allowed by the reg- ulation in the course which he i.-; taking, he shall be
    charged for the additional work In accordance with the rule governing "Extra
    Hour.s" as printed in the Catalog, page 84. C. On the authority of the
    Chair-

Heading: man
Content: of the Committee on Standing and Attendance, each Professor is authorized to
    Jtreat all absences up to October 11th according to his judge- ment.

Heading: GAME.
Content: In order to accomplish great things

Heading: man
Content: has found union of purpose to be of the utmost necessity.

Heading: No
Content: great group of individuals ever

Heading: won
Content: a bat- tle uiile.ss ihty worked togetlier as a unit. The only

Heading: way
Content: 

Heading: man
Content: can work In unity is to select leaders and then follow- the leaders. The popular

Heading: way
Content: of choosing leaders is by election.

Heading: We
Content: elected a cheer leader some time ago

Heading: who
Content: will lead the parades and dem- onstratlans.

Heading: He
Content: l.s popular with the student body. Let every loyal stu- dent stand by him. Let's
    hear no whisper of discontent. The last year hfifi brought great changes in
    the ad- ministration of the University. With it has come a shifting power in
    the student body. Former leaders have been retired in favor of

Heading: men
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: have found popular favor.

Heading: The
Content: change was due and It came. Good

Heading: men
Content: will fall in line behind the new leaders. Straeplers will soon be lost from the
    line forever. Bucknell is go- ing on, greater today than ever be- fore, to
    greater things than ever be- fore attempted.

Heading: No
Content: 

Heading: man
Content: is big enough to be a leader unless he is big enough tj take his place

Heading: among
Content: the followers of his .succes.sor.

Heading: No
Content: 

Heading: man
Content: is so great but what tlie world .soon finds a greater.

Heading: We
Content: are going to have unity

Heading: among
Content: the boosters of the University. If a

Heading: man
Content: cannot stand with the majority, Le Ls not playing fair tohim.<elfnor to his
    .school. Get together and felo- brate our athletic victories. Back
    *verythlng the school attempts and you will

Heading: be
Content: building for your

Heading: own
Content: success. It is the boosters that run the world.

Heading: GREAT
Content: 

Heading: NEED
Content: If there is one need that is para-

Heading: mount
Content: for the success of Bucknell, u- thletics this year, it is development or
    organized and effective cheering. Coaches and players will testify to the
    fact that the vocal and spiritual support of a well trained and well led
    cheering section is an Important factor in the winning of games. Bucknell,
    long noted for her spirit and for the cheering ability of her student body,
    has been lax in main- taining this reputation in the past few years. This,
    like

Heading: many
Content: other de- fects,

Heading: may
Content: be blamed partly upon the effects of war, but not entirely .so. Both cheering
    staffs and student body have*been apathetic in their support of Buckneli's
    teams. The ex- perience of the past year has proven that the substitution of
    individual witticisms for organized support is a failure. It Is the duty
    this year of the cheer leader and his asj^Lstants to develop and maintain a
    cheering body that is well trained and enthusiastic. This is not an easy
    task, but it is a neces- .sary one. and it merits the support of every loyal
    Bucknellian. It is a task which must be begun soon and con- tinued thruout
    the entire year. It is a task that coaches, players and alum ni

Heading: demand
Content: and expect to be accom- plished. It is a task in which the greatest service is

Heading: demanded
Content: of the Freshman cla.ss. Bucknells athletic teams this year will fight to the
    limit of their en- durance and ability, just in so

Heading: much
Content: as Buckneli's

Heading: men
Content: and

Heading: women
Content: rally behind them with the full strength f)f voice and enthusiasm.

Heading: URSINUS
Content: Another forward step in givin;.; students and other resident

Heading: members
Content: of the College conununlty additional buying convenience is announced by the
    College Supply Store. It is

Heading: now
Content: possible thru special ar- rangement with a bureau of expcit shoppers in
    Philadelphia to place an order with the Ursinus College Sup- ply Store for

Heading: ANY
Content: article desired froma Philadelphia store. The shop- pers will personally select
    the arti- cle desired at the lowest retail pricei available and ship via
    parcels ex- press to the College Store on the same day. It is thus possible
    to secure ar- ticles within twenty-four to forty- eight hours.

Heading: The
Content: only charge for this service will be a ten per cent, ad- vance on the purchasing
    price to cover cost of ordering, shopping, and shipment.

Heading: No
Content: charage will be

Heading: made
Content: for shipment except from those con- cerns which do not nuike mail order
    deliveries free, in which case postag? ischarged. Students with account.^ at
    the Supply Store

Heading: may
Content: receive ciedit on their purchases for fifteen days. At the annual oratorical
    contest of the Chinese Students' Prohibition League, F. P. Chen, University
    of .Michigan,

Heading: won
Content: first place, and Mis;s Lily Soo Hoo, Oberlin College,

Heading: won
Content: second honors.

Content: International College at Smy- rna never clo.ses its doors. Classes are held all
    year, and there are no va- cations.

Content: fiiHt regular meeting of thv? Chemical Engineering Society wa-; held in the
    Chemical Labratory laat Thursday evening with a good

Heading: num-
Content: ber In attendance. After the usual preliminaries the meeting waa turn- ed over
    to the program committee. Mr. Merrill Dewlre gave a very In- teresting talk
    on "The Produillon and Fabrication of Aluminum," as It Is done In the
    N'iagara Falls plant of the United States

Heading: Alumnlum
Content: Co.

Heading: He
Content: explained the whole process of the manufacture, from the time the ore is
    received until It Is the finished product. Kheet alumnium. The capa- city of
    the plant at the preaent time is about two million pounds per month.

Heading: The
Content: method of removing the metal from the ore l.s

Heading: known
Content: aa the "Hall Process" Mr. Dewlre touchei on the production and reduction of I
    the ore, remeltlng, rolling, annealing, packing and shipping.

Heading: He
Content: also brought in the lay out of the factory as well as the source of electrical i
    power and methods of application. ! Samples were on hand and passed '

Heading: Hounds
Content: were de- feated by Ream's Bean Jugglers last Saturday afternoon in one of the
    most spectacular games ever witness- ed on the local campus. The

Heading: game
Content: was called at three o'clock and start- ed at three forty-five. After a .secret
    s^crlmmage held by moonlight the pre- vious evening Moyer's delegation were
    ready for a hard battle. But "Mother" Ream's boys baffled them by a system
    of signals which posi- tively could not be understood by anyone. Forward
    passes figured ex- ten.sively, the

Heading: won

Heading: W
Content: Smith Iniittee cannot refuse to pay It. ' It Is the belief of the finance com-
    mittee that this system should ap- peal to the students and that after It
    has gotten Into working order it will prove as successful at Bucknell as it
    has in other colleges. Organizations having funds aside from those collected
    from the budget

Heading: may
Content: have separate accounts for these funds If they desire, but It Is hoped that they
    will avoid the complexity of two accounts by placing this

Heading: amount
Content: In the general students organization account. This amount will then be credited
    to the organization In ques- tion on the books of the finance com- mittee.
    At the end of the year an Itemized statement will be published showing the
    financial status of each organization. (Turn to Page

Heading: Two)
Content: With the

Heading: Penn
Content: State "X:ollegian ' as host, the Intercollegiate Newspa- per Association held
    Its annual Fall conference at State College Friday and Saturday. The

Heading: members
Content: of th.- *Collegian" staff proved to be Ideal hosts, and everything possible was
    done for the convenience and enter- tainment of the visitors. The "Buck-
    nillian" was represented by Manager Victor a. Clare and Editor George
    Sduiyler,

Heading: who
Content: 

Heading: made
Content: the trip Fri- day by automobile. The first meeting was held Friday evening in
    the Liberal Arts building on the Penn State Campus, and af- ter the meeting
    the

Heading: members
Content: were en- tertained at a dance at the Sigma Chi hou.se. Saturday morning the
    variou.- newspaper representatives were con- ducted on a tour through the
    campu.-. and inspected the buildings with in- terest, especially the
    agricultural and dairy farms. They were also treat' d to a view from the top
    of "Old Main" from which point they could look in to four counties as well
    a.s see a beautiful view of the Penn State, campus. Saturday afternoon the
    visiting journalists were taken to

Heading: New
Content: Beaver Field, where, in a reserved box in th<

Heading: new
Content: stands, especially decorated for the occasion, they saw Penn State pile up a
    109-7 score against Lebanon Valley, in a contest which .seemed more like a
    track-meet than a foot- ball game. That evening a smoker was held for the I.

Heading: N.
Content: A.

Heading: members
Content: at the Phi Delta Theta house, follow- ing which the

Heading: members
Content: weat to dances at the Phi

Heading: Gamma
Content: Delta, Alpha Zeta, and Pi

Heading: Kappa
Content: Alpha houses, using the Penn State custom of vi.^iting from house to houae.

Heading: A
Content: very interesting business session was held in the Liberal Arts build- ing on
    Friday evening, at which time it was decided to have the next con- ference
    at Gettysburg in May.

Heading: The
Content: visitors were welcomed to Penn State by Dr. Stoddard, dean of Liberal Arts
    department, followed by a paper by II. C. .Kiessling. of *'Pennsylvania
    Grit", telling of the

Heading: making
Content: of a weekly newspaper, and also telling the cause of the advance In the cost of
    printing different papers.

Heading: The
Content: *Thlelonsian". of Thiel College, was admitted into the association by a
    unanimous vote of the

Heading: members
Content: pre- .sent. The design for the key of the a.ssociatlon was selected, and will be
    sent to the Individual

Heading: The
Content: Bucknell Glee Club journeyed to Williamsport on Tuesday evening and furnished
    the music for the ser- vices tluit evening of the Pennsyl- 1 vanla Baptist
    State Convention meet- | ing in the First Baptist church. They , sang with
    splendid effect at both the evening banquet and the general ses- sion of the
    Convention, and

Heading: many
Content: were the words of commendation for their good work. Manager Hartz and his
    assistant remained in Williamsport on Wed- nesday and Thursday in order to
    con- fer witli the pastors and delegates from the various cities in regard
    to the possibilities of holding concerts in their cities, wonderful interest
    and co-operation were manifested on the part of ail, the possibilities for
    con- certs are so numerous that it

Heading: may
Content: bo neces,sary to hold two trips through western Pcnnsylvnia and the usual
    eastern trip, aside from the general run of "near-by" engagements. In all.
    delegates and pastors from al- most forty towns were interviewed and In
    almost every instance the con- versation was favorable for a con- cert.

Content: towns visited last year are asking for return concerts, as well a.^ the

Heading: EDITOR
Content: "I regret to ob.~crve the decline of tlie debating society in our modern
    *'ollege life. It .seems to

Heading: me
Content: that

Heading: we
Content: are giving too

Heading: much
Content: attention to atbletlcs and too little to the mental dovftlopment which comes
    from the TOfjgh and tumble contest of the de- bating .society." These are
    the words of William G. VIcAdoo, universally regarded as one ol America's
    brainest men. in a re- cent Interview with a representative of the Yale
    Daily News. Whether or

Heading: ot
Content: Mr.

Heading: McAdoo
Content: was justified in

Heading: making
Content: such a sweeping assertion, it is nevertheless a deplorable fact that so ittel
    attention has in late years been paid to debating at Buckn>'ll.

Heading: To
Content: say that there is no interest Bbovin here in the subject or that there is no
    material with which to ->>^'ork would be fallacious. If. as Mr.

Heading: McAdoo
Content: holds, debating Is ju.st as important as athletics in tb<< development of good
    citizenship

Heading: and
Content: if it is the purpose of Bucknell to .Tiend forth good citizens from her liall.s,

Heading: why
Content: then would it not be aa- vl.'iable for the school authorities to take a hand in
    the matter, giving txtme offi'ial recognition to those

Heading: who
Content: would elevate the mental stand- ard of the school and have a share in bringing
    honor to the institution?

Heading: U3
Content: Phi Gar..ma I'cHa bmther.-. As a result of the vastly Increased uses and need
    for passenger and truck transportation, the automotive Industry

Heading: now
Content: ranks second largest in the world. The

Heading: number
Content: of motor cars registered in this country has Increased 400 per cent since the
    war. The position of the General Mo- tors Corporation in this industry i:^
    unequalled

Heading: --
Content: in fact It is the largest producer of a finished product of any

Heading: kind--
Content: its sales for lt>>19 having total- led 1509,000,000 while for the six months
    ending June 30, 1920 Ihey were $320,000,000. In this great organization, the
    Ex- port division is perhaps the young est. but because of the strategic pos
    tion of the United States with re- gard to foreign trade, has rapidly become
    one of the most important of the subsidiaries.

Heading: From
Content: a personnel of less than 200 in August 1919. i>> has expanded until it

Heading: now
Content: employs more than 600 per.sons; but it is sti lanx- lous to secure

Heading: men
Content: of the riglit cali- bre

Heading: --
Content: mental, morall and physical- to represent it abroad. In the branch offices which
    are being estab- lished throughout the world. Realizing, however that the

Heading: num-
Content: ber of

Heading: men
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: possess the desired experience it* relatively small, the General .Motors Export

Heading: Company
Content: has already organized a Training School in which it seeks to develop

Heading: men
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: possess the potential qualities desired Naturally the college graduate is a
    logical candidate. Although he has a valuable training and mental dis-
    cipline, yet he is not immediately qualified to assume the responsibility
    that come with representing so great an enterpri.se abroad. Therefore, at
    great expense, the company gives each

Heading: man
Content: a year's training, divided as follows: Three months in which the student goes to
    school from 9 until 3 P.

Heading: M.
Content: in the

Heading: Company
Content: cla.ss room and has from 3 until 5 P.

Heading: M.
Content: for study. Dur- ing these three months he is given instruction in the principles
    of sales- manship, practical salesmanship, sales letter and report writing,
    cable messages, foreign trade, accounting foi-elgn languages, advertising,
    and office practice.

Heading: The

Heading: M.
Content: Director. Chester. Pa. Inadvertently in the last number of

Heading: The
Content: Bucknelllan a misstatement re- garding the graduate studies of Prof, llerold
    crept into a news item. The facts are that, while his master's work In
    Anglo-Saxon. Dante. Milton, and the drama, including a thesis en- titled
    "Four Typical Tragedies," was completed at Washington and Lee In 1911-12, he
    has since then devoted two years to graduate study In Eng- lish and American
    Literature at Col- \imbia University, bedding a Univer- sity Scholarship
    there in 1915-16 and more recently an instructorship in Extension English.

Heading: He
Content: has also com- pleted a considerable part of the re- search for his doctoral
    dissertation a work interrupted and delayed by his .service in the Adjutant
    General's Department of the U. S. Army.

Content: friends on a hike to Chlllisquaqua Saturday. ivarl D. Smith. '19, of El Dorado,
    Kan.sas. went in the following dipp- ing from "The Empire," a newspaper
    devoted to the interests of the em- ployes of the Kmpire Gas and Fuel
    Company. The clipping deals with the death of Leon

Heading: H.
Content: Noll. '19. I^eon

Heading: H.
Content: Noll, a junior engineer employed In the El Dorado field, wa.^ found dead Friday
    morning in the motor hou.se of Well No. 12, Ander- .'^on lease, four miles
    from El Dorado. The di;-covery

Heading: was
Content: 

Heading: made
Content: about eight o'clock. It is believed his death was caused by an electrical shock
    from the switch in the motor room w here he was v,f)rklng. Mr. .Noll had
    been working out of the Barnhlll sub-stAtlon two week.-* before his tragic
    death, and had been in the Kl Dorado field a short time previous to hi.s
    transfer to meter- reading work.

Heading: He
Content: was 2 6 years old. He

Heading: was
Content: a graduate electrical en- gineer from Bucknell University, and also took a
    course in the United States Naval Steam Engineering School.

Heading: He
Content: had been in the employ of the Empire Companies about four- teen months, coming
    to the Doherty organization as a junior engineer on his graduation from
    Bucknell. His home

Heading: was
Content: in Lowisb\irg, Pa., where he has a mother and several other relatives, and to
    which place the body

Heading: was
Content: sent for burial. Mr. Noll's death

Heading: came
Content: as a blow to his friends .not only

Heading: among
Content: his fellow junior engineers, but also to those

Heading: whom
Content: he had

Heading: come
Content: In contact during his year with the Empire or- ganization. Junior engineers of
    the EI Dorado field, meeting shortly after the death' of Leon

Heading: H.
Content: .Noll, who

Heading: was
Content: killed last F^rlday nu)rnlng by an electrical shock

Heading: and
Content: have adopted the follow- ing resolutions in

Heading: memory
Content: of their fellow engineer: Resolution

Heading: WHEREAS,
Content: the Almighty God, in His infinite wisdom has seen fit to remove from our midst
    our highly es- teemed confrere and co-worker, Leon Henry Noll; Whereas, the
    deceased, during thi' period of his association with us, has evidenced to
    those about lilni the aus- terity of his conscience by practicing what is
    right and by doing what \\ just; Whereas, it Is

Heading: common
Content: knowledge that in the death of our departed friend, the Henry L. Doherty

Heading: Com-
Content: pany has lost one of the most loyal, enthusiastic and promising Junior
    Engineers;

Heading: THEREFORE.
Content: 

Heading: BE
Content: 

Heading: IT
Content: 

Heading: RESOLVED
Content: that we, the Junior Engineers of the Henry L. Doherty Company, in meet- ing
    assembled, while bowing in sub- mission to the win of our Heavenly I'ather,
    do hereby express our most profound sorrow for the death of our dearly
    beloved associate, Leon Henry Noll: . cj.

Heading: RESOLVED
Content: 

Heading: FURTHER,
Content: that copies of this resolution be sent to all Junior Engineers of the
    Bartleville school, to the family of the deceased, and to "The Empire

Heading: and
Content: the "Buck- nellian" for publication.

Heading: SONNTAG
Content: Committee. September 4, 1920.

Heading: PANORAMIC
Content: 

Heading: PHOTO
Content: 

Heading: TAKEN
Content: 

Heading: A
Content: panoramic view of the student body of Bucknell University was taken last

Heading: Monday
Content: afternoon on the athletic field. With few exceptions the entire body of students
    turned out for the picture which was origin- ally scheduled for \.\e.
    forenoon. This is the first picture of this nature that has been taken since
    the year 1916. It is the custom to take such views of the students from time
    to time but no such picture has been laken since three years; before the S.
    A. T. C. period.

Heading: Two
Content: views of the group were taken one of which will be used for this years edition
    of the "L'Agenda". Copies of the pictures will be placed on sale to the
    students at various central points as soon as th>>-y are finished. It is
    expected that the views will be completed within a very short time.

Heading: MINISTERIAL
Content: 

Heading: HIKE
Content: Fifteen couples participated in the annual ministerial hike last Saturday
    Leaving the

Heading: Sem
Content: about eleven A.

Heading: M.

Heading: Morning.
Content: ArmiHtice Day, Nov. 11, will be obKerved with appropriate Kervices at Bucknell.
    Thin fact was

Heading: made
Content: 

Heading: known
Content: to the student body at chapel exer- cises, at which lime President

Heading: Emory
Content: 

Heading: W. Hunt
Content: announced that at the re- quest of Senior Council the faculty had decided to
    allow a holiday on :

Heading: November
Content: 11, instead of November 2.

Heading: A
Content: committee was appointed, com- posed of Mason. Davis, MacUerniott and Quinn. to
    take charge of the activities of the day and to

Heading: make
Content: up a suitable program of patriotic ser- vices and sports. This committee be-

Heading: came
Content: active at once and by the end of the past

Heading: week
Content: had a rough outline of the day's events ready.

Heading: When
Content: this rough outline wa.s

Heading: made
Content: public, it was with the explanation that a de- tailed program would be ready for
    publication in another week. There will be a parade in the morn- ing. This
    is assured, although the lineup of the organizations and the time of
    starting are not yet definite. Several organizations will send dele-
    gations. They are the Lewisburg Post of the American Legion;

Heading: Company
Content: 

Heading: M
Content: of the National Guard of Peunsylva- nia, with headquarters in Lewisburg; and the
    Civil

Heading: War
Content: Veterans. The line will form at the Tustin gymna.sium After forming at the
    gymnasium, the line will march to the Baptist church 80 as to reach that
    place at 10 o'clock. The formation of the students delegations in the parade
    will be announced at a later date. At the Baptist church, a patriotic
    service will be held. Dr. John

Heading: Howard
Content: Harris will be the speaker of the day. but his subject has not yet been

Heading: made
Content: public. The Glee Club Quartet has promised to sing several songs. Seats for the
    faculty and their wives and for the townpeople will be re- .served. This
    fact and that of the entire plans for the Armistice

Heading: Day
Content: celebration will be announced in all the churches of the town in ample time.

Heading: An
Content: attempt Is being

Heading: made
Content: to secure General Charles Clement, of Sunbury. for an address in the morning's
    ser- vice at the Baptist church. General Clement

Heading: made
Content: an investigation trip of Europe before the World War, and upon the outbreat of
    the war wa.^ declared too old for active service. Since then he has been
    travelljng and lecturing, and has gained for himself an enviable record as a
    lecturer. If the fact can be accomplished the committee will have General
    Cle- ments here Nov. 11. Dr..

Heading: Hunt
Content: will be in charge of th.^ services at the church. It is expected that a very
    large

Heading: number
Content: of .people will be present; and, in fact, some doubt as to the ability of the
    seatln capacity of the church to accomod the crowd 1h entertained. However,
    every student of the University, to- gether with the faculty and ton-n-
    people. Is urged to attend the service. ) In the afternoon the Freshmen-Soph
    omore foot ball

Heading: game
Content: will be held on the athletic field, and at this time the organizations above
    mentioned will be the guests of honor.

Heading: The
Content: 

Heading: game
Content: will be called at 2:30 o'clock, and Inasmuch as a great deal depends upon the
    outcome of this

Heading: game
Content: a re- cord crowd is looked for. In the evening the fraternity houses will keep
    open house and in- formal smokers will be held.

Content: faculty will be the guest.s cff the

Heading: What
Content: Muhlenberg thought of the big Orange and Blue team which catised such havoc at
    Allentown last week Is

Heading: shown
Content: b'^' the following clip- ping fro

Heading: mthe
Content: Muhlenberg Weekly. Incidentally, it is very fairly writ- ten, and shows that
    true Ideals of sportsmanship are being lived up to at the Allentown college.
    Bucknell brought their far-fam- ed football team to Allentown last Sat\irday
    and after sixty minutes of play against the Cardinal and Gray, it was agreed
    by all present at the game, that the team had fully lived up to its press
    dispatch repu- tation. The final score wav 43-0. the 'argest score rolled up
    against .Muh- lenberg on the

Heading: home
Content: field in the last fifteen years. Bucknell presented a wonderful team, consisting
    of a heavy line and backfield. but unusually fast, a team well-drilled in
    teamwork and u.^ing splendid interference. Bowser at full- back, was easily
    Bucknells star,

Heading: mak
Content: ing four touchdowns and a 43 yard field goal. All credit must be given the
    Bucknel Iteam which played a hard, clean game.

Heading: Few
Content: penalties were inflicted, all being on technical grounds. Despite the evidence
    of the score, the .Muhlenberg team, shoved sftatches of Its old-time
    brilliancy. The team started the

Heading: game
Content: minus Wills, Lewis and Parks, but all thre>>> soon got in. Wills and Feldman
    easily shared the honors for the day with superb tackling. Feldman saved

Heading: many
Content: a touchdown

Heading: when
Content: he alone stood between the runner and the goal posts. Wills, despite an injured
    shoulder,

Heading: made
Content: tackle after tackle on the line, and twice did the unusual feat of passing the
    ball on Bond

Heading: who
Content: punted. Wills being the first

Heading: man
Content: to nab the runner where he caught the ball. Freitag. Crowley, Parks and Lewis
    also shone. Bticknell started off in the very first quarter, obtaining the
    ball on a fumbel by Anderson, after he had dropped on the ball on the five-
    yard line. Bucknell went clean

Heading: down
Content: the field for a touchdown, repeating the process six times in the game. In the
    second quarter. Bow.><or kicked a frat'ernltl^. and interv'lsTting will be I
    beautiful field goal from the 43-yard The first half of tlie tcni* match
    between the faculty and the Varsity tennis team was played last week

Heading: when
Content: the young

Heading: men
Content: defeated their older opponents in doubles by th<; score of three matches to one.

Heading: The
Content: singles matches of the tournament were not played due to the lateness of the
    day. They will be finished at an early date. Professors Balltntine,
    Rassweller. Rockwell and Mr. Bur- roughs upheld the honor of the fac- ulty
    and ISrandt. Purnell, Gray and Koch played for the Varsity. This match

Heading: was
Content: the Initial appear- ance of Purnell and Gray on tln' school tenni.s team.
    Purnell was out for the team last year and displayed real merit at that time
    but such re- cent improvement in his playing ha;! warranted him a place on
    this year's team.

Content: other

Content: 

Heading: man
Content: on the team. Gray, is a

Content: of the Fresli

Heading: man
Content: class and bids well toward hold- ing

Heading: down
Content: fourth place on the team.

Heading: He
Content: i.s rather undeveloped as yet but shows promises of becoming a val- uable man.
    Profei<<sor Ballentine played with his usual excellent form and with his
    partner, Mr. Burroughs succeeded in cau.sing a strenuous match against
    Brandt and

Heading: Koch
Content: which the under- graduates finally managed to annex by the scores. 6-3, 11-9.
    After this match ,the Ballcntine-Burroughs combination defeated Purnell and
    Gray In a hard fought match, 7-5, 5-7 and 9-7. Profe.';sor.'3 Rockwell and
    Rass- weiler lost their matches ^ut put up strenuous opposition in both.

    football, with his powerful The Bucknell University Glee Club rendered a

    Thursday night to a large sized crowd of musical enthusiasts. The Glee Club

    by the entire organ- ization was most acceptable to those present.

    Interpretation of "Meditation" from Thais was extre-

Heading: mey

    extremely well pleas- ing to the ear.

Heading: DEBATING
Content: In an article printed under the Student's

Heading: Forum
Content: of last week's issue a student expressed regret at the de- cline of debating in
    Bucknell. 'Why,' he says, "wor.ld it not be advisable for the school
    authorities to take a hand in the matter, giving some offi- cial recugnition
    to those

Heading: who
Content: would elevate the mental standard of th-^ Bchool and have a share in bringing
    honor to the ins^titution?" In Buck- nell's case the question is already
    amswered. Bucknell does give official recognition to her debaters in the
    form of a debating B, similar to our athletic B. Insitnia for last year's
    team have been ordered and will be issued by Francis Reamer, manager of that
    team, at an early date. Granting that Mr. McAdoo's ob.-^er- vatlon
    concerning the decline of de- bating in college is correct, in the cat^e of
    Bucknell with

Heading: whom
Content: does tho fault lie? The triangular debatin;; league of last year, between
    Bucknell Dickinson, and Penn State, showed that Bucknell has the

Heading: making
Content: of a debating team. Arrangements aie

Heading: now
Content: being

Heading: made
Content: for this triangular league to be continued this year and for dual debates to
    take place with other Eastern colleges. Profe.ssor Rassweiler

Heading: now
Content: has a promising clas.-. In advanced debating and the same time la able and
    willing to give aid to any one

Heading: who
Content: wi.'^^h to try out for the team. At a meeting of the debating hoard, held
    October iHth. Ellis Smith '21 was elected manager and Wra. Sugden '22
    assistant manager of this year's team. Debaters of high chool or college
    experlenro and any

Heading: who
Content: are Interested in debating are urged to hand their names to one of the managers
    or to Professor Rass- weiler without delay.

Heading: The
Content: college has recognir^ed debating, the board is^ or- ganized and ready for
    business the only element remaining for a succes-s- ful debating year is the
    interest and participation of the student body. ^0

Heading: A
Content: 

Heading: PLEA
Content: 

Heading: rOR
Content: 

Heading: THE
Content: 

Heading: MODERN
Content: minds on problems of the elghtenth century or onthe problems of the twientieth
    century the more import- ant to UB? In short. " Is not the study of
    contemporary literature as impor- tant as that of classic literature?" Let

Heading: UB
Content: see in what contemporary literature consists. Of late years fic- tion has been
    the most prolific form of literature. Still more lately has sprung

Heading: up
Content: the short story. Professor Fries has ex- pre.s.sed the opinion that a new age of
    drama is about to dawn. In this per- iod of world reconstruction there
    should be just as spontaneous an out- burst of poetry as has succeeded every
    great

Heading: war
Content: of world history. In response to the situation two

Heading: new
Content: courses have been added to our cata- logue. Last years English

Heading: A
Content: course came as an innovation and as a shock to some of our educators. But Pro-ie
    Fiction, the outgrowth of English A. and a course In the Modern

Heading: Drama
Content: have

Heading: come
Content: to stay. Having admitted the importance of eontemporary literature to this ex-
    tent let us see what the University has to offer to hose whose curriculum
    does not include these two courses? Aside from current magazines the showing
    is pitiful. Over in and above of the library

Heading: two
Content: small sections, in dust and di.sorder, represent our en- tire collection of
    fiction .Less than twenty of these have been written within the twentieth
    century. Great authors of modern times such as Winston Churchill, Henry

Heading: Van
Content: Dyke,, John Galsworthy, and

Heading: H.
Content: G. Wells, are represented by one or two books each, Harold Bell Wright, Zane
    Gray, and

Heading: Gene
Content: Stratton Porter, acknow- ledged by the Freshman question- aire of reading as the
    most popular American novelists, are not repre- sented at all. Foreign
    novelists are almost unrepresented. Other forms of modern literature are
    totally missing.

Heading: No
Content: collection of worthy contemporary drama or of contemporary verse is found in our
    library.

Heading: W(c)
Content: offer these observations more as a plea than as a criticism. Where- ever the
    blame lies, it should be rem- edied unless

Heading: we
Content: are to concudle that the

Heading: muse
Content: of literature, and hence the muse of thought, suddenly died about fifty years
    ago, something should be done and that right quick- ly.

Content: the Purdue alumni In Monroe county.

Content: goal .set by the Purdue Union Board is $1,000,000, which they hope to raise by

    progressing very nicely. There are in charge of instruction three commis-
    sioned officers and three non-com- mlssion<<i officers. For the second year
    of its existence, the R. 0. T. C. unit has a record enrollment of 595
    students, the enrollment of all Fresh-

Heading: EDITORIAL
Content: The Story That

Heading: Was
Content: Never Published One of the famous stories of Edgar Allan Poe is entitled. "The

Heading: Imp
Content: Per- Terse." The circinustances recorded are of a

Heading: man who
Content: committed a crime undetected and was driven by lliis

Heading: Imp
Content: of Perversity to confess his guilt. Thin

Heading: Imp
Content: Perverse, or the ten- dency to do a thing simply because

Heading: we
Content: 

Heading: know
Content: we should not. is a strange but true phenonenon of

Heading: human
Content: na- ture, noted by le.s<<<er

Heading: men
Content: than Poe. There is a tradition in literary cricles however, that this tory is
    the second writing and that the circumstance;; of the first writing, which
    was re- fused by the printer, were wierd and Imaginative. In hl.s original
    draft Poe is credit- ed with dealing with the psychologi- cal reaction of a
    group of college ^^tu- dents. In

Heading: common
Content: circumstances h<' repre.-ent.s them as being normally Intelligent, God-fearing,
    and gentle- manly. It is in the daily assemblage for worship that the author
    turp'^ loose his Imp Perverse.

Heading: He
Content: tells a strange tale of young

Heading: men
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: nic normally well conducted coming into this chapel >crvlce stamping and
    fihouting. Educated gentlemen are represented a.-; .singing harmonicju-^ and
    unharmoniou.s chords in uni.-on with the chord struck on a piano a-

Heading: a
Content: signal for silence.

Heading: Men
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: are musically gifted are seized by the

Heading: Imp
Content: and refuse to sing or el.se shout discordant notes. ChristiHn gentl"- men, under
    the spell, keep up an \\n- dertone of conversation slurring re- marks about
    the leader, or actual profanity while the word of God 1-^ being read.

Heading: Many
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: are seldom ac- customed to open text books are stimulated liy the

Heading: Imp
Content: with a violent desire to study during the devotional service. Other bright wide-
    awake fel- laws are rfpres<'nted as suddenly feeling the dire need of a nap.
    To <^ap the climax the author credits the

Heading: Imp
Content: with ex'iting such a desire to return to recitations that young gen- tlemen push

Heading: and
Content: trample on the heels <if young ladif ^ in leaving the chapel. Thl.s story,
    acocrding to unauthen- tic tradition is supposed to have been refused by the
    publishers as being untrue to life in the American col- - leges of this day.
    .

Heading: ADVERTISING?
Content: Everybody appreciates the spirit

Heading: shown
Content: at Bucknell by the chalking on the floors.

Heading: However
Content: some care seems to be lacking, in several re- spects.

Heading: The
Content: Cla.ss Memorials hardly seem a fitting billboard. The stairs in .Main Building
    also .seem to have re- ceived an over-abundance of the coral product. It
    seems fitting to say that the top of the stej^s might be chalked, becau.se
    there it will soon disappear. The sides of the tpcps, however, present an
    entirely dif- ferent side of the Issue. There the chalk must stay until the
    janitor scrubs it off.

Heading: A
Content: little di.scretlon In advertising nuiy save tiniciand labor for the other
    fellow. Lets cooperate!

Heading: A
Content: Senior.

Heading: OUR
Content: 

Heading: NEW
Content: 

Heading: SPIRIT
Content: The Following article written by "Bobby Waddell, '20, and published Ina
    Pittsburg paper expresses to

Heading: my
Content: mind the

Heading: new
Content: spirit of Bucknell , "Bucknell is no longer a trial horse for the big colleges.

Heading: We
Content: have a big team this year, and we are startiiii^ to grow.

Heading: We
Content: had more students than

Heading: we
Content: could handle

Heading: when
Content: college opened in September.

Heading: Many
Content: extra acres of land have been acquired lately upon which to build. Athletics at
    Bucknell have been carried along just so-so, b\it there Is a revival on and
    it won't be long until

Heading: we
Content: will be up with the loaders.

Heading: Vou
Content: 

Heading: know
Content: it doesn't tak.^ long to get to the top these days."

Heading: BOOST
Content: Tliere are a certain few wet blankets in every institution In th" country
    whether that instituticMi Ix prison, asylum, hospital or school and in
    Bucknell

Heading: we
Content: have our few

Heading: who
Content: have long since adopted the

Heading: common,
Content: ordinary

Heading: hammer
Content: as their mainstay of equipemnt. These few fellow beings refuse to turn the
    doud.s inside out. They seem to feel that the only difference between school
    and jail if tliat in jail you have hopes of shortening you'- sentence while
    in school you

Heading: work
Content: only for clemency. They hover over every bit of sunshine ready to swoop

Heading: down
Content: and destroy it like a bunch of hawks. Thoy set up a wail at every opportunity,
    equal to that of the hound dog in Huckleberry Finn,

Heading: wh
Content: .sat and howled at the

Heading: moon
Content: becau.sH it was bright. These fellows accomplish nothing,

Heading: amount
Content: to nothing, are are wortli nothing minus to the school and to their fellow
    students.

Heading: The
Content: hamni'r is a great instrument for driving nails but a poor one for driving a-
    head. Con<<tr"'tive cirticl'^m has ac- complished wonders, l)ut destructive
    criticism has never accomplished any thing. Let's get together and learn to
    take things as they come. Forget about the thorns on the roses, think only
    of the fragrance of the blossom. If things are going

Heading: wrong
Content: don't sob. but get out and change them. Be alive and smile a bit and strive to

Heading: make
Content: your surroundings the brighter for your pre.-ence. Remember, an optimist i.--- a
    person

Heading: who
Content: sees a light where there isn't any and a pessimist la a person

Heading: who
Content: blows it out. so look about you and see the lights of opportunity and then cast
    aside your

Heading: hammer
Content: to lend your ef- forts toward a better Bucknell. *21

Content: ledge of the limits and possibilities of the camera, and use of the close-up,

Content: wafl called the big green horde swept

    min- utes,

    taste for the true and tlie beautiful. So an efort is being made, not to

    a means, whereby the who!'.' University can function culturally, a sort of
    open forum, to be called th-' Buck- nell Lyceum. It is proposed that it be-
    co-education having, be.iides the J t- erary and musical portions of the
    program, a perfectly democratic, unlve.^ity broad social feature. The plan

Heading: BOWSER
Content: (From Page One) P. Reynolds saw his possibilities and held him out of several
    important games, and then put him in on the line In order to arouse

Heading: him
Content: to lii.^ greatest effort.

Heading: He
Content: stands today as one of the greatest fullbacks in the country. I

Heading: He
Content: has been the outstanding Indi- vidual performer In every

Heading: game
Content: tlibn year. "Bow.ser is an all-round iOotl)all j player. His ability is not
    contined to particular phases of the game.

Heading: He
Content: performs equally well as a kicker, line-plunger, open-field runner, for- ward
    passer and defensive man. His line plunging and open-fleld run- ning are
    very spectacular. Seven of his eight touchdowns against Ur- sinus' and
    Mublenburg were made by straight line plunges, within their 10-yard lines,
    where the defense 1.^ always the stiffest. The eighth was

Heading: made
Content: on a crossed signal.

Heading: Wheu
Content: he found, himself in possession of tlie ball, with no one to receive It from
    him, and no Interference, he dug out for himelf, and unaided, tore thru the
    entire Muhlenburg team, shak- ing off a half dozen tacklers and car- rying
    the ball flfty-flve yards to the goal line. His kicking ability allows oppo-
    nents scant reason for any feeling of security.

Heading: He
Content: sends klckoffs high into the air and rarely drops them shurt of the goal lin(;.
    IIl.^ punts are ', usually forty-flve or fifty yards, and kicks the ball
    high enough to allow | the ends ample time to ge,t

Heading: down
Content: the I held and d^jp the receiver in his | tracks. Hi;, ability to accurately di-
    lect placement kicks between the ; goal posts from any distance less than
    half the length of the fi'ld, , makes hi.-, team dangerous every timo ' they
    pu.sh the ball into their

Heading: own
Content: I territory. I Playing as a defensive halfback. I not a single play has tot past
    him in the four games playi d th'^i year. In seviuai insianct ;ie ha.- '
    crossed to the other side of the lino ' and stopped the runner on nfi-tackh-
    i plays.

Heading: He
Content: has also knocked

Heading: down
Content: ' every forward pais which bii.i been | points which Bucknell has piled up as
    against their opponents' 14."

Content: 

Heading: The
Content: footbal season is over. Last September

Heading: when
Content: 

Heading: we
Content: came back to Buclcnell from far and near

Heading: we
Content: all turned out to football scrimmage, the

Heading: team
Content: looked promisiug, hopes ran high. Coach Reynolds

Heading: was
Content: given ;t

Heading: welcome
Content: which all but took

Heading: him
Content: off his I'eet. Rou.-iing mass meetings placed the whole student body bchir.il
    their team. But

Heading: now
Content: that the sea- son is over, as the smoke beglnp to Clear from the field of battle

Heading: we
Content: can look back to see

Heading: what
Content: 

Heading: we
Content: have ac- complished. In spite of the fact that we were disappointed in our high
    hopes of "beating Penn," in spile of the fact that our three great games
    were "al- mcstp." what is there in this year-; record which makes every
    Bucknell- ian proud of his football team'.'

Heading: The
Content: fact that our total of scores

Heading: amounts
Content: to 244 as against 37 for our opi>' i:i^nts and the fact that no team scored more
    than one touch

Heading: down
Content: on Us (luring the season .speaks for the consistent playing of the Orange and
    Blue eleven.

Heading: The
Content: fact that at the back of our line-up stands a

Heading: man
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: holds the second highest individual score in this years football records of
    America strikees a note of response In the heart of every Bucknellian.

Heading: And
Content: the fact that every player re- Bpects his coach and every student Ib proud of
    his team nuikes Bucknell fofttball a imit to be reckoned with.

Heading: Back
Content: of our whole football organ- ization stands "Pete" Reynolds, th' greatest coach
    Bucknell has ever

Heading: known.
Content: 

Heading: A
Content: driver and a master he

Heading: com
Content: 

Heading: mands
Content: the respect rather thati the familiarity of hi^ men.

Heading: The
Content: spirit with which his .equad does tho.se "lour laps around the track and un- der
    the cold .'-howers" after three hours of steady diill is the greatest
    tribute possible to his ability. His arrival in Lewisburg this fall, riding
    with President Hunt, in a cab

Heading: drawn
Content: 

Heading: by
Content: a njob of willing students, was an Index of his place in the heart of Bucknell.

Heading: Behnd
Content: 

Heading: him
Content: have stood a host of loyal supporters, all responsible for the success of the
    .-reason. Graduato- Eianager Glass Kas filled his office honorably and well.
    Only those

Heading: who
Content: have dealt with "Art" Harris as stu- dent comptroller

Heading: know
Content: what praise he deserves.

Heading: And
Content: "Bill" Willman as manager- well, suffice it to say that Bill has

Heading: managed
Content: as only the 'Kal.ser' himself could. Last but not least in the iiiachine.

Heading: we
Content: 

Heading: may
Content: mention Cap- taia ''Joe" KostoH

Heading: who
Content: silently fights his fierht with r^U fhf fight that is in him.

Content: who, thru

Heading: many
Content: hard

Heading: bumps
Content: h&n never been permanently disabled.

Heading: And
Content: finally in l)ack of the coach In previous years the

Heading: Xmas
Content: vaca- tion

Heading: was
Content: of three weeks duration. School floi-cd on or about the 17th of December, and
    opened about Janu- ary (J. This year it is closing the 22. and opening
    .January Gth, or nearly one week later. I wonder

Heading: why
Content: vaca- tion is so arranged tills year? The other colleges and larger high schools
    of the east close Wednesday December 15. or not later than the 17th.

Heading: Why
Content: can't Bucknell do the same and fall in line? In the negative

Heading: we
Content: are told: Bucknell must have a certain number of days upon which

Heading: we
Content: sliall hold classes to maintain her high standard. The wiiter

Heading: knows
Content: that otlier colleges open later in in the fall, have a vacation Just as long as
    our

Heading: own
Content: at Xnuii. and still dismiss at an earlier date in the spring. How- do they do
    It?

Heading: Do
Content: other colleges fall below the standard? Dec. 21, has been proclaimed a na-
    tional holiday, as the 300th anni- versary of 'the landing of our Pilgrim
    Fathcr.s. Will classe.4 be held upon that date? If classses are not held
    should cla.s.ses be resumed upon Tues- day and

Heading: Wedneday
Content: following? If doesn't seem right. Students,

Heading: why
Content: not talk it

Heading: up
Content: and endeavor to obtain a vacation from December 17th to January 6th? Lets all
    pull together.

    Dec. and a good orche.stra secured. The ccunmittee in charge consists of

Heading: TEACHER

Heading: SITUATION
Content: 

Heading: From
Content: Reports

Heading: By
Content: Those

Heading: Who
Content: 

Heading: Know
Content: 

Heading: An
Content: impression prevails that th,' teacher shortage throughout tli.- United States is
    no longer a serious problem. Recent reports received from county and
    district .superinten- dents in every State clearly indicate that such a
    conclu.'^ion is erroneous. While the average condition is slight- ly better
    than last year, due to markt improvement in States where salari^/s have been
    greatly increaat. the gen- oral situation hemain'^ practically un- clianged.
    The numl)er of .schools with out teachers and the still larger num- ber
    tatight by incompetent teachers sho wthat a very serious situation still
    exists, particularly in those States where salaries are lowest.

Heading: On
Content: September 1, 1920. the Na- tional Association sent a letter to every county

Heading: and
Content: district .superin- tendent of schools in the I'niled States, enclosing a retuin
    po.-^tal ( ard upon whieli were askt ten questions leuardinu the teacher
    situation in their respective counties. Tlie follow- ing is a tabulation of
    the replies re- ceived to thiee of the (juestions asked ( 1 ) The number of
    teaching posi- tions in the country or district cov- ered by the report; (2)
    the shortage of teachers at the opening of school in September, 1920; (3)
    the numl)e>>- of teachers below standarad

Heading: whom
Content: it had been neces.sary to accept in order to keep as

Heading: many
Content: schools as possible open. The standard referred to is. of cour.se, the

Heading: minimum
Content: for the given county or district, and teacher.s be- low standard are admittedly
    incom- petent.

Heading: The
Content: real shortage i.-!, there- fore, the

Heading: sum
Content: erf th" actual shortage and the

Heading: number
Content: of teachers below standard. Inrjuirics were .'^ent to 3,168 sup- erintendents
    and 1,492 replies had been received at the time this tabu- lation

Heading: was
Content: nuide. Oetoijci- 12. very re- port is signed by the county or dis- trict
    superintendent nuiking it, and the infornuition is, therefore, the most
    reliable that can be obtained.

Heading: The
Content: figuies given in the first five columns are taken directly from tlie signed
    reports.

Heading: The
Content: "estimated short- age and below standard" given in file last column is based on
    the assump- tion that the unreported counties of a State would show
    conditions tlie same as those reported. Unquestionably the greatest edu-

Heading: away

Heading: who
Content: were receiving pa.ssing grades in tlielr work at the end of ten weeks, were
    required to sign a slip pledging them- selves to obey the laws and regula-
    tions of Buckneli University as long as they were

Heading: members
Content: of the same. Tile student was not considered a

Heading: member
Content: of the institution until after matritulation. Last year a list of the Freshmen

Heading: who
Content: were

Heading: up
Content: in their

Heading: work
Content: was post- ed at the

Heading: end
Content: of ten weeks, but this year the list will not be posted.

Heading: FRATERNITY

Content: local fraternity has, with Pres- ident Hunt's consent,

Heading: made
Content: Its ap- pearance at Rucknell under the

Heading: name
Content: of Phi Theta Sigma.

Heading: The
Content: nu\jority of the

Heading: members
Content: of the fraternity have been in associa- tion for the past two or three years as
    a boarding club. Due to the friend- ship that has (existed

Heading: among
Content: the club

Heading: members
Content: during this period, some

Heading: new
Content: form of closer relatlonsliip was desired and although the promoters of the
    fraternity had dlscu.^sed the proposition at length last spring, no
    (iuflnlte steps were taken toward complete organization until the open- ing
    of school this fall.

Heading: B
Content: 17 he was Commissioner of Health. During- the epidemic of infantile pa- ralysis
    In 1916, the work of the De- partment of Health of

Heading: New
Content: York City gained general appreciation of the state and f-doral public health
    offi- cers. Entering

Heading: Army
Content: service as Major, Medical Corps, In January 1918, Dr. Emerson served in the
    American E.\- pedillonary Force until June 1919. during which period he was
    in charge of the offlye of epidemiology of tho Chief Surgeon.

Heading: He
Content: was advanced to rank of Lieutenant-Colonel, and In March 1919 to the rank of
    Colonel, and received decorations from the French Republic of Chevalier of
    the Legion d'Honneur, and the Medallle dese Epidemies. During the past year.
    Dr. Emerson organized the Department of Hygleno and Preventive .Medicine at
    Cornell University, and directed the Hospital and Health Survey of
    Cleveland, Ohio for the Cleveland Hospital Council. Dr. Emerson has recently
    return- ed from Europe, where he attended the International (Conference on
    Cer- tified Causes of Death, as a represen- tative of the Bureau of the
    Census, and the International Conference on Tuljenulosis as a delegate of
    the Na- tional Tuberculosis A.ssociation. Dr. Emerson holds the degrees of

Heading: A.
Content: B., Harvard, 1S9G, and

Heading: A.
Content: 

Heading: M.
Content: and

Heading: M.
Content: D., Columbia, 1S99.

Heading: He
Content: has contributed numerous ar- ticles of technical, medical character dealing with
    problems of publico health education, in medical per- iodicals.

    free from initiation into col- lege life.

Heading: They
Content: were ducked in a lake at mid-night on a Friday and then taken into a nearby
    cemetary to hear some advice from "ghosts" percjied on tombstones.

    basketl)all committee, rubs governing the league and the con- tests woje
    made up and adopted, and a schedule

Heading: made
Content: out. The rules for the

Heading: coming
Content: season are as follows: Rule 1.

Heading: Games
Content: shall start at 7:15 and 3:30, with 15 minute halves.

Heading: Games
Content: shall be forfeited if delin- riuent team does not appear within 15 minutes after
    scheduled time. " Rule 2.

Heading: Games
Content: 

Heading: may
Content: be postponed upon consent of both managers, but these games must be played off
    in the seven days following scheduled date of such postponed game. Rule 3.
    Intercollegiate basketball rules shall govern all contests. Rule 4.

Content: 

Heading: man
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: Is not

Content: the first .seven on the varsity sfniad, as picked by the coach, is eli- gible in
    play. Rule 5.

Heading: AUDIENCE,
Content: The condition of Dr. John

Heading: Howard
Content: Harris,

Heading: who
Content: underwent an operation at the (ieisinger hospital at Danville last Wednesday is
    very good, and steadily improving, according to the latest reports that have
    been re- ceived, Dr Harris was taken to the hospital last Tuesday, and was
    op- erated upon the following day. Due to hi.s age, cocaine was injected in-
    stead of the application of ether be- ing made. Dr. Hnrris

Heading: came
Content: out of the operation very well, and imme- diately began to improve.

Heading: He
Content: is re- maining at the hospital only at the insistenf e of the phys;icians.
    Reports yesterday indicated that he is

Heading: now
Content: well on tlie road to health.

Content: Psi

Heading: made
Content: its flr<<t ap- pearuiKu on the intcrfraterntiy floor last Wednesday evening,

Content: Chi drawing first blood and following by consist- ent team work and good
