Heading: Two
Content: On last

Heading: Wednesday
Content: afternoon the Bucknell

Heading: Lyceum
Content: held a very Inter- esting meeting at which about .seventy students were present.
    The program was one of an entire social nature and an atmosphere of real fun
    prevailed. It is seldom that the stu- dents get an opportunity to get to-
    gether outside of their respective groups and it was an opportunity that all

Heading: who
Content: took advantage of thor- oughly enjoyed. The presentation of "The Three Bears"
    was given with *Tiny" Ha.^en as the "little

Heading: wee
Content: bear,"

Heading: We
Content: can all imagine "Tiny" as the little bear and with her voice to match it
    certainly was a .scream. Laughter flowed free- ly during this number.
    "Curly" Lawson then rendered .several ditties accompanying himself on the
    banjo. They were very well given and ap- preciated by all. "Tiny" Hasen

Heading: was
Content: again featured in a

Heading: mock
Content: opera scene from

Heading: Romeo
Content: and Juliet. "Tiny" had to keep up her established reputation and she certainly
    did. The crowd was then divided In half in a contest to see which sides
    could think of the most slang expressions in ten min- utes.

Heading: The
Content: king's English

Heading: was
Content: mur- dered. One side thought of about eighty ann the other about fifty. Anything
    from

Heading: "Where
Content: do you get that stuff," to "Stand back, you'll get your money," was used. Sue
    Post then gave a reading entitled "The Courtier." It wius v.ell acted out
    and showed marked ability. The after- noon closed with the Hinging of sev-
    eral popular airs and was one of real fun. The next meeting will be held
    thi.s Wednesday afternoon

Heading: when
Content: an after- mjon will be spent with Rudyard i\ipllng. The whole school is invited
    and it is hoped that a large

Heading: number
Content: will avail themselves of this oppor- timity.

Heading: MAYPETERSOlT"
Content: 

Heading: SCORES
Content: 

Heading: BIG
Content: 

Heading: HIT
Content: 

Heading: May
Content: Peterson, the first of the art- ists presented in the course by

Heading: Mu
Content: Phi Epsilon, delighted and captivated a very large audience last Friday ev-
    ening at the Bapti-st church. The soprano has made herself

Heading: known
Content: as one of the most gracious and winsome of the younger singers befort' the
    public, both in concert and at the Metropolitan. Her voice Is beyond
    reproach in warmth, beauty and technique, and is always on pitch, a virtue
    of tew singers. Style, irreproachable taste and finish, combined with great

Heading: mu-
Content: sicianship, impart to every phase of her

Heading: work
Content: a delicate distinction and great artistry. One of the charming things about her
    concert was the description she gave before her songs. It seemed to bring
    her audience closer and gave them a moie personal feeling towards the
    singer. Credit Is certainly due Stuart Roi^s for his finished
    accompaniaments. It is hoped that MLss Peterson will return for another
    engasement. The varsity basketball team

Heading: won
Content: but one of its three games on its trip, this from F.

Heading: &
Content: 

Heading: M,
Content: by a score of 2 to 14.

Content: other two games went against us, the Temple

Heading: game
Content: by a close margin of 27 to 24, and the Swarthmore

Heading: game
Content: by a larger margin of 21 to 11. The team's defence on all occasions proved
    strong, our weakness being in the offense, the forwards being weak in
    advancing the ball, as well as in shooting F. &.

Content: '20. Bitner '21. Hi len Bodine '20. Ethyle Culbert '2'^, G,

Heading: W.
Content: Lees '20, C,

Heading: A.
Content: Zeller '21, Mar- garette Fowler ex'23, Reynolds El- liott ex'lS, and Robert
    Grone ex'23. To those Bucknell students

Heading: who
Content: attended the Student Volunteer Con- ven in Des .Moines last year, the an-
    nouncement of the coming of Sher- wood Eddy to this University will be
    retelved wtlh great pleasure. Arrangements have been

Heading: made
Content: for Mr. Eddy to b- at Bucknell for three days, March 8th to 10th. Previous to
    th. Des Moines Convention he was engaged as one of the leaders in a r.allon-
    wlde campaign of evangeliza- tion for China and ho came from this work witli
    truly an inspiring message for the student body of America. Those wIh) were
    interested in the re- cent visit of Dr. Foster will look for- ward to his
    coming with more than usual interest. Sherwood Eddy has just returned from a
    campaign

Heading: among
Content: the students of Europe and the Near East.

Heading: He
Content: made a special study of the social and lndn.strial problem In Europe during the
    present unrest.

Heading: He
Content: has held con- ferences with students of the Uni- versity of Berlin, and studied
    present conditions <n

Heading: Germany
Content: and Austria.

Heading: He
Content: was with the Poles in their la: t stand before Warsaw, flew with their flying
    squadron, and studied condi- tions

Heading: among
Content: the Bolshevik prisoner-. He conducted the first student con- ference ever held
    in Czechoslovakia, and

Heading: made
Content: two journeys through Tur- key in the midst of the present strife between
    Nationalists, Armenians and Greeks. In Egypt the attendance at \\\a meetings
    rose from twenty-five hun- dred a night in Cairo where two tho- aters were
    filled every night, to over six thousand a night in A.ssuit. Af- ter
    entering the industrial centers of the Balkans and Italy, and the devas-
    tated areas of France and Belgium. Turn to Page

Heading: now
Content: on file in the library. It contains a list of 75.000 photo.-, indexed as to
    per^ns. places, mili- tary units and subjects.

Heading: Men
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: saw service overseas will find the vol- ume of value in selecting photos of
    their foreign experiences.

Heading: On
Content: Saturday morning last Mis.<< Elizabeth Peifer of the class of 192 4 met with an
    accident while coasting on the college hill.

Heading: The
Content: recent snow and subsequent thawing and freezing had

Heading: made
Content: ideal coasting and a large crowd of enthusiasts were taking ad- vantage of this
    opportiinlty to enjoy the sport. The smooth condition of the hill

Heading: made
Content: steering a very

Heading: much
Content: more difficult task than ordinarily, so that

Heading: when
Content: the sled on which .Miss Peifer

Heading: was
Content: coasting turned toward a tree she was not able to change its course.

Heading: The
Content: full force of the blow was fortunately turned aside, so that the side of Ihe
    lieau aiiu ilght .^houl der received the worst injury. Miss Peifer

Heading: was
Content: Immediately carried Into the

Heading: home
Content: of Dr.

Heading: Hunt
Content: and a phy.^iclan sent for. She was soon revived and after a thorough examination
    the physician gave a.ssuranco that no ser- ious injury had been sustained.

Content: 15. The single feature whlrh disin; guished the recent ten-day trip of (h'
    Bucknell Olee Club from all oth' i trips, was the

Heading: manner
Content: in which Mic

Heading: men
Content: put across the series of concerts in the absence of I'rof. Paul Stolz, the
    director of the dub,

Heading: who
Content: was unable to accompany the

Heading: men
Content: on the trip. Fired with their usual entluis- iasni, the men, under the able
    leader ship of Ilulph Hartz,

Heading: manager
Content: of the club, staged ten successful concerts in nine towns in the northern coun-
    ties of the state. Manager Hartz, in ' the absense of the regular director,
    assumed that position, and filled both it and his

Heading: own
Content: place as soloi.st and tenor in the quartette in a highly 1 satisfactory nianner_

Heading: Much
Content: credit is I due every

Heading: man
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: made the trip, I and especially to Manager Hartz for his part for the

Heading: way
Content: In which they | [entered into the work. It was the' I first time in Glee Club
    history at I Uucknell that the club has opened, on a tour without a nieniber
    of the faculty accompanying them. I The factors contributing most I greatly
    to the success of the concerts were the cooperation shown by the

Heading: men
Content: and the spirit of responsibility oxhiliited. Each one seemed to real- ize that
    it was up to him to do his utmost to

Heading: make
Content: things run smoothly in the ab.sence of Prof. Stolz. and that he must at all
    times enter into the work at hand with a will. The morale of the

Heading: men
Content: was also excellent, for, while the trip was be.set with difficultie.<<, such as
    poor traveling ac- commodations, getting up early to

Heading: make
Content: train connections and .so on, there was not a

Heading: murmur
Content: of discon- tent. Their being well-fed at all times doubtless had a great deal
    t(i 'do with keeping up the morale. I That the concerts were successful lis
    given added proof of a different ! nature when the letters of apprecia- tion
    which have been received by tln' manager arc taken into considera I tion.
    Letters of praise have been received from various towns, and 1 praise is
    both for the excellence of 'the concert work and for the excel- lence Qf
    behavior on the part of the men.

Heading: Many
Content: return concert dates for next year were booked as a result of the trip. At Port
    Allegany, the

Heading: members
Content: of the club took entire charge of th'^ Sunday evening union services, in the
    Methodist church, after which a sacred concert was given. Another feature of
    the

Heading: work
Content: of the club, which is carried out on every trip, was the securing of name-i of
    prospective students for Bucknell. The club is one of the best adverti-<-
    ing mediums at the disposal of th>^ University, as it Is ever talking up the
    University and urging h'gh school students to come here.

Heading: The
Content: club did not fail in this depa'tniont of its work on the recent trip. In fact,
    taken all in all, the recent trip was

Heading: among
Content: the most successful ui the history of the organization.

Heading: was
Content: commendable. Terrlng Helronlmus, tearing about the floor, tore

Heading: down
Content: every point for Phi Theta Pan-Hellenic Council, at the

Heading: Wo-
Content: men's College, decided last

Heading: week
Content: that beginning February 1, all sorority meetings will be held on Tuewday nights.
    Formerly meetings were spread out from

Heading: Monday
Content: to ThurHday, each sorority taking a separate night which made it rather
    inconvenient, due to the fact that whenever a lec- ture,

Heading: game
Content: or something of the sort was held, one sorority was at a dis- advantage. The
    idea of sorority meetings all on Tuesday evenings is doubtless a good one
    and will prove advantageous to the co-eds as well as the school in general.

Heading: AMER1CA;S
Content: 

Heading: NEEDS
Content: (Printed by Request of the

Heading: U.
Content: S. Treasury Department.)

Heading: The
Content: economic necesRitles of Amer- ica and the need for safeguarding the financial
    independence and safety of each individual citizen has deter- mined the
    Treasury Department to continue the issue of Government Savings Securities
    throughout 1921. according to an announcement by Secretary of the Treasury
    Houston. Those necessities, widely recog- nized

Heading: among
Content: college

Heading: men
Content: have also committed the Treasury to contin- uance and Intensification of the
    work of the Savings Division of the Trean- ury In a broad campaign to

Heading: make
Content: saving, and safe Investment, a na- tional habit.

Heading: The
Content: savings securities of the gov- ernment, familiar in every house- hold, will be
    augumented In 1921 by two

Heading: new
Content: Issues, a $1 Savings

Heading: Stamp
Content: and a |25 registered Treasury Savings Certificate. In announcing the issue of
    these securities. Secre- tary Houston says:

Heading: "Two
Content: 

Heading: new
Content: Treasury savings .se- curities will be Issued during the somlng year, a $1
    Trea.sury Savings

Heading: Stamp
Content: and a $2 5 Treasury Savings Certificate. The |1 stamp will be non-interest
    bearing, will be bright red In color, imprinted on a green tint, and will
    bear the portrait of Alexander Hamilton, the first Secre- tary of the
    Treasury. The |25 cer- tificate will be similar In design and terms to the
    |100 and $1,000 Treas- ury Savings Cetrlficates, which will also be offered
    In 1021, to mature January 1, 1926. "The

Heading: new
Content: securities will supply a $1 unit for saving and a registered Government security
    In the |25 de- nomination, which can be conven- iently purchased through the
    accu- mulation of the $1 Treasury Savings Stamps. More Important still, the

Heading: new
Content: securities will complete a most attractive line of Government sav- ings
    securities, the $1 stamp and the $25, $100 and $1,000 registered Treasury
    Savings Certificates, and thus place the Treasury Savings

Heading: movement
Content: on a solid peace-time ba.sls.

Heading: The
Content: small denomination war- time securities, the $5

Heading: War
Content: Savings Stamp, in a 1921 series, and the 25- cent Thrift Stamp, will also be of-
    fered during the coming year. "Notwithstanding the reaction since the
    arml.stlce from habits of saving, and the natural tendency during the past
    year to Invest funds In Liberty bonds and Victory notes at current market
    prices, the

Heading: demand
Content: for the savings securities has contin- ued strong in

Heading: many
Content: parts of the country. As the security markets become more settled. Treasury Sav-
    ings securities, bearing interest at 4 per cent compounded quarterly, ex-
    empt from State and local taxes and from the normal Federal income tax, and
    redeemable substantially on de- mand, .should prove Increasingly at-
    tractive to the multitude of small investors. With these considerations; In
    mind, the Treasury Is committed to the continued sale of Government sav-
    ings securities,

Heading: and
Content: feels that as time goes on continuous sales of savings securities over the
    counter, at pot- offices and banks throughout the country, should play an
    increasingly important part in the current finan- cing of the Government.
    "To this end, the Treasury Is also committed to the continuance of the

Heading: work
Content: of the Savings Division, In Washington and in the several Fed- eral Reserve
    districts. This organ- ization endeavors to promote the popular purchase of
    Government Savings Securities; develops and pro- tects the secondary market
    for Lib- erty bonds and Victory notes and other

Heading: war
Content: is.'<upR of Government .se- curities, and unites the efforts of all helpful
    agencies and movements, fi- nancial. Industrial, educational, com- mercial
    and social, in a broad .savings campaign to

Heading: make
Content: permanent habits of saving and Investment in United States Covernment
    .securities. It.s work along these lines will be Inten- sined in 19::i. 'The
    Treasury Savings

Heading: Movement
Content: has already demonstrated its useful- ness by its efforts to promote sound
    economic conditions throughout the j country and disseminate sound econ-
    omic doctrine. In fact, the work of the .Savings Divl.sion thi.<< year, not
    only in promoting the sale of Gov- ernment Savings Securities and in
    strengthlng the secondary market for Liberty bonds, but in establishing
    wide-spread habits of thrift and suv Ing, has been frequently recognized as
    meeting a great national need. That recognition has been strikingly
    emphasized by the requests of great national organizations that the sav-
    ings work be continued and by their offers of active cooperation In the
    movement. "The work of the Savings Division has been splendidly successful
    In the .schools, with the children as well as with the leaders of
    educational thought In America. As a result, th<! committee of State
    Superintendents of public Instruction, which has just met in Washington, has
    decided to urge every State Superintendent and Commissioner of Education to
    Install thrift courses in every school and at the same time provide for the
    prac- tice of the principles taught by of- fering means for sound
    investment. "In responding to these demands the Savings Division will
    intensify during 1921 its campaign to spread broadcast the essential facts
    relative to wise savings and spending and in- vestment and the continued
    develop- ment of

Heading: new
Content: capital."

    and the annual Prom, with further events hinted at by those In charge.

Heading: TALK
Content: Friday night at the monthly meet- ing of the Electrical Engineering so- ciety.
    Prof. Rhodes gave an Interest- ing talk on "The Advantages of Elec- trical
    Engineering."

Heading: He
Content: pointed out some of the

Heading: many
Content: things an engineer should train himself for, and their advantages.

Heading: He
Content: closed his talk by emphasizing the fact that college in the place for a young
    engineer to de- velop his ingenuity and not depend on some other person for
    all his work. This

Heading: was
Content: followed by an illustrated lecture on the F.

    meetings in the fu- ture. Including moving pictures and lectures.

Content: Psl team entered into their second

Heading: game
Content: of the season with unlooked-for ability and

Heading: won
Content: from the Non-Frats.

Content: contest

Content: full of surprises, the biggest be- ing the score, which was 18-22. Lonrr and
    Mussina brothers connected with the basket frequently enough to off- set the
    good work of Treadwell and Miller for the Non-Frats. Under the capable lead
    of Buck- nell's bandmaster the

Content: final whLstle found the

Heading: Forum
Content: team but a few points behind and going strong. There was, however, great
    activity in Tuatln

Heading: gym
Content: during the week of February 1. Seven games of basket- ball were played in the
    Inter-frater- nlty league and some of them proved interesting. Phi

Heading: Kappa
Content: Psi played three

Heading: games
Content: during the week without a defeat and were still able to retain the honor of a
    clean slate.

Heading: They
Content: have plenty of material, have been playing a hard and fast

Heading: game
Content: and are bidding strongliy for the handsome cup that will be donated to the win-
    ning team. The Non-Fraternity team also has a mighty fast aggregation,
    having suffered but one defeat In tho hands of Beta

Heading: Kappa
Content: Psl.

Content: de- pends on the results of the

Heading: The
Content: second concert of a series of four, given under the auspices of tho

Heading: Mu
Content: Phi Epsilon sorority,

Heading: wan
Content: given by Oliver Denton on Thursday ev- ening. February 3rd at the Baptist
    church.

Heading: The
Content: high musical standard set by the first concert, given by

Heading: May
Content: Peterson,

Heading: was
Content: in evidence again on Thursday evening. Mr. Denton at once charmed and delighted
    his audience with his clear, well-delined technique which !?avo him the
    greatest freedom in the in- terpretation of his program. Hi.s success with
    his audience

Heading: was
Content: evi- denced by the hearty applause which compelled

Heading: him
Content: to give three encores. .Many people from the surrounding towns were present and
    the diurch was well tilled. Those

Heading: who
Content: have failed to attend these two concert^ have surely missed two of thp best
    musical treats that have been given here in

Heading: many
Content: a day.

Heading: Two
Content: more con- certs still remain of this series Ra- faelo Diaz, a tenor of the
    Metropol- itan Opera company, will give a re- cital on February 15th, and
    Tlielnia Given, a violinist, on

Heading: March
Content: 3rd, will give the last of the. series. Both of these musicians are of the
    highest rank and the music-loving public Pan not afford to miss them.

Heading: The
Content: 

Heading: Mu
Content: Phi Epsilon sorority of Bucknell university deserves a f^reat deal of credit for
    undertakings tho task of securing these musicians with the financial risk
    envolved.

Content: ere to anyone hath said "I did not see the

Heading: game
Content: Friday night"

Heading: On
Content: Friday night last the campus at Bucknell echoed with the shouts and shrieks of
    the "Semites" as they witnessed the games between the girls from the
    var!ou<< women's build- ings. Faculty and students filled tho gym, all out
    to cheer ou their teams.

Heading: The
Content: 

Heading: New
Content: "Machine Gunners," as they termed themselves,

Heading: made
Content: 

Heading: New
Content: Building people proud of them as they conquered the Main "Sharp Shooters" by a
    score of 16-11. Wolf "Hounds" were defeated by Annex "Bums," the final score
    being 9-10. It was good basketball, too. since tho fair ones did not indulge
    in anv hair-pulling, and there were no knock-outs. Boys' rules with girls'
    guarding rules was played, which added a great

Heading: amount
Content: of "pep" to tho

Heading: game
Content: and at the same time prevented any so-called "rough house."

Heading: As
Content: to tlie

Heading: game
Content: itself. Main "Sharp Shooters" had a hard time guarding Forwards Fuhrer and
    Scholl. as they caged ba.sket after basket. Elva Horner did good work for
    "Main" until Emily Devine went In as guard and from then on she found It
    rath<<>r hard to locate the basket.

Heading: The
Content: work of C. Conrad at guarding. Darl Davis. Main's snappy forward, and also the
    playing of Domsalskl, Wunkerburg. Jack and

Heading: Keough
Content: 

Heading: was
Content: worthy of mention.

Heading: The
Content: 

Heading: Annex
Content: 

Heading: "Bums"
Content: with L. Llewel- yn and R. Ruhl as forwards had no difficulty In piling up points
    for their

Heading: Turn
Content: to Page Three Running even with the Getty.sburg

Heading: game
Content: of the

Heading: week
Content: in respect to being the most exciting

Heading: game
Content: seen on our floor in years, wa.s the Bucknell-Al- bright

Heading: game
Content: of January 28th. Haps Benfer's live was defeated by a score of 28 to 23.

Heading: The
Content: two biggest factors in defeating Albright were the five field goals by Dayhoff
    and the re- markable foul shooting of Bihl, he

Heading: making
Content: 14 out of 17 tries. Tht- op- posing foul shooter, on the other hand,

Heading: made
Content: 5 out of 16.

Heading: The
Content: .scoring during the first half ran even, with the visitors ringing six goals
    from field,

Heading: many
Content: of which were sensational shots, to our three. Our eight successful fouls to Al-
    bright's three

Heading: mode
Content: up for the differ- ence caused by tho field goals. All this half the score see-
    sawed back and forth with one or two points dif- ference, and the half ended
    with the Orange and Blue on the short end of a 1 to 14 score. The second
    half saw Coach Glass'

Heading: men
Content: guarding closer and consistently breaking up thoir opponents' short pas.ses. At
    the same time, Searlos got going, ringing two pretty field goals, while
    Dayhoff also contributed two and Bihl continued his foul shooting,

Heading: making
Content: all six chances good. Wlls- bach,

Heading: making
Content: his first appearance at center on the home floor, continued his < xcellent work
    of the first half, aiding greatly In getting the

Heading: jump
Content: and in retrieving the ball under the baskets.

Heading: With
Content: Bihl and Dletrlcli piitting up their usual bang-up

Heading: game
Content: at guard, Albright could cage but three basket.s this half.

Heading: As
Content: a result, the Bucknell quintette nosed their fast opponents out. Albright

Heading: was
Content: by no

Heading: means
Content: an easy team, but rather the contrary, pre- senting a team strong in both
    defense and offense, as well as possessing speed. Our team, in defeating
    them, played real basketball and deserved the hard-fnugh victory. For a time
    it appoared that the Albright fiv' would spoil our record of no defeat on
    our

Heading: home
Content: floor since 1917.

Heading: Morgan

Heading: was
Content: here he renewed

Content: acquaintances he

Heading: made
Content: during his stay at the academy.

Heading: The
Content: recital of Uufaelo Diaz, which was scheduled for next Tuesday even- ing,
    February 15th, will not be given until the follow iiig evening, Wednes- day,
    February 16th. Mr. Diaz telegraphed that he could not appear In Lewisburg on
    the 15th owing to his contract with the Met- ropolitan Opera Co. The illreae
    of Caruso makes It necessary for Mr. Diaz to appear in Philadelphia on the
    luth with the Metropolitan Opera company, but It is assured that he will bo
    in Lewisburg on the 16th. It is hoped that all of the

Heading: members
Content: of the student body will be on hand to hear this operatic star.

    which ought not to be

Content: hundred acre.s would not be too much. Dr. Harris

Content: liivisli In his praise of the School of Music and said that there

    Uni- versity than the School of Musi" The opportunities to l.ear concerts

    accustomed to the floor, the forwards being unable to locate the basket.

Heading: EASTER
Content: 

Heading: TRIP"
Content: Plans fur thv> Easter trip of the Bucknell Musical Club, which will begin 01)
    Alarch 23, are now well under w.iy and being pushed steadily. .Manager Ralph
    Hartz has been busy stcuring d.ites and lining up other towns in tlie hope
    of securing en- gagements, for the past few weeks.

Heading: He
Content: has announced the above date of departure from Lewisburg. which dale,
    Incidentally, is the same upon which the spring recess commences, and has
    alHO

Heading: named
Content: four towns with wliich contracts have been signed. Three of the.se towns are in

Heading: New
Content: Jer- sey, and are Vineland, Bridgeton and North Plainlleld. The fourth town l.^
    In this state, and Is

Heading: West
Content: Chestre. These places were visited last year, at whihc tlnic the club

Heading: made
Content: a favor- able impresi^ion upon the people, and the people upon the club, so that
    the

Heading: men
Content: Itwk forward to the time which they will spend there. Just

Heading: how
Content: long the trip will take Is not decided as yet. as no decision can be reached
    until the matter of engagements is settled. However, the

Heading: men
Content: are assured of a trip lasting at least eight or ten days, and per- naps longer.
    Whether or not dates for

Heading: New
Content: York. Philadelphia and Washington can be .secured remains to be senc. but the
    manager is striv- ing hard to get them. Inasmuch as the Easter trip is con-
    sidered

Heading: among
Content: the

Heading: men
Content: to be the most pleasant of all. in addition to being superior to the others in
    more than one way, there Is considerable inter- est being

Heading: shown
Content: in the preparation^^ for it.

Heading: Some
Content: new numbers are being worked up. which fact adds still more interest.

Heading: A
Content: week-end trip for April 28 and 29 has been settled by the manager.

Heading: On
Content: Thursday night, which is the twenty-eighth, the club will sing at Pottstown. and
    on the following ev- ening, at Reading. The good

Heading: work
Content: of the club

Heading: when
Content: it -sang at these towns last year

Heading: made
Content: the signing of the contracts for this year easy. At the meeting of the club last

Heading: Monday
Content: evening .several announce- ments of interest were made.

Heading: The
Content: first of these was that intensive re- hearsal for the remainder of the time
    before March 23 will be held. Thl.^ means that at least one rehearsal will
    be held each week, on

Heading: Monday
Content: even- ing at 7 o'clock in the Chapel.

Heading: Mem-
Content: ber.'^ of the Glee slub are requested to be prompt In their attendance.

Heading: -B--
Content: 

Heading: SHERWOOD
Content: 

Heading: EDDY
Content: 

Heading: From
Content: Page

Heading: One
Content: University of Berlin. In Czechoslo- vakia he conducted the first student
    ronterence in that

Heading: new
Content: republic, five hundred year.s after John Huss. the rector of the University of
    Prague, was burned at the stake.

Heading: He
Content: has cros.^cd the interior of Tur- key since the armistice and more re- cently
    visited the principal centers of the Near East, making a study of the
    present

Heading: war
Content: between the Nationalists. Armenians. Greeks, and the threat- ened Bolshevik
    invasion. In Poland he flew with the air force, and wit- ne.s.sed the relief
    of War.saw and the advance against the Bolshevists.

Heading: He
Content: was in Egypt during the agitation for independence and the discussion of the

Heading: new
Content: constitution. In Cairo two theatres were filled each night, and the attendance
    rose from over twenty-five hundred a night in that city to more than six
    thousaqd in Asisut. Mr. Eddy had special oppor- tunities for interviews with
    the lead- ing

Heading: men
Content: of Europe including Presi- dent Masaryk of Czechoslovakia, the King of Bulgaria,

Heading: members
Content: of cab- inets, employers and labor leaders as well as students and professors of
    the universities of Europe.

Heading: He
Content: has had unusual opportunities to study also the social and industrial problem of
    today.

    do so at their

Heading: Gamma
Content: Delta entertained the active chapter of the fraternity with an excellent dance
    at the Lewisburg club last Fri- day night.

Heading: The
Content: dancing continued from eight till two with the custom- ary intermission period
    at midnight, at which time refreshments were served. Diffy's College Five
    fur- nished the music for the dancing.

Heading: The
Content: hall was decorated with various pennants and banners.

Heading: we
Content: shall se a de- cadence In the intellectual fibre of Europe

Heading: by
Content: the falure lln attendance at

Heading: many
Content: European unverslties. I find that your committees at present at work

Heading: among
Content: students of European universities are doing wonderful work encouraging self-
    help, in holding the staffs and students together, and In maintaining the
    morale of the uni- versities.

Heading: We
Content: have also parallel problems of distribution;

Heading: we
Content: should give funds for the benefit of des- titute and under-nourished children in
    the university towns as a part of our whole problem of child relief In
    Europe. "In order that

Heading: we
Content: should get most effective organization both for the re- cruiting of support in
    the United States and in the handling of the problems of distribution,

Heading: we
Content: should like to send out to you the following plan: "That the

Heading: Y.
Content: 

Heading: M.
Content: C. A. and

Heading: Y,
Content: 

Heading: W.
Content: C. A., and such other organizations in each of our colleges as

Heading: may
Content: be best, should at once erect the neces- sary machinery for a continuous ap-
    peal to American students over the winter and to help their brothers and
    sisters in these European universi- ties and al.so to give such help as they
    can to the children In the university towns. "Our organization, conducting
    as we do a regular shipment, warehous- ing, and distribution of food and
    clothing for relief purposes, will un- dertake this portion of the work of
    primary distribution. "In the matter of the organization of distribution,

Heading: we
Content: will be glad to co- operate with your committee In way^ which will fit in with
    the plans which you already have under way, helping to select for these
    purpo-ses the American representatives to cooper- ate with the Student
    Fdratlon with ate with the Student Federation within the European
    universities. "Under this plan, with the remit- tance of

Heading: MEETING
Content: 6.

Heading: E.
Content: 

Heading: On
Content: Sunday evening, February at 6:30, the newly organized C. society of the Baptist
    church held its first meeting.

Heading: An
Content: Informal program had been arranged consisting of sing- ing, a talk by a leader
    and special music Mr. Hobart

Heading: Brown
Content: added to the pleasure of the meeting by sing- ing a solo which was thoroughly
    en- joyed by all.

Heading: An
Content: open forum wan held at the close of the meeting and the response

Heading: made
Content: in the form of testimony promLses well for the life of the society.

Heading: The
Content: attendance was exceptionally fine, for about sixty college

Heading: men
Content: and

Heading: women
Content: were present. It is the plan of the officers in charge of the society to

Heading: make
Content: the organiza- tion one of real Chrl.^tian Endeavor and to

Heading: make
Content: the meetings on Sunday evenings interesting and helpful.

Heading: An
Content: invitation is extended to all college

Heading: men
Content: and

Heading: women
Content: to attend the meet- ings and enjoy the early Sunday ev- ening hour in a
    gathering that is en- tirely their own. C*tabllah<<d 1680

Heading: The
Content: annual conclave of the fifth diHtrict of the

Heading: Kuppa
Content: Sigii'a frater- nity was held over the past week-end at the house of the Alpha
    Phi chap- ter at Bucknell.

Heading: The
Content: program in- cluded a dance in the club on Friday evening, a buKiness meeting on
    Sat- urday and a smoker In the fraternity

Heading: home
Content: on Saturday night. The fra- ternity was quite honored to liave a<< one of its
    delegates and gue.st.s, hYank J. Shea, the greatest quarter-mller in the
    United States.

Heading: He
Content: is inter- colleigate champion and was a

Heading: mem-
Content: ber of the Olympic team that com- peted last

Heading: summer
Content: in Belgium.

Heading: He
Content: was the delegate from the University of rittsburgh.

Heading: The
Content: other delegates were J. Harold Strickler and William

Heading: W.
Content: Shultz from State College; Donald R. ilart and John Q. Robin^^on from Washington
    and .leffer.son; Roland R.

Heading: Lehman
Content: from Dickinson; and Jo- .<eph R. Carder, William S. I'rice and John Kennedy from
    the University of West Virginia. At the dance on Friday night Diffy's
    College Five furnished their usual brand of syncopation to the dancing
    couples. 11 was a wonderful dance and thoroughly enjoyed by all.

Heading: Among
Content: the guests were ^Ir. and .Mrs C. A. Lindenian. Mr. and Mrs.

Heading: W.
Content: 

Heading: A.
Content: Blair. Mr. and Mrs. Neal Baker. Mr. and Mr.s. B.

Heading: W.
Content: GvilTitli. and Judge and Mrs. A.

Heading: W.
Content: Johnson.

Heading: On
Content: Saturday the busine.ss ifieeting of the Conclave began at 10 o'clock and lasted
    through until 4 o'clock, with the exception of a .short period that was
    taken off for dinner. The vi.-iiors were then taken to the movies and after
    the evening meal a smoker was given in the house.

Heading: A
Content: spirit of brqthcrly friendship

Heading: was
Content: everywhere in evidence which

Heading: made
Content: the smoker one not soon to be forgotten. If wa.s a great conclave and one that
    Alpha Phi is proud of.

    called out and practice is going on.

Content: anxious for a con- structive part in humanity's prog- ress Not only have the
    people of today taken en masse,

Heading: more
Content: free time, but they have also more

Heading: money
Content: and more temptations and a wider vision which results in more Insistent demands
    on life. They live surrounded by eoi . mercialized amusements. Theatres,
    pool-rooms, race tracks, dance halls, basball games, cabarets and sundry
    other places of diversion are run In great numbers with a keen eye to
    prolils. and a hit-or-miss attitude in the muiter of their reactions upon
    their patrons. All these things are well enough in their way. and within
    their limits, but with the exception of the dance hall and the pool-room,
    both often Questionable in their moral tone)

Heading: --
Content: they provide purely passive forms of recreation, and are therefore not ade-
    (luate for the full recreational needs of the individual. These needs in-
    volve activity as well.

Heading: A
Content: warning has been sounded that the American na- tion is in danger of becoming a
    peo- ple of "bleacherltes," not only as re- gards the great American game,
    but also figuratively. The old-time "hike" Is being sripplanted more and
    more by some artificial means of lo- comotion. Baseball. Itself, which used
    to exercise the muscles of its great numbers of enthusiasts,

Heading: Hm
Content: o.ecedented report Did Bucknell gain or did Bucknell lose by their 31-30 victory
    over Oet- ty.sburg In Lewlsburg

Heading: on
Content: Saturday night? As far as the casual newspaer reader is concerned the contest
    was merely an ordinary one-point victory of one rival quintet over another.
    But to the veteraif Gettysburg sport followers it carries with it a vast
    signiflcance. For twenty years Bucknell has been a leading rival of
    Gettysburg.

Heading: Even
Content: before the days of the historic battles on Island park in Ilarrisburg, the two
    rivals met flrst in Lewlsburg, then in Gettysburg. Always the rela. tlous
    between the two, although at

Heading: Umes
Content: bitter In their rivalry, were al- ways fair. The better team nearly always won.
    Getysbiirg admits fair- ly that the Bucknell elevens led by the agile Tip
    Tophaiii, the great end Jordan, and others of more recent years have always
    played superior ball to the boys frora the battlefield. The cry

Heading: "we
Content: got a

Heading: raw
Content: deal" is as old as sport Itself.

Heading: From
Content: a constant cryer It atracts no attention. Tills situation, however, is differ-
    ent. For the past six years no Get- tysburg basketball team has ever re-
    turned here in defeat or victory with the alibi of receiving poor treatment.

Heading: Monday
Content: morning, however, the hone-t opinion of the

Heading: men
Content: was that they had lost to Bucknell because in the last few minutes of play
    Kefcree Earnest, a young

Heading: man
Content: from Williams- port,

Heading: who
Content: was not a Central Board official such as is provided for visit- ing teams in
    Getty.sburg, persisted in calliur: fouls until nneknell tallied the neces-
    sary point to win. i Such treatment as

Heading: was
Content: afforded Gettysburg at Lewlsburg topples Bucknell from tlie high pedestal i
    where she once stood in the minds | of all Gettysburg pportsnuu and places
    her. in a class with Carlisle High School where Gettysburg schol- astic
    teams perpetually receive poor treatment. All of which leads to tho
    question, is it better to win in point of score or in point of
    sportsmanship? .

Heading: game
Content: of greatest skill was that on the Bucknell fioor last Thursday night.

Heading: Tho
Content: the Orange and Maroon lacked nine points for the victory, does in no

Heading: way
Content: say they were beaten or outplayed; but filled with burning eagerness to get even
    In the next con- test, is the essence of It all.

Content: old and bitter rival of the Orange and Maroon, challenging the utmost power and
    skiii. ambition ami hopes, started the

Heading: game
Content: at a fast ami energetic pace.

Content: close calling of fouls and scrimmage together with the good sportsmanship of the
    stu- dent body

    but were soon left behind by the rapid scoring of Rogawicz and Leidick.

Heading: was
Content: a question to the spectators

    barely able to keep in the lead until the end. The contest

Content: hard fought and every

    concerns only Sun- day .school children and old people about to die.

Content: drew a very tilting all the necess.tles and even riches of life except society.
    'Tis a poor sport, he said,

Content: will not return the treat. Dr. Hamblin closed his remarks with two very
    interesting memories of his youth.

    which the feede had to keep a t<<teady stream of sheaves pouring into the

Heading: KNELL

Heading: LY

Heading: CEUM
Content: Laat week's meeting of the Buck- nell

Heading: Lyceum
Content: was devoted to Rudyard Kipling. The program was quite varied and IntercBting.
    and tho>>e

Heading: who
Content: gathered in the chapel were well pleased with It. While the audience was not so
    large sm it Hhould have been, it waa appreciative. Prof. L. L. Rockwell gave
    a very comprehensive review of Kipling'.^ life, his works, and his present-
    day reputation Following are some of the high lights from the speech:
    Rudyard Kipling was born In

Heading: Bom-
Content: bay, India, in 1865, of very able par- ents. At the age of five he

Heading: was
Content: sent off to ICngland for his education; and at eighteen returned to the country
    of his birth with the intention of pur- suing a journalistic career. After a
    year or two, however, he entered into what

Heading: was
Content: destined to become hie life work,

Heading: when
Content: his first book

Heading: came
Content: out in 1886. Three years later he re- turned to England by

Heading: way
Content: of the United States, from which trip the inipre.'isions of America," emerged.
    In 18U0, his first novel. "The Light that Fulled." appeared, it being re-
    markable because Kipling wrote two diflerenl endings to it. After his
    marriage to an American, he resided for four years in Vermont.

Heading: Then
Content: he took his trip through the British colonial possessions, his writings con-
    crening these winning for him the title of the "Higlit Priest of the Brit-
    ish Empire. ' Kipling's later work, lujwever, has bi.cn deteriorating and is
    far from being equal to his earlier writings. The works of his youth have
    been criticisid as being unfair to women, containing few philo.soph- ical
    ideals, and being overdrawn. Lawreiu.B Kimball sang

Heading: "On
Content: . the Iload to Mandulay." accompanied by ivathryne Wagner, and responded to an
    encore with "Banjo Song." Har- ry F. Koye recited Kipling's "If." and was
    followed by Clara Casner.

Heading: who
Content: gave a parody on "If." Emily Uevine recited

Heading: "Gunga
Content: Din." All of these numers where well delivered and added

Heading: much
Content: to the enjoyment of Kipling. The last feature of the afternoon was the giving of
    "The Incarceration of .Mulvaney," by Prof. G. F. Rass- weiler. The
    professor's handling of this story almost converted some of his Frosh
    students In the audience to his standard. For those

Heading: who
Content: had never read the story, the

Heading: number
Content: was a delihtgful treat, while for those wliu liad TL-ad it, a

Heading: new
Content: insight into .some of the parts and a general bet- ter undersUiiifiing of the
    whole ."pirl' of the story resulted.

Content:

Content: 

Heading: CCESS
Content: Washingtons birthday was a hap- py day for Delta Sigma,

Heading: when
Content: about rtfteen of the

Heading: men
Content: raided the

Heading: "Sem"
Content: and took their fair prizes on a lengthy sleigh ride. The objective .was Fore.^t
    Inn. which was reached about one o'clock, after a three-hour ride.

Heading: Two
Content: sleighs were needed to carry the co'iples.

Heading: The
Content: asinine (juad- rupeds attached to one of the sleighs caused

Heading: much
Content: trouble to their pas- sengers both coming and going, fore, ing them to dismount
    and plod up the hills in the cold, deep snow. DLscomforts were forgotten at
    For- est Inn, however, for there was

Heading: warmth
Content: and food.

Heading: The
Content: lads and las- sies had their fill of chicken and waf- fles and Ice cream, and
    all the ftixln's. One "lad" held the record with twenty waffles downed, in
    addition to the rest of the stuff. The ride

Heading: home
Content: was uneventful, that is to say- It was no better and not worse than the going
    out. Under the careful laanipulation of the chap- erones. Prof, and .Mrs.
    Harrold, the "Sem" was safely reached by seven o'clock.

Heading: APPRECUTION
Content: The

Heading: management
Content: of the baskotball team wi.shes to take the opportunity here to express its
    appreciation of aH the kindnesses rendered the team nn its recent trip to
    Pittsburgh. The alumni organization not only enter talned the team

Heading: members
Content: as its guest- at the banquet, but also stood the ex pense of having the team
    stay for it. Besides his, they lunched the team Thursday noon, and aided
    greatly in its successful trip by turning out to all the games and being
    ever present to render Innumerable favors. It can be truly .said, "they have
    a Spirit."

Content: to Page 3 Today Coach Glass has isseud a call for candidates for the track
    squad. This form of athletics, once holding forth in Buckneli in a su- preme
    place, is again to be taken up with full strength.

Heading: No
Content: other sport ran boast of such a history as track has had, starting in Greece

Heading: many
Content: centuries ago with the ancient Olympics and continuing through time

Heading: down
Content: to the modern Olympics.

Heading: No
Content: other sport can boa.st of such a meeting of athletics of the various countries
    of the world to engage ni International competition such as is held .very
    four years by the Olympiad committee, including all the greatest and most
    progressive nations of the earth. I^o other sport can boast of .such
    individual compelltion. ba.sed entirely upon skill, ability and con- dition.
    It is the fairest and hardest of them all- the best

Heading: man
Content: wins. Track and Held competition flour- ished at Buckr.ell years ago and upon
    track more than any other sport wa.s based the athletic prestige of this
    Institution in the latter years of the nineeenth century. It continued, al-
    though not holding such a prominent position, until fhout 1!)12.

Heading: when
Content: it again sprung forth with great force and for about four years mighty

Content: teams were produced. Dur- ing the period of the war. track was given up. It was
    revived to some extent last year and this year it is hoped It will resume
    its former prom- inent place

Heading: PROBLEM
Content: Ret inning from a visit to twenty countries in Europe and the Near East in
    hunger and famine, in war und revolution, Sherwood

Heading: Eddy
Content: asked

Heading: "What
Content: is

Heading: wrong
Content: with the world?

Heading: What
Content: does the world need today?"

Heading: He
Content: enswered the question by saying the world needs bread, the world needs peace,
    the world needs God. Mr. Eddy spoke of the world's need of bread

Heading: among
Content: the two hundred millions suffering F:urope, the atro- cities in Armenia, and the
    famine In China.

Heading: He
Content: spoke of the starvation and hunger in Russia. Poland. Aus- help to put track j
    trla. Germany, the Near East, and the famine district of China.

Heading: He
Content: en- dorsed the appeal of Herbert Hoover on behalf of the students and starv- ing
    children of Europe, pointing out that ten dollars saves a student. Speaking
    of the need of peace, Mr. Eddy told of the strife on three fronts

Heading: --
Content: national, racial and class strife. The ultimate issue of the

Heading: War
Content: was between autocracy and dem- ocracy, militarism and freedom, might and right.
    Now, in the period of reconstruction, the world is strug- see-sa^ neither
    team was sure of victory until I

Heading: ANTI-SOCIAL
Content: materialism.

Heading: SOCIAL
Content: Personality Brotherhood Service Liberty Justice Stewardship Golden Rule Love
    Property Strife Profit Repression Injustice Selfishness Hule of Gold Hate
    Every student is going out to live, and is living now, one of these kinds of
    lives. Labor is justly demanding five things: 1

Heading: A
Content: fair, living wage. 2. Regulation hours. :^ Insurance against unemploy mont 4. 5.

Heading: A
Content: growing share industrially.

Heading: A
Content: fair share in profits. Case after case was sighted in which industry,
    recognizing the hu-

Heading: man
Content: element in labor, was prosper- inp. Capital is strongest recruiting officer for
    the I.

Heading: W.
Content: 

Heading: W.,
Content: by pushing its open-shop drives and other ef- forts to crush labor instead of
    rec- ognizing it. The test of the sanity of a nation as well as of an indi-
    vidual, is whether in case of danger they remove the cause.

Heading: We
Content: have the choice of seeing labor rise by evolu- tion, by a period of Russian
    anarchy. !or l)y the observence of the teaching gling blindly on toward the
    realiza tlon of those three ideals for which i^^ ^'^^'^^^ Christ

Heading: men
Content: fought-- Democracy. Liberty and Righteousness.

Heading: We
Content: are in the midst of one of the great crises of all hla- tory, in a decade of
    transition, in one of the great migrations of the

Heading: human
Content: spirit. Great as was the change pro- duced by the French Revolution in France,
    so great will be the change for Europe and the world after tho present war.
    Just as the period of Robespierre, the Guillotine and the

Heading: Ked
Content: Terror discredited France and threw England into reaction, so the present
    v*^viod of tyranny and the Red Terror in Europe is producing reaction But

Heading: when
Content: the smoke of I pulsion of jealousy batth' cleared

Heading: away
Content: and the ideal pr.miotion of real brotherhood

    France land a freer Europe, emerged,

Heading: men
Content: 'realized the lasting gains of the French Revolution. So will it be 1 after the
    great

Heading: War
Content: in Europe, not only In the political sphere, but in the social and Industrial
    realm.

Content: sees the Irresistible onward march of dtnu'ciacy in the world today. Fol lowing
    the Bourbons of France, the Romanoffs, the Hapsburgs, the Ho- henzollerns--
    all the great autocra- cies of Europe.

Content: was first considered as a factor in world de velopment. Plato taught forty years
    and Christ three, yet His teachings arc

Heading: now
Content: foremost In the world. Shakespeare has been translated into thirty languages,
    Tolstoi into forty. Jesus Chri.st, not an author, has been translated into
    .seven hundred lan- guages. Jestis was no architect, yet the finest
    architecture of the world has been reared in His honor.

Content: was no poet, no musician, yet the greatest poetry, the greatest music has been
    written in His praise. Al- though he had no wife

Content: at, things which he must do to demonstrate his fitness for the poHltlon.

Heading: He
Content: will be given ji chance to try his hand at the me- chanical features of
    newspaper work, including the different processes which are necessary to get
    out a fln- IshtHl paper. In addition to this, he will have a chance to get
    advertise- ments for next year, or secure con- tracts for advertising space.
    Another Important feature he will have to learn Is the handling of the
    subscription list, which includes wrapping and mailing copies of the
    iiucknellian to alumni subscribers and other college papers on the ex-
    change list.

Heading: He
Content: win learn a great deal about second-class mail matter from the post office
    department; in short, he will get a good knowledge of

Heading: managing
Content: a paper. Candidates must not get the impression that the work iB easy, as such
    is not the case.

Content: regular period of time each week

Heading: win
Content: have to be devoted to

Content: Of course. It la complimentary to call the policeman a "copper" becau.se he
    shines as a

Heading: man
Content: of metal. The' dictionary says that this term is slang but In the pralance of
    the great American public "cop" or "copper" iH a friendly everyday

Heading: name
Content: for the policeman.

Heading: We
Content: do not deny thai some of the highbrows designate hlni as "officer." while some
    of the law breakers call

Heading: him
Content: a "bull." But, th" big. robust, healthy fellow

Heading: who
Content: es- corts the school kiddles across tho thoroughfare and sends them on their

Heading: way
Content: with a smile Is "de cop." Like all people

Heading: who
Content: serve the public the policeman comes In for his sharo; of "kidding" and jokes.
    Most of the

Heading: humor
Content: concerning friend "copper" that is penned by the press humor- ists is as good-
    natured as the genial enforcers of the law.

Content: the screen In hundreds of theatres "Topics of the Day" P'llms often present
    "cop- per" comics with laughing success.

    "arrested" by the Bucknelllan.

Heading: MIFFLINBURG.
Content: 

Heading: PA.
Content: Bucknell's campaign for one and ..ne-half millions of dollars in five years,
    which was Inaugurated last April In a pageant upon the streets of Lewisburg.
    is moving on apace as la evidenced In the following real facts and figures.

Heading: The
Content: enlargement of the Chemical Laboratory is visible to ev- eryone, and the steady
    construction , being carried on by Professor Burpee establishes beyond a
    doubht that Bucknell's forward

Heading: movement
Content: has really begun.

Heading: Much
Content: 

Heading: money
Content: has been collected al- ready, more Is promised and yet again several prospects
    are In view for obtaining more of the million and a half.

Heading: The
Content: Board of Directors Is not asleep and the

Heading: new
Content: Bucknell Univer- sity catalogue will

Heading: show
Content: a layout, proposed, for the entire acreage re- cently purchased by the
    University. This will prejsent tentative plans for the athletic field,

Heading: new
Content: buildings, etc. Dr. Judd, trea.surer of the Institu- tion, has received thus far
    from alumni friends of the school, $28,288.

Heading: From

Heading: PENNSYLVANU
Content: ^01 Chaplain James J. Kane, Rear-Ad- miral. retired: of the

Heading: U.
Content: S. Navy, a graduate of the Theological depart- ment of the cla.ss of 1S67. died
    Thiirr,- day.

Heading: March
Content: 10. at the Philadelphia

Heading: Navy
Content: Yard Hospital, and was buried at Arlington cemetery, Va., Saturday. Chaplain

Heading: Kane
Content: was 84 years of age. Born In Ottawa. Canada, he entered the United tales- navy
    as a volunteer seaman In 1861. rose to the

Heading: command
Content: of a gunboat and

Heading: saw
Content: service in sev- eral battles- notably In Mobile bay. under Farragut. In 1865 he
    entered (he Theological course here and was graduated with the cla-ss of
    1867. Later ho pursued the law course In Harvard, graduating in 1870.

Heading: He
Content: was chaplain In the navy until his re- tirement in 1896. with the rank of rear-
    admiral, retired.

Heading: He
Content: resided In Brooklyn for

Heading: many
Content: years, but more recently at Asbury Park.

Heading: N.
Content: J.

Heading: He
Content: was a cosmopolitan by travel and sympathy, interested in humanity and In
    progress, devoted to his friends, and to the cau.se of Christ throughout the
    world.

Heading: He
Content: was a loyal alumnus of Bucknell. having a daughter a graduate of the Insti-
    tute, and a grandson a graduate of the College.

Heading: To
Content: promote excellence in public speaking, he established the

Heading: "Kane
Content: Prize for the best oration on

Heading: Com-
Content: 

Heading: menecment
Content: Day"

Heading: --
Content: a gold watch. Chaplain

Heading: Kane
Content: 

Heading: was
Content: a gifted con- versationalist, a prized guest In

Heading: mnny
Content: a circle of distinguished people. His

Heading: memory
Content: 

Heading: was
Content: stored with Incidents of travel and personal experience, which enlivened
    conversation and Turn to Page Three Upholding the negative side of the
    question. "Resolved, that labor should share in the

Heading: management
Content: of corporate industry," a debating team representing Bucknell lost the two to
    one decision to three orators from Swarthmore last Friday evening In
    Bucknell Hall. That Bucknell lo.st once more Is a matter of history to go

Heading: down
Content: along side of the other two defeats of this year, but as a

Heading: medium
Content: of getting at the basis of very real problems, the debate

Heading: was
Content: 

Heading: shown
Content: to be very effi- cient. Sherwood Eddy brought before the student body some real
    Issues concerning social labor problems, and the subject under consideration
    Frl- j day night, being right In line with the thought of the students, was
    the subject of ninre than a little Interest

Heading: Some
Content: valual)le facts on eitlier side of the proposition were brought for- ward. The
    affirmative side of the (jues- tlon was ably introduced by the cap- tain of
    the Swarthmore team, Allan C. Valentine.

Heading: He
Content: declared that rep- resentation in industry

Heading: was
Content: to be compared with r^ presentation in gov- ernment, and that taxation witliou*
    representation was tyranny. The af- firmative attack as a whole

Heading: was
Content: upon the principle of the fact that the workers were entitled to a voice in
    management. They pointed out that the existing conditions were far from
    satisfactory

Heading: and
Content: produced sharing plans, such as is in u.-^e by the Phila- delphia Rapid Transit
    Company, fo support their contention that to give labor a voice in the

Heading: management
Content: was to solve the problem.

Heading: On
Content: the other hand, the ncj^ativc argued from a legal basis and sliowed according to
    the law of the cas.-, r- p resentation in

Heading: management
Content: v/as r.ot legal. They upheld the case of the public, the great body of people

Heading: who
Content: arc neither capital or labor, and d--

Heading: manded
Content: justice for them. They ar- gued that sharing in

Heading: management
Content: was not feasible, that it

Heading: was
Content: undem- ocratic and that it

Heading: was
Content: against Amer- ican initiative . It was perhaps the last speaker of the
    affirmative

Heading: who
Content: 

Heading: won
Content: for Swarth- more. He, in a forceful presentation, set over against the legal
    argument of the negative the

Heading: human
Content: side of the case, and

Heading: wound
Content: up the plea for his side In an appeal to the rights of la- bor against
    capitalism. The program was as follows: Prof.

    Selinsgrove, Pa.; Mr, Walter Wilson, Milton, Pa. Jones-Hausauer Co..
    Buffalo, the printers of the book this year, and with them the board begins
    to see some material gain and results from their long endeavors throughout
    the year. If the rest of the book can be judged from these first proof

    appeared at Bucknell In recent years.

    peclai ordering days are over, they will have themselves to thanl< for their

Heading: CATALOG
Content: The Alumni Quin(iuennial catalog for 1920 Is

Heading: now
Content: on press and is ex- pected to be ready for distribution about the end of April.
    This catalog will contain a wealth of Information. All trustees, presidents,
    faculty, graduates and matriculates are listed on Its pages. Graduates and
    matrlc- iilates of college, Institute and music department are arranged
    according to classes, alphabetically and geo- graphically. There are pool
    games, and then again there are pool games, and thos * two or more contests
    which are being staged weekly on Stahl's 'lontr green," are developing more
    and more interest.

Heading: A
Content: cup for the win- ning fraternity and a prize from Stahl himself to the winning
    player* are the stakes for which these ten- o'clock contests have taken on a

Heading: new
Content: note of importance. During the past

Heading: week
Content: the Kappa Sigmas surprised the league by de- feating the leaders of the tourna-
    ment, the

Heading: Lambda
Content: Chls. In a close contest, full of fine runs. The score was 100 to 98. Then the
    Phi Psls

Heading: won
Content: from the S. A. E.'s by twenty points and fixed the present stand- ing of the
    teams as follows:

Heading: Won
Content: Lost Percent the ball room of which had been al- tered so as to serve quite
    efficiently as a theater. The play began at << o'clock and lasted slightly
    over two hours. It wa.^ Charles Kenyon's "Kindling," of which the following
    description a.-* given on the program, says: " Kind ling' " Is admirable as
    a work of art; but it is even more important as a social document. It Is a
    sincere and sympathetic study of the emotions of the desperate poor.

Heading: The
Content: play reminds us with a pang that each of us is at j least a tacit partner In a
    social or- ganization that is guilty of Infanti- cide upon an enormous
    scale. After

Heading: we
Content: have lived the life of Maggie .*^chult:'. for an evening in the theater or
    library,

Heading: we
Content: can scarcely recede to our

Heading: own
Content: more snug and comfort- able lives without asking ourselves a few serious
    questions." The cast is to be congratulated upon the excellent work which
    they did throughout the entire action of the production and upon the sympa-
    thetic interpn tations they gave to the play. Every

Heading: member
Content: 

Heading: was
Content: at hii or her "best, and the results of their fine

Heading: work
Content: 

Heading: was
Content: apparent in the atti- tude of their audience.

    Piof. G. E. Rassweiler. Following is the cast of characters: Heinrich

Heading: A
Content: cloB(c) correspondence between good scholarship In collcKe and em- inence in
    engineering is shown in an investigation

Heading: made
Content: under the aus- pices of the American Association of Collefflate RegiBtrars by
    Prof. Ray-

Heading: mond
Content: Walters of Lehigh University,

Heading: who
Content: presents a report in the current i.ssue of "School and Society." It was found
    that, of 392 distin- guished engineers graduated at 7r> technical schools,
    colleges and uni. versitles, 182 or 46.4 per cent stood in the. highest
    fifth of their class scholastically upon graduation: 109. or 27.8 per cent
    stood in the second highest fifth: 72 or 18.3 per cent In the middle fifth:
    14 or 3.6 per cent in the next lowest fifth, and 15 or 3.8 per c(?nt in the
    lowe.st fifth. Figures for a group of 189 alumni of five Eoi^tern
    engineering Kchool.s were

Heading: somewhat
Content: different in the upper classes, the second highest scholastic fifth having the
    larRCst percentage. In all groupings of the eminent en- gineers, there were
    less than 4 per cent in each of the two lowest schol- astic fifths. Of 730
    names on the Registrar's Association list of distinguished en- gineers,
    practically 80 per cent were found to be collegiate graduates, 16 ! per cent

Heading: men
Content: of secondary school ed- ucation and practical training, and less than 5 per cent

Heading: men
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: t;taiteil in college but did not finish.

Heading: The
Content: arbitrary basis of eminence in thi.s study of a professional group was taken to
    be the holding of office, membership in important committee.^ and service as
    representatives of the four "founder" engineering societies, civil,
    mechanical, electrical, and min- ing and metallurgy, for five years.
    1915-1919. Carl Gelger, '15. and Clinion Sprout, '17,

Heading: members

    over the week-end.

    undisputed; the kind of education for business Is a debat- able question.

Heading: My
Content: 

Heading: own
Content: experience and observation lead

Heading: me
Content: to believe that the present tendencies are to- ward too great specialization or
    be- ginning specialization upon Insuffi- cient foundations. There Is too

Heading: much
Content: anxiety upon the part of our youth ! to pick special courses of supposed
    Immediate application to the busi- ness of earning money.

Heading: We
Content: do not

Heading: commence
Content: building our houses with the purcha.se of a lightning rod and the plumbing and
    hardware trim. The foundation Is not only of first but of fundamental
    importance; if it Isn't right, the plaster will crack, the doors will stick,
    and the roof will leak. For a good job, build upon a rock. Whatever rank or
    reputation I have attained Is not based upon any great business acumen,
    selling ability or managerial talent, but upon soun<l technical training
    ba.sed upon the lib- eral education received at Washing- ton and Jefferson.
    I believe implicit- provoked and satisfied the Interest ly in the liberal
    college education as of old and young.

Heading: --
Content: greater than all other books In the world." The principles of life and conduct
    In It are a part of the education de- sired in big business. Education for
    busln'is.s should develop the power of reasorlng, of Intense concentration
    and of stralghtllne thinking.

Heading: The
Content: mind of the student should be filled with a knowledge of usuable princi- ples of
    conduct, science, economics and civics, and not with a heterogen- eous
    collection of facts. There Is .something wrong with the education received
    at a Christian college which turns out unchristian and antl-chrls- tlan
    faddists, dreamers and socialists, socialism Is the science of selfish-
    ness; the falalcy of failure. Educa- tion should Instill in the mind a pas-
    sion for service, for constructive ef- fort. Desire to serve Is a more noble
    trait than a desire to get. Financial returns should be viewed as the re-
    turn that .society makes for well-di- rected creative effort, and not some-
    thing that the recipient takes from the less fortunate. Earning

Heading: money
Content: is not a crime; making

Heading: money
Content: some- times Is.

Heading: Some
Content: people

Heading: make
Content: money, but never acquire a fortune. Other qualities than those which reault in
    earning must be cultivated. The dis- tinction between hoarding and sav- ing
    and the prolitable use of savings or capital, Is Important for the young

Heading: man
Content: to know. Opportunity has to be look<<4 for and even created. Prob- ably no one
    here inherited the major part of his capital or his job. The laborer nf
    today is the capitalist of tomorrow. As Prof. J. Lawrenae Laughlln says:
    *'The creation and legitimate possession of capital re- quire certain
    personal qualities willingness and Imagination to weigh the future gain over
    against a pres- ent indulgence, self-control, patience persistence, foref-
    ight and prudence. Those

Heading: who
Content: possess these homely vir- tues become possessors of capital and hence employers
    of others; those

Heading: who
Content: have them not and

Heading: own
Content: no capital must seek those

Heading: who
Content: have capital and hence are employed by others. The separation into two great
    classes of the employers and the employed ^ due to differences In

Heading: human
Content: qual- itie.s; differences, however, of a kind which can be remoTCd t)T training,
    environment, and the development, of character and civilization." Thi.*
    ^-reat distinetion between those

Heading: who
Content: acquire and those

Heading: who
Content: do not should be realized by every educated man.

Heading: PENNSYLVANU
Content: Eta Chapter of Alpha Chi

Heading: OmcRa
Content: was first established at Bucknell University on June 16th, 1898, with Belle
    Bartol,

Heading: Amy
Content: Gilbert (AlllBon.) Jessie Steiner (Hursh).

Heading: Mary
Content: 

Heading: Wood
Content: (Kerstetter), and Ida List as charter members. Three of these

Heading: women
Content: gra- duated two days after initiation, and y*he others did not return to finish
    their coursep, At this same time, a raculty ruling reguiring Sophmorc
    pledging wa.s pa.=sed. As the result <;f these difficulties, Eta became In-
    active June 1899, and the charter was withdrawn in 1904. In 1920 the
    National Council of Alpha Chi

Heading: Omega
Content: wrote to the college authorities asking if a suitable group (ould be found to
    undertake the re- establishment of Eta Chapter. The ten girls

Heading: who
Content: were chot^en were con- sidered favorably by the National Inspector

Heading: who
Content: visited the college in May.

Heading: No
Content: further steps were taken until October 1920,

Heading: when
Content: permission to petition for a charter

Heading: came
Content: from the extension board. -Mrs. Irving Brown, the Atlantic province presi- dent,
    came In

Heading: November
Content: to organize the group as Zeta Nu.

Heading: The
Content: formal petition was sent in January, and a charter was granted February 11,
    1921.

Heading: The
Content: week-end of April 1 and April 2, was devoted to the re-estab- Ushment of Eta
    Chapter of Alpha Chi Omega.

Heading: The
Content: jn.slalling officers were: Mrs. S.

Heading: D.
Content: Graff, Grand President, Mrs. Irving Brown, Atlantic Province President, Mrs.
    Ethel Moore Miller, Miss JosepWne Lee Meek, Miss Ruth Titue. Miss

Heading: Edna
Content: Fulton and Miis

Heading: Ruth
Content: Lassen. Mrs. Allifon and Mrs. Kerstetter, original charter membere. of Eta
    Chapter also were guests of the fraternity.

Heading: A
Content: formal reception to representatives o fthe faculty and of fraternities and
    sororities was held from 3 to 5 o'clock Saturday after- noon, April 2, in
    the

Heading: Women's
Content: College parlors. In the evening a banquet was served at

Heading: Hopp
Content: Inn, .Mifflinburg. Alpha Chi

Heading: Omega
Content: was founded Oct. 15, 1885 at

Heading: Depauw
Content: University, Greencastle. Ind. a.': a musical frater- nity. In 1908, at a
    national conven- tion, the constitution was amended, making Alpha Chi

Heading: Omepa
Content: a general fraternity, emphasizing scholarship, and the development and practise
    of the allied arts. Alpha Chi

Heading: Omega
Content: was admitted to Panhellenic Congress in (Turn to page three)

Content: Delta enjoyed the beit house party since Us establishment Jit Bucknell. during
    the recent Easter vacation. The party sftarted at noon on Wednesday, March
    23, and closed Saurday afternoon, giving those pres- ent a chance to get to
    their homes in time to enjoy Easter day.

Heading: Much
Content: of the success of the house party wao due to Waring's Banjo orchestra and the
    music they furnished, which, a' usual, was of the very highest grade. Dances
    were held Wednesday anJ Tbur.<<day evenings at the chapte- house from eight
    to one, and Friday Tiight at the Lewisburg

Heading: dub
Content: from nine to five, with a breakfast served afterward at the house. At inte--
    mlsslon on Friday night, a four- course supper was served, during v/hich
    time the orchestra gave sev- eral of its specialties. .Many of the Phi

    Beech-

    containing a large picture of the Phi

Heading: men

    first

Heading: WEDNESDAY
Content: Coach Cockill is devoting all ef- forts to eliminate the weaknesses of the
    Bucknell baseball team, which were brought out in the

Heading: game
Content: with Gettysburg this week. Several shift.- in the lineup and the improvement
    which is bound to result from the constant batting practice, which is on the
    daily program, are expected to greatly Increase the effectiveness of the
    team. The

Heading: game
Content: this week will be played on the

Heading: Campus
Content: on

Heading: Wednesday
Content: after- noon at 3:3 Oo'clock.

Heading: The
Content: visitors, Delaware University, raised their stocks considerably in college base-
    balldom this week by decisivel * defeating the strong Dartmouth team. They
    have a strong team, and the

Heading: game
Content: on Wednesday should be well worth w itne.->>slnR.

Content: usual admission will be charged.

Heading: when

Content: evening was a ntting climax for such a worthy effort. Miss Kathryn Bennett is a
    librar- ian in the

Heading: Brown
Content: Library, of Wi'l- lami^port. She is a popular story teller of the Natloiuil
    Story Teller- Leasut*. Her services are in

    made- .ipecial researc ii into the folk- lore and traditions of
    Pennsylvania. Personally MLss Bennett was not at her host last week because

    Bennett commetfted with th>> Indiau legends of

    tale of a Swedish girl, tlie sweetheart of a naturalist

Content: was forced by her oomni'inity to marry a missionary to America, because the
    missionary needed a wife and she was the most li'uely i^irl in the
    community. They came tJ Pennsylvania, the missionary diea and their daughter
    died. The naturalist, hearins tbat the mission- ary and his wife had died,
    came V) America to honor their grave, found his sweetheart and married her
    They traveled up and

Heading: down
Content: the coast studying the plants and America and finally returned to Sweden. The
    final act of the great epic, Evang".'- ine was enacted in Pennsylvania. This
    story

Content: beautifiilly narrated by

    Penn. John | 1 P..>r.n fell in love with the daughter ! of a chieft lia

    ha.i accepted the position of executive secretary of the Intercol- legiate
    Newspaper Association, ac- cording to

Heading: an
Content: announcement in The State, the weekly publication at that Institution. The
    Bucknellian is i.

Heading: member
Content: of this association. 1

Heading: The
Content: Intercollegiate Newspaper as- sociation is an organization composed of
    repieaentatives from 18 college 1 paper.s located in this section of the
    c.^uutry.

Heading: Two
Content: meetings are held each year and the editors-ln-chlef and busiae.ss managers
    attend and discuss policies of editorial and business topics. In addition a
    prize Is award- ed to the board that issued the best paper during the
    previous year. The judges of this competition have for- merly been

Heading: members
Content: of the staff of the Philadelphia Ledger. Prof Weston's duties as executive
    secretary will be chiefly that of an advl^^^r to the various editorial
    board.s.

Heading: He
Content: will take charge of all records of the association during the vacations or at
    any other time

Heading: when
Content: , the

Heading: new
Content: boards are being elected, i His principal duty will be the Issu- 1 'anc^ from
    time to time of bulletins I containing the best articles published , I in
    th^ various papers as well as rriti- , I ci.ms and suggestions for improve-
    i ment.

Heading: Pennsylvania
Content: AVhut the war did to the universi- ties and colleges In this country and in
    England, the present great famine i8 doing to those In China. The stu- dents
    are forsakHng their classroonv in response to a call for need. Several of
    the Chinese colleges al- ready have cloeed, and the students have gone to
    the stricken dlstricls in the quickly mobilized

Heading: arm
Content: of re- lief workers through whose efforts

Heading: many
Content: 

Heading: among
Content: the millions left desti- tute by flood and drought are being kept alive with
    food rushed in from the outside world. In other Institutions, where some
    students still remain, they are divid- ing their food with the starving folk
    of the five stricken provinces on the "stint yourself to save" plan.

Heading: And
Content: this is one of the ctriking signs of the awakening in the new- republic for
    which our

Heading: own
Content: American colleges are largely responsible. Whatever progressive Western spirit
    China has today, she

Heading: owes
Content: to the young

Heading: men
Content: 

Heading: and
Content: 

Heading: women
Content: educated here and in Europe,

Heading: many
Content: of whose ex- pense* at American universities and colleges were paid for out of
    Boxer indemnity money. Her hope for the fuUire rests with

Heading: them and
Content: with the students in the Chinese colleges mod- eled after our own. Before the
    call for

Heading: men
Content: 

Heading: and
Content: 

Heading: women
Content: willing to endure hardship and hard

Heading: work
Content: in famine relef became po ur- gent, the 800 students of the Univer- sity of

Heading: Nanking
Content: petitioned the au- thorities of that institution to re- duce the

Heading: amount
Content: of food served at the student table In order that

Heading: what
Content: should be saved might be sent to the famine vlcitms.

Heading: They
Content: saved 1800 during the first half of the school year, besides con- tributing more
    than $3,000 in cash. $800 is a lot of

Heading: money
Content: in China. Board at the U. of

Heading: N.
Content: costs abou>> $3.50 a month. No, not a day, or -v^.eek-- a month! Figure up and
    you'll see that the Chinese student? really stinted themselves. They saved a
    good

Heading: many
Content: lives. At current prices in China .their $800 would buy 20 tons of sweet
    potatoes, 13 tons of mllet, 5000 pounds of meat, or 8000 pounds of fish.
    Everywhere Chinese students are throwing themselves into the or- ganized
    effort to save their starving countrymen. In

Heading: Soochow
Content: University

Heading: Number
Content: three, a

Heading: much
Content: shaller insti- tution than the

Heading: U.
Content: of N., they saved $120 In a

Heading: month
Content: by denying them- selves meat and fish.

Heading: Many
Content: of these

Heading: same
Content: students are

Heading: now
Content: in the famine provinces busy with the tremendous

Heading: work
Content: of distribution.

Content: Chester. Pa., to Pres. Hunt. "It gives

Heading: me

    the Bucknell Musical club.

Heading: The
Content: program given by the hoys

Heading: was
Content: high class and gave universal i-atlbfaction.
