    ythe club. The concert

Heading: made
Content: 

Heading: much
Content: sentiment for Bucknell. In the afternoon of the day the concert was given, the
    boya gave a short program before the high school, which was excellent Indeed
    and

Heading: won
Content: the student body. There will, I feel quite certain, be more students for
    Bucknell from

Heading: West
Content: Chester hereafter. The boys

Heading: won
Content: the confidence and esteem of everybody. Their conduct wa.s of the highest order
    and re- flected favorably the characterof Bucknell. 1 would earnestly advise
    that the college, faculty and student body, give the musical clubs next
    year, the best possible support and encouragement. The

Heading: work
Content: of th.' clubs is a very effective

Heading: way
Content: to advertise Bucknell."

    than those in Chinese colleges or of Chinese birth. In Syria,

Heading: two
Content: thousand miles from the stricken and, a group of Christian students gave
    substantially to the famine fund from their scant means. In this country,
    contributions ar"

Heading: now

    for China

Heading: Famine
Content: Fund, whose treasurer Is Vernon Munroe, Bible House,

Heading: New
Content: York City; and In several institutions the adoption of the "stint yourself to
    save" idea, borrowed from the U. of N., is help- ing to swell the fund.

Heading: No
Content: contribution Is too small to be welcomed by the relief organixation. and none Is
    too large. For three cents, a famine victim, man,

Heading: woman
Content: or child, can be supplied with food suf- ficient for a day; $1 will keep one
    alive thirty days; and $5 a

Heading: month
Content: will support a family.

Heading: But
Content: the need Is great ; there are so

Heading: many

Heading: The
Content: 1922 L'Agenda has been coni- lileted: The final copy sheets liiive been
    forwarded to Baker-Jones-Hau- naiur, Inc , of Buffalo, the printers of the
    book this year, and tims has been completed what has all the appear- ances
    of being the best year book that has been published at Bucknell for some
    years. Finley Keech, the ed- * ,\6r. aided by his staff, has been working
    hard for peveral months In an tndeavor to

Heading: make
Content: the book the very last word in college annuals for the year, and a book of which
    the college

Heading: may
Content: well be proud.

Heading: Word
Content: comes back from the printers that

Heading: work
Content: on the book Is progressing nice- ly, and that the proof sheets will be forwarded
    in the very near future.

Heading: An
Content: effort has been

Heading: made
Content: to get the book published before the contem- plated printers' strike, which is
    ex- pected the first of May.

Heading: The
Content: book is arranged Irt tw<<lvo Hections. or departments, consistinK of the

Heading: new
Content: view section, the faculty, the classes, the music department, the fraternities,
    the Rlrls' fraternities, publications, college activities, liter- ary
    department .athletics, feature ;*-- lions and the advertising section. Of
    most of these,

Heading: much
Content: has been said in previous material on the obok, bu* there is

Heading: much
Content: that has not been said about the book that cannot l)e ex- pressed until the
    publicatibn is dis- tributed to those

Heading: who
Content: have sul) wcrlbfed. Every department is com- plete in itself, and covers the
    life of the college from the issuing of last gear's book until the 15th of
    March, this year. In the department of publication-? Tvill be included the
    L'Agenda,

Heading: The
Content: Bucknellian, The Alumni Monthly, the

Heading: Commencement
Content: News, and last, but not least, the staff (?) of "The Woodpecker,' the
    announcement of which will be awaited with

Heading: much
Content: anxiety on the part of many. The view section contains only !liree pictures that
    have appeared in Jormer L' Agendas. Thus, covering t:ight pages,

Heading: many
Content: 

Heading: new
Content: views of the campus and buildings will be pre- sented,

Heading: making
Content: a splendid change in the book from previous years. Special mention should be
    made of the snow Kcene across the athletic field and the sunset view of the
    *Hill' 'from across the Susquehanna river. This view Kfcction is headed by a
    beautiful plate entitled *Campus." which has been prepared by the printers,
    and which Hhows the Sixth Street entrance to the campus to good advantage.
    The departments of college organ- izations and activltie^ of former year.s
    have been combined in one depart- Bient this year, thus giving the whole
    range of college and student activ- ities in one section. The literary
    department, covering nineteen pages, is headed by a liter- ary masterpiece
    entitled. "Nature's Setting for Bucknell," written by Dr. Martin in
    commemoration of the 75th anniversary of the founding of the jniverslty.
    Four pages are devoted to this article.

Heading: The
Content: remaining pages contain the efforts of several of our budding authors, two of
    the.se en- deavors being illustrated to add to the novelty of the
    department. Sev- tral are of a more serious turn, and have real literary
    ability displayed in them. The athletic department Is com- plete, covering
    football, baseball, track, girls- athletics, the letter m'>n cf the class,
    and a splendid article on *The Beginning of Athletics at Buck- nell," by
    Prof. Bromley Smith, writ- ten after a great deal of research work along
    this line, going back a.? far as lJ>71t. Accounts

Heading: and
Content: photos In connection with the Sophomore- Freshman football and basketball Fames
    are also included in this^ sec- lion. Of most vital interest will be the
    feature sections, headed by a neat drawing of one of our anuable fresh- men,
    and entitled, "Dlabollqnes."

Heading: And
Content: the section is all the

Heading: name
Content: ini- pliep.

Heading: With
Content: appropriate dedication cf the department Fhere it rightfully (Turn to pftge two)
    The

Heading: management
Content: of the L'Agend.i is still solidting orders for that an- nual.

Heading: One
Content: hundred more orders must Uv taken in order to cover all ex- penses and come out
    on top. Lets get behind it and see that more order.n are turned in. Only 325
    copies, out of 938 students, have been ordered. Kveryone should have a copy
    by wliidi, in after >cars, to r^niembor their college days and college
    activi- ties. There are still 60

Heading: The
Content: regular meeting of the Social and Industrial group was held in the reception
    room of the

Heading: Woman's
Content: Col- lege last Thursday evening. Th" meeting was addressed by .Mr. b. B.

Heading: Cannon
Content: outlined some of the labor Car and Foundry Co., of Milton. Mr.

Heading: Cannon
Content: outyined sonje o fthe labor problems that had arisen in his plant and mentioned
    the steps that his firm had taken to meet them. Starting from his boyhood he
    traced the gradual develndiuenl of the labor unions up their present day
    organi- zation, and along with their develop- ment the grawth of the
    antogonistic spirit entertained toward them by capitol.

Heading: He
Content: handled the situation in an absolutely iinbia.<<ed

Heading: manner
Content: as l^

Heading: shown
Content: by hi.s explanation of what he thinks is the cause of the gradually increasing
    gulf between capital and labor ,and in what he thinks is a solution to the
    problem.

Heading: He
Content: gave the following causes for the present crisis: (1) Alternate abuse of power.
    (2)' Suspicion and distrust (3) Failure to realize that their interests are
    mutual. In support of the firi-l cause he cit- ed the

Heading: manner
Content: in which labor,

Heading: when
Content: the

Heading: demand
Content: for manufactured articles is great and

Heading: man
Content: power is .'scarce, sets exhorbitant prices upon its services.

Heading: Then
Content: upon the other hand the pro- cedure of capital

Heading: when
Content: the opposite condition obtains and workers are plentiful. The second cause needs
    no expla- (Turn to page two)

Content: Chi Alpha fraternity en- tertained at a formal dance Friday evening at tlie
    chapttr dance. The decorations were superb, each room representing different
    institutions, in color. One room was decorated in our

Heading: own
Content: national colors to represent our country; another in orange and blue for
    Bucknell and then purple, green and gold, which are the fra- ternity colors.
    The whole house shone with a mass of color and lights which were especially
    arranged. The music

Heading: was
Content: furnished

Heading: by
Content: Ditfy's Col- lege Five,

Heading: who
Content: rendered unsurpass- able

Heading: music--
Content: just the kind the boys like. During the intermission, lunch was served, the
    porch being especially arrangfd for thdt purpose. At three o'clock the
    joymakers departed. Judge and Mrs A.

Heading: W.
Content: Johnscn acted as chaperones.

Heading: THURSDAY
Content: 

Heading: EVENING
Content: The piano recital of Mr. Moyer, given last Thursday evening in the Baptist
    church proved to be one of the outstanding features of the sea- son. The
    church was filled to capa- city with a

Heading: warmly
Content: appreciative and enthusiastic audience. In the opening

Heading: number
Content: of Etude Symphonlqucs of Schuman. Mr. Moy- er's rhythmic sen.se was superb. His
    tone, singing at times, brittle at others,

Heading: made
Content: the

Heading: Schuman
Content: pieces in- deed memorable. The Chopin numbers, including a Ballade, Nocturne and
    Polonaise, were an exposition of fine feeling and adequate technique The
    group of modern compositions were given with real charm and true
    understanding.

Heading: The
Content: Scherzo, written by a young American composer

Heading: now
Content: dead, was weird and fantastic and pre.scnted

Heading: much
Content: food for the imagin- ation. In the last group the Paganini- Liszt Etude deserves
    particular mer- it, while the Nocture for left hand alone was unique. The
    closing

Heading: num-
Content: ber. La Campanella. was most bril- liantly executed. The clarity and smoothness
    of the trills were truly remarkable. .Mr. Sloyer was obliged to respond with
    frequent encores during the evening, the last of which

Heading: was
Content: a massive ocmposition in itself Bucknell University as well as the people of
    Lewisburg, can well be proud of such a brilliant and gifted pianist. Mr.
    Seaman, a

Heading: new
Content: 

Heading: member
Content: of the music faculty, gave several vocal numbers which were well received.

Heading: He
Content: was accompanied on the piano by Mrs. Moyer.

Heading: RELAYS
Content: Track and field has taken on

Heading: new
Content: activities during the past week. Next Saturday at 2:30 there is to be a handicap
    meet on this track. Last

Heading: Wednesday
Content: after the ba.<<e ball game, in which

Heading: we
Content: defeated Delaware, the try-outs for the relay team were held.

Heading: A
Content: large

Heading: number
Content: of

Heading: men
Content: reported for the quarter-mile try-outs and these

Heading: men
Content: were run individually and the time of each taken. Coach Gla.ss 1 and Manager
    Mohler acted as tlme- j J<eepers. Of the

Heading: men
Content: to run the fol- I lowing men. in the order

Heading: named
Content: 

Heading: made
Content: the best time: Hahn. Moor<<, Joseph, Davis. Chapman, Ro.'^enbloom, and Dayhoff .
    These tryouts. however, are not final and quite a few change^

Heading: may
Content: be expected. Five

Heading: nun
Content: will

Heading: make
Content: the Penn trip with the relay team, four

Heading: men
Content: to run and one as a substi- tute. The handicap meet on Saturday is open to all
    members of the univer- sity and handicaps are to be given I according to
    experience and ability. The

Heading: men
Content: 

Heading: who
Content: have already

Heading: made
Content: names for themselves will be on scratch. Entries will still be received by
    Manager Mohler,

Heading: up
Content: until Tue.<<day at noon and entrance blanks can be obtained from him or at the
    gym. The list of events includes the 100, 220, 440. 880. mile. 2 mile. 120
    high hurdles, 220 low luirdles, shot put, pule vault, high jump, broad jump,
    and the dl.<<cus throv.-. It has been requested by the man- agement that all
    automobiles, bi- cycles and vehicles of any kind keep and be kept off of the
    tracks. The base ball

Heading: men
Content: are also requested tto use the outside of the track, as their spikes cut up the
    track considerably. The young boys from town arc found on the track or
    walking acros. it at the entrance to the

Heading: home
Content: .'^tretch during track practice, and several of the runners have been hurt thru
    col- lision with them while running. It is hoped something will be done
    about this before there is

Heading: more
Content: ser- ious Injury.

Heading: SUSQUEHANNA
Content: -B-

Heading: Omar
Content: Dewald. '23. is visiting with frirnds at Jersey Shore, over the week end. C. E.
    Derek, '22. spent Friday and Saturday at ble

Heading: home
Content: in Trevorton. Dr.

Heading: W.
Content: G. Owens,

Heading: who
Content: recently

Heading: made
Content: a visit to Japan, spoke at Sus- quehanna last week.

Heading: The
Content: following account was taken from "The Su.-^- quehanna"; Dr.

Heading: Owens
Content: of the Bucknell Univer- >lty faculty gave to the students of Susquehanna a very
    inspiring and ed- ucational illUKtraled lecture on "Life in China and
    Japan,' 'last Thursday iifternoon. Dr.

Heading: Owens
Content: was one of th" delegates representing the United States at the World's Sunday
    School Convention held at Tokio. Japan. Through his wide experience and per-
    .^onal contact with the people of thc^ Orient, he was able to bring to his
    au- dience a lecture of great interest.

Heading: The
Content: lecture was supplemented by th-i use of well-selected slides. Dr.

Heading: Owens
Content: ^aid in part: "Japan's highly developed educa- tional system was introduced and
    es- tablished by

Heading: men
Content: of our

Heading: own
Content: colleger iind universities. Military tactics play an important part in their
    edu- eatlon and when drilling they

Heading: make
Content: a very impressive looking body. For the younger students there are well directed
    methods of recreation. Agricultural pursuits are devoted chiefly to the
    growing of rice and the -ilk worm.

Heading: A
Content: total of 17 per cent of the land is irrigated for the cultiva- tion of rice.

Heading: The
Content: tillage of the soil is intensive, altho greatly handi- capped by the lack of
    modern imple- ments.

Heading: Work
Content: of this kind is done to a large extent by the cjolie

Heading: who
Content: as a rule possesses great strength and vitality. Religion in Japan is gradually
    be- coming Christianized.

Heading: --
Content: that Is t!ie way romances end in the fairy tales. In reality, married life Is
    not always one joyous holiday. De- bates and di.scu.ssions of a more or less
    serious nature are frequent fac- tors in the lives of married people. Witty
    and humorous wordings in the public prints often reveal every-day happenings
    In the hou.sehold.

Heading: The
Content: press humorists show that those petty little arguments and misunderstand- ings
    are only trivial after all. In a pleasant, satirical vein. "Topics of the
    Daj' Films present the little ups and downs of married couples, and
    audiences laugh In sympathy with the people joked about. Married couples,
    pre.sent and future, and ev- erybody else will have a jolly time If they
    read the following funnies an- nounced below by the Bucknellian.

Heading: and
Content: cents which comes with the knowledge that you are engaged in a businss
    contributing to a permanent fund of

Heading: human
Content: happiness. The sale of Life Insurance is such a business. Life Insurance is
    thrift and protection, two fundamental elements in the scheme of a happy
    life, and to promote this is a

Heading: work
Content: worthy of any

Heading: man
Content: or

Heading: woman.
Content: That the public appreciates this service is best told by the fact that the
    volume of life insurance purchased doubles every ten years.

Content:

    the Seniors and Sophomores, and

Content: program will open at l.'O o'clock on Saturday afternoon, with registration and
    get-together of guests. At three o'clock Walter Lippman uf th.,-

Content: Republic" will deliver the opening address, and will be followed by speeches
    from the floor and the appointment of commit- tees. At six-thirty a banquet
    will be served in the living room of the Harvard I'nion, at which Senator
    Ladd of North Dakota, President Mc- Cracken of Vassar and other distin-
    guished

    present.

    opinion on social. Industrial, po- litical and international questions; the
    encouragement of inquiry; the presentation of facts; subservience to no
    "i.sms:" education of the col- lege youth in the problems of citizen- ship.

Heading: Penn
Content: State five matches to one on State College courts last Saturday afternoon.
    Lybarger, Gedrich. Koch and

Heading: Goho
Content: represented Bucknell anJ all of them displayed a superior brand of tennis with
    which State could not < ope. Lybarger

Heading: was
Content: at his bet>>t and his tiingles opponent,

Heading: "Andy"
Content: Wilson, "ould only secure one

Heading: game
Content: in two KEURt8. "Bill" easily took the match. 6-1, 6-0. In doubles, Lybarger and

Heading: Koch
Content: met with a little more opposi- tion but had no difficulty in finally *winning.
    Gedrich lost his singles to Bogs but with

Heading: Goho
Content: finally defeated Boggs and Parsons In straight sets, both of which were deuced.
    "Steve"

Heading: Goho
Content: 

Heading: made
Content: his first appearance as a

Heading: member
Content: of the team and played like a veteran, easily winning his singles und putting

Heading: up
Content: an excellent defensive

Heading: game
Content: in doubles. All of the matches were decided In Htralght sets with the exception
    of Koch's singles.

Heading: He
Content: and Parsons waged a pretty even battle with the former finally winning by the
    score C!f 6-3. 6-8, and 8-6. State seemed very anxious to se- cure a return
    match and it is quite likely that

Content: Sowers will ar- range to play tliom here on June 10.

Content: result of the State match gives promise of the tennis team's completing a
    successful season.

Heading: Manager
Content: Boweii, includes a match with Sus- fiuehanna at Selinsgrove on Friday and a
    match with Swarthmore at Lewisburg on

Heading: BRYAN
Content: 

Heading: SPEAKS
Content: "W^Jiiini Jennings Bryan spoke in Milton last Thursday evening. By special
    arrangement he stopped off at Bucknell Friday morning and spojte to the
    student body a.ssembled in

Heading: Commencement
Content: Hall. Mr. Bryan

Heading: commenced
Content: his speech by remarking on his love for college students and work

Heading: among
Content: them and his purpose to spend more and rnorj^ of his time

Heading: among
Content: them. Ills address was essentially a plea for full round- ed development,
    mentally, physically and morally.

Heading: He
Content: stressed especially the moral development, rebuking any system of education or
    system of thought which destroyed a man's be- lief in God and his faith in
    his fel- lowmen. Mr. Bryan was well re- ceived and his visit kindly appreci-
    ated.

Heading: RELAYS
Content: The relay team sent by Bucknell to the

Heading: Penn
Content: Relays last Saturday,

Heading: made
Content: a very creditable showing, taV- ing second place in her class.

Heading: We
Content: were entered In the fourth gro\ip of colleges, comprised of Muhlenburg.
    Bucknell, Gettysburg, Franklin and Marshall, Catholic University, Colby,
    Manhattan and Washington and Jef- ferson, In their order from the pole.
    Colby

Heading: made
Content: fir.-^t place with a time of two minutes thirty-three and two- fifth seconds, a

Heading: new
Content: record for this class. Bucknell finished second. Wa.shton and Jwfferson third
    and Franklin a.jd Marshall fourth. Our time was one of the best In all the
    college events. Every

Heading: man
Content: ran a good quarter, all averagnlg less than fifty-three seconds. Colby had two
    forty-nine second

Heading: men
Content: on her team; they

Heading: won
Content: simply because they could run faster.

Heading: BOTANY
Content: 

Heading: TRIP
Content: Last Saturday a crowd, composed ( f Dr. Davis' class in Botany and Professor
    Stewart's class in Zoology, and a few other students, visited the Snyder-
    Mlddleworth State Forest Re- serve, in Snyder County.

Heading: Two
Content: trucks und several "fllvers" left Woman'.- College a bout seven-thirty and

Heading: made
Content: the thirty nvile trip in time for lunch. This reserve contains some of the small
    area of virgin forest left in Pennsylvania. In spite of the rain and the
    cold the "nature hunters' had a good tie climbing over the mountain paths
    and fishing for trout. Basket lunch was served at the edge of the forest,
    after which the ex- ploring began.

Heading: Dean
Content: Philips and wife and Registrar Clark and wife ac- companied the party.

Heading: A
Content: happy sing- ing crowd returned thrue the cold rein. Victor

Heading: RECEPTION
Content: The Junior reception was held on

Heading: Wednesday
Content: evening In the

Heading: Women's
Content: College parlors. Seven forty-five found about thirty

Heading: men
Content: In the living room wondering what had happened to the Junior girls. But they
    came, and things went off with a bang. had his

Heading: name
Content: I tagged to his back and a contest was run at once to see

Heading: who
Content: could collect the o.-^t names. Appropriate prizes were awarded to Francis
    VanCleaf and Ike Humphrey. As a further "mixer" th Juniors divided them-
    selves Into twelve groups represent- ing the months of their respective
    birthdays.

Heading: Each
Content: group then gave a tableau to represent their month. September won, even though
    they could not ^et the statue of

Heading: Venus
Content: de Milo to represent the well-known fe- male

Heading: named
Content: for the ninth month.

Heading: By
Content: an eleventh-hour permi.ssion from Miss Carey, dancing was permitted for onehalf
    an hour.

Heading: To
Content: the

Heading: harmony
Content: produced by Wilson, Allan and Hoffa the clas."

Heading: made
Content: the most of those thirty minutes between nine-thirty and ten o'clock.
    Refreshments were served, songs and yells were wafted to the squirrles, and
    a really jolly bunch of Juniors disbanded aa ten- fifteen. The clas.s extend
    their thanks to Chairman

Heading: Law^on
Content: and his com- mittee, and to Miss Armstrong and Miss Fowler,

Heading: who
Content: acted as chaper- ones. for the occasion. After his musical numbers the boys
    gathered In a fire- .slde circle (every

Heading: man
Content: 

Heading: making
Content: his

Heading: own
Content: fire) and told stories.

Content: ac count of space the stories cannot be published In the Bucknelllan. Great
    credit is due Chairman "Dutch" .Miller and his comlttee for their part In
    the success of the smoker. The Juniors of '22 and their Senior guests had a
    royal time. The regret was expres."ed by

Heading: many
Content: that more such occasions cannot find a place in the college year. The Civil
    Engineering Society will meet In Euepla. Main College, on .Monday evening.

Heading: May
Content: 2nd, a twhich time Dr. liartol will speak.

Heading: On
Content: the following

Heading: Monday
Content: evening,

Heading: May
Content: V. Judge Johnson will speak to the so- ciety in the same place. The purpose of
    these meetings Is to establish the American Society of Civil Engineers at
    Bucknell. Thi3 is a national organization of wide- spread reputation.

Heading: The
Content: Interest of all Civil Engineering .students is earne:5tly solicited. It is
    essental that a goodly number of students be present at these meet- ngs.

Heading: The
Content: worries and cares of '22 went up in smoke Thursday evening.

Heading: The
Content: third ytar nien and quite a few Sen- iors met at the

Heading: gymnasium
Content: for one of the jclliest events of the year. Cig- arettes and cards were first in
    order. But soon the cigars were passed and the

Heading: men
Content: gathered in a crlcle to watch some clever bouts. Eddy Treadwell and

Heading: Ada
Content: Klein first entered the ring .-ind proceeded to wallop each othei- for three
    rounds. At the request of Treadwell, however, the second and third wtre

Heading: made
Content: one-minute rounds, with two-minute intermissions.

Heading: Hunt
Content: and Wilsbach were booked to wrestle but ofter witnessing this battle they
    decided ot box. The.se

Heading: two
Content: giants showed three rounds of good boxing.

Heading: No
Content: one was knocked out. however, except Referee Julian,

Heading: who
Content: tripped over a mat. Jlmmle Earle and Johnny Johnson next came on the mat for a
    wrestling match. After a fast tangle the

Heading: Smoke
Content: Shop proprietor was thrown for a down.

Heading: The
Content: pro-

Heading: gram
Content: was concluded with a bout be- tween Tcmjiiy Horan and Steve Hod- oba, for the
    championship of Locust Gap. Both boys showed good form, but they were too

Heading: warm
Content: friends to decide the championship at this time. "Gus" Short contributed
    generously toward the program. Besides an- nouncing the contestants he
    after- ward tuned his warbling tenor to the bai.jo orchestra which

Heading: was
Content: present

Heading: PROM.
Content: The Junior Prom, given last Friday night in the Lewisburg club by the class of
    1922, was one of the most successful events of the year. About eighty-five
    couples attended, which did not overcrowd the hall too

Heading: much
Content: to interfere with the dancing.

Heading: A
Content: great deal of credit should be given Chairman Diffendafer and the cimit- tee for
    the commendable

Heading: manner
Content: in which the dance was given.

Heading: A
Content: for- mal dance with Seminary girls In at- tendance is not an every-day occur-
    rence and it Is safe to say that every one enjoyed the affair to the utmost.
    Refreshments consisting of Ice- cream, cake and coffee were served at
    Interlssion at 10:30.

Heading: A
Content: bowl of punch was placed at the disposal of the guests early in the evening and
    proved to be a very popular spot a.s the eveninr wore on. The progranis of
    the dance were especially pleas- ing, being

Heading: made
Content: of a dark blue leather with an orange

Heading: "B"
Content: stamped on tho face and the whole fastened with an 'orange cord. 'Dlffy's
    College Five ' furnished most acceptable dance

Heading: mu-
Content: sic from 7:30 to 12 o'clock,

Heading: when
Content: they unpleasantly reminded everyone with "Home. Sweet Home," that it was time to
    go "there."

Heading: Day"

    utterances and writings of lead ing citizens and newspapers, relative to the
    biased and one-sided angle of such unfair and un-American legis- lation have

Heading: On
Content: Saturday one of the best and closest inter-class meets seen at Bucknell in years

Heading: was
Content: witnessed on Tu^^tln Field as a part of the program f(.!- nucknell Day.

Heading: The
Content: day was ideal f(,r a track and field meet except for a V,, eeze which struck the
    runners on llie back stretch and for a few drops

Heading: a
Content: rain which fell at the beginning of the contests. Very fast times were made in a

Heading: number
Content: of the races and the Held events were also quite good. The points were for a
    long time in favor of the Freshmen and it looked a<< if the Sophomores, last
    year's vic- tors in the inter-class meet, would po

Heading: down
Content: in defeat. The class of '23 was without three of her point-scor-

Heading: ers--
Content: Wren.

Heading: Chapman
Content: and Davis, but in the last few events she took all the points and

Heading: came
Content: through with flying colors. The last two events, the broad

Heading: jump
Content: and the half-mile, were taken entirely by Sophomores. Tvhlch added twenty points
    to their tally This made a total of fifty-six points, giving them a margin
    of ten points over the Freshmen with forty- Bix points. The Junior class had
    the third largest

Heading: number
Content: of points, fin- ishing with thirty-one.

Heading: The
Content: Senior track team, represented by Ein.- Smith, finished last but not least,
    *with two points to their credit. Joseph was the outstanding star of the
    meet, scoring eighteen points jn all for his t6am. He

Heading: won
Content: the 100- yard dash, the 200-yard dash, the quarter mile r.nd was second in the
    high jump. That is a mighty fine record for one afternoon. His time in all
    of these events, was, moreover, exceptionally fast. His time In the century
    of 10 1-5 was equal to Love

Heading: VACATION
Content: Senior vacation begins

Heading: May
Content: 29th. All Seniors

Heading: who
Content: at tluil time have the requrled credits for graduation are entitled to two weeks
    vacation. Special announcement is made, how- ever, that all Seniors

Heading: who
Content: shall hav? fifteen absences on

Heading: May
Content: 15. 1921. shall be denied the Senior vacation and shall continue all courses to
    the end of the semester.

Heading: CONFERENCE

    the semi-annual confer- ence of the Intercollegiate Newspaper Association of
    the Middle Atlantic States, which will be held at Gettys- burg on Friday and
    Saturday of this week.

    quarter was exceptionally fast.

Content: ran this in 51 3-5 seconds, very close to record time.

    throw.

Heading: The
Content: Cap and Dagger Dramatic So (iety of this insitution will present either the last
    week In

Heading: May
Content: or the first week in June, a farcial comedy in three acts entitled. 'Nothing But
    The Truht." This play, which wa.^ written by James Montgomery, played a
    season at the Longacre Theatre.

Heading: New
Content: York, and has been on tour for three years. The comedy deals with the
    experiences of a wealthy young ?tockbroker

Heading: who
Content: pledges himself to tell 'nothing but the truth" for a period of twenty-four
    hours. The ab- surd and complicated situations that arise are extremely
    humorous.

Heading: The
Content: entire cast has not been se- lected but Francis

Heading: H
Content: Gibson will play the leiiding role and will be .-supported by Ada

Heading: Thomas
Content: as leading lady. It has been planned to use no Seniors in this play on account
    of the inter- ference it would cause with the Sen- ior Class Play.

Content: 

Heading: S

Heading: CHEMISTRY
Content: The

Heading: number
Content: of recitation hours per

Heading: week
Content: 

Heading: m
Content: Chemistry I. haa been in- creased from three to five, while re- t.iining the
    same

Heading: number
Content: of credit hours (5). and not requiring from the student more than fifteen hour?
    of time (including the class hours.) In pursuance of the custom that they
    established at Bucknell five years ago. of observing Mother's Day a*^ a
    fraternity, Sigma Chi gave those

Heading: who
Content: are affiliated with the fraternity as mothers and wives, an informal reception
    for the entertainment of the thirty ladies

Heading: who
Content: were present.

Heading: The
Content: program had been arranged with Diffy furnishing the music. The entertainment
    was, for the most part, on the porch, although the boys took great pleasure
    in having the ladies inspect the interior of the house as well. Everyone had
    a very enjoyable afternoon. The hoys hav- ing mothers present generously
    shared with those not so fortunate.

Heading: A
Content: feature of the occasion

Heading: was
Content: the

Heading: number
Content: of mothers present

Heading: who

    luncheon was served. Later in the day a picture of the group was taken.
    After some more pleasant visiting the mothers were motored to their re-
    spective homes.

    semseter system, the number of tri, s taken was increa.sed while their
    duration decreased. V trip to the western part of the state .nt Thanksgiving
    time, a trip into the northern part of the state at Christ- mas, a trip to

Heading: New
Content: Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania during the Easter vaca- tion and several week-
    end trips to surrounding towns, furnish evidence as to the activity of the
    club. Every- where it did such excellent work that the task of securing
    dates for next year, in its early development, ha- proved to be greatly
    facilitated.

Content: laces but the other were too fast for them and they were both eliminated. In the
    trial beats of the 4 40-yard run

Heading: we
Content: had two men-^Joseph and Hahn. participat- ing. There were three trial heats, the
    first three of each heat to qual- ify for the finals. Joseph, although badlv
    spiked at the start of his race, ran a mighty pUicky and fast race and

Heading: won
Content: his heat in exceptoinally fast time

Heading: Due
Content: to the crowding at the Btart he

Heading: was
Content: forced back, but on the back stretch, with a wonderful burst of speed, he forced
    himself up

Heading: among
Content: the leaders and maintained his po- sition until the home-stretch where he
    gradually forced himself into the tead.

Heading: Hahn
Content: ran in the next heat and he laso ran a mighty heady and fast race, finishing
    second in hi^ heat and thereby qualifying for his finals.

Heading: He
Content: also got

Heading: way
Content: to a bad start, but on his first turn forced himself to the front and by a hard
    sprint finished second.

Heading: Hahn
Content: and Joseph both ran their heats in 52 seconds flat. Dayhoff ran in the low
    hurdles but did not succeed in qualifying for the semi-finals. The field was
    too fast .for Harry and, though he ran a game race, he

Heading: was
Content: outclassed. In the 220- yard dash, Joseph again did him.self proud, finishing
    second and thu.A *iualifying for the semi-finals. In the field events all
    the

Content: practiced in the morning were elim- inated with the exception of Ha.slam,

Content: qualified for the finals. Trials in the broad

Heading: jump
Content: were not held until the afternoon. Treadwell and

Heading: Wren
Content: both entered the high

Heading: jump
Content: and made some fine jumps, but the field was a mighty classy one and they were
    eliminated. Wilsbach partici- pated In the trials of the shot-put and
    discus-throw but did not succeed in qualifying for the afternoon events.
    Treadwell also entered the discus but did not qualify. The team was
    entertained for din- ner by the

Heading: Kappa
Content: Alpha fraternity. They put up a mighty fine dinner for the team and entertained
    them In flro Htyle. Nothing seemed too

Heading: much
Content: trouble to them while looking afte,- the comfort of the team. In the afternoon
    the first final event in which Bucknell took part was the finals of the 4
    40. in which both Joseph and

Content: had qualified.

Content: drew position

Content: 4 while Joseph drew the extreme outside po- sition. In thf fight for the pole

    Three wife at the duor. Surprise was ex- of evenin.i pressed at the
    appearance preparation on the part of Mrs. Dav- i>^.

Heading: A
Content: second .-surprise soon came in the greeting of the guests present. The clever
    arrangements were moving in order and soon the chimo:^ sounded. As the
    guests moved into the dining room each took his place where he thought he
    belonged, which place he chose by selecting a sou- venir of the evening
    which he sup- posed suited.

Heading: Then
Content: each read a cleverly written

Heading: name
Content: card and if it suited the penson he remained where he was. If the

Heading: name
Content: card did not Piiit, the reader changed places witli the person to

Content: the verse al- luded in "life occupation."

Content: all had been rightfully as- signed tu his place, a most delightful dinner

Heading: was
Content: served. Miss Davis helping in giving the family touch to the evening. The dinner
    ended with each receiving a remembrance souvenir of the event. After dinner
    the guests were enter- tained by Prof. Stewart, using his character
    sketches. The.-e were thor- oughly enjoyed by all. The plans of the evening
    were to

    * Dr. Davis,

Content: head of the Bio- logical department, has done a serv- ice any

Content: 

Heading: ENTERTAINED
Content: Registrar and Mrs. Theron Clark delightfully entertained

Heading: members
Content: of the college office force at their

Heading: home
Content: on Wedncs-day evening,

Heading: May
Content: 11. Everyone was told to come pre parde to do a "stunt," which resulted In
    .'^uch features as Bolter chancing off an owl,

Heading: Owens
Content: telling a story about two Chinamen and a dog, "Dlnty" Moore rendering a vocal
    solo, Carr and Miss

Heading: Seamon
Content: each re- citing and

Heading: Owens
Content: and Miss Seslngcr singing a duet. Later In the evening everyone went to the
    dining room and partook of delicious refreshments.

Heading: A
Content: most pleasant evening was spent and each one felt It well worth while to be

Heading: number
Content: 

Heading: among
Content: the "force." Geroge Schuyler '21. Perry Rogers *22, and Roy Land.s '22,
    represent- ing the Bucknellian, attended the semi-annual conference of the
    Inter- collegiate Newspaper Association of the Middle Atlantic States, held
    at Getty.sburg, last Friday and Saturday. This association includes weekly
    n.wspapers of nineteen colleges of Pennsylvania.

Heading: New
Content: 

Heading: York.
Content: 

Heading: New
Content: Jersey, Delaware and Maryland most of which were represented at this conference.

Heading: The
Content: business meeting, held Satur- day morning, was of keen Interest to anybody
    interested in collegiate newspaper work. Professor Sander;, of the
    Gettysburg faculty, gave a live wire talk on the opportunities and
    responsibilities of collegiate newspa- pers. Colletie journalism, he said,
    i.- a

Heading: new
Content: thing, not found in European institutions, an outgrowth of Amer- ican democracy.

Heading: A
Content: collegiate news- paper, like any newspaper, is a shaper of public opinion. Just
    as Cleon was the most dangerous^

Heading: man
Content: in Athens In the time of Aristotle, because he

Heading: knew
Content: 

Heading: how
Content: to appeal to the superficial Impulses of the people, so the jour- nalist becomes
    dangerous

Heading: when
Content: he over-emphaslzefc the insigniflacnt and refuses to deal with the big construc-
    tional ideas of his time.

Heading: A
Content: collegi- ate newspaper must do more than report happenings, it must strive at
    dealing with big questions in a truly literary way. Election of officer? for
    the coming year was conducted, George Schuyler acting as chairman <f the
    nominat- InK committee. Richard Slocum of Swarthmore

Heading: was
Content: elected president;

Heading: Roy
Content: 

Heading: H.
Content: Landis, business manager of the Buknellian,

Heading: was
Content: elected treasurer of the association. The Bucknellian was hospitably received by
    her old rival. Every op- portunity was taken by the Gettys- burgians to show
    their guests a good time.

Heading: On
Content: Saturday afternoon the en- lire conference was conducted over the battlefield in
    automobiles. The fall conference will be held at Bucknell, probably the day
    of the Huknell-Lafayette game. The Buck- nellian is planning for a real live
    conference and will call upon the student body to help put it across. One ol
    the speakers during the Seventy nfth celebration of Com- j mencem' nt at
    Bucknell tJnlverslty will be General Tasker

Heading: H.
Content: Bliss. General Bliss is an alumnus of Buck- nell wh.. has played an Important
    role in the military and diplomatic affairs <>f the I'nlt.d States, and hl.f
    return at this time with the matters which he will have to discuss. Is of
    the highest Interest to both alumni

Heading: who
Content: will be here at the time and to the present undergrads. Fo^- thl.i reason a
    short sketch of his life is given li'i-e: General BHbs was born in Lewis-
    burg on December 31, 1853, the son of the Rev. George Ripley and Mary

Heading: Ann
Content: Bliss. His mother was the daught. r of a professor at the Uni- versity. He
    attended the

Heading: Academy
Content: for four years and then took two years' work at the l^niversity, leaving for

Heading: W<
Content: -t Point in 1871 and graduat- ing from that institution in 187.'^. Several years
    later he was an honor graduate of the U. S. Artillery School.

Heading: He was
Content: married In 1882.

Heading: Upon
Content: his graduation from West Point. General BlLss was comml-i- i-ioned a HPcond
    lleutennat in the First ArtiUrey, and in five years he had become a first-
    lieutenant. In 1892 he was commissioned as capta'n of the commissary
    subsistence. Just before the outbreak of the Spanish- American

Heading: War
Content: he was commissioned a major. Following the close of the war he was sent to Cuba
    to reorgan- ize the customs service, which duty he vcrfc-rmed in a highly
    efficient manner.

Heading: He
Content: also helped to negotiate the treaty between the infant repub- lic and the United
    States.

Heading: m
Content: 1899 he was commissioned lieu- tenant-colonel chief of the commis sarv of
    subsistence, and after holding the' post of Brigadier General of vol-
    unteers, was made Brigadier General in the Regular army in 1902.

Heading: He
Content: served on several staffs and special missions at this time and

Heading: saw
Content: serv- ice in the Philippines.

Heading: He
Content: was also sent to study the artillery systems of the Europeans. General Bliss was
    on the Mexican border in 1912. After holding sev- Turn to Page Three

Heading: SURVEY
Content: On Friday,

Heading: May
Content: 6, a party consist- ing of Professor J.

Heading: W.
Content: Rice, Nelson Davis, Jr.. and Harry V.

Heading: Thomas
Content: started on a thret-day hike through the mountains. The object of the trip was to
    produce a

Heading: map
Content: in survey outline which would some day

Heading: make
Content: possible a bacteriollogical survey of White Deer creek. The party left Lewisburg
    at 6:25 a. m. and arrived f.t White Deer sta- tion where they started off on
    foot. Following a course almost due west they arrived at the intake of the
    *White Deer

Heading: Water
Content: 

Heading: Company
Content: and her.' were met by Mr. Huff, the care-taker of the

Heading: dam
Content: and supply station. Mr. Huff proved an admirable guide and accompanied the party
    as far as Mile Run, at which site

Heading: camp
Content: 'Goodland- er' is located. The streams and springs feeding White Deer were
    pointed out by Mr. Huff

Heading: who
Content: also gave valuable information as to the source of the streams, acid

Heading: camp
Content: sites located upon them, which in ". bacteriological survey would prove to be
    valuable information. At

Heading: camp
Content: Goodlander the party had dinner and after bidding Mr. Huff farewell started out
    alone to trace

Heading: White
Content: Deer to Its pource.

Heading: The
Content: after- noon found the party will on its

Heading: way
Content: and at 4 p. m. they had reached Z'm- nierman's farm, which is located fourteen
    miles from the

Heading: dam
Content: and is the source of Sand Spring Run. one of the main trlbutarlts to White Deer
    Creek. Zimmerman'? farm Is :tJso 1400 feet higher than the dam. which proves
    that the party had an up-hill Job.

    Swarthmore four with what was vir- tually a victory in the shape of a 3-1
    tie. Swarthmore has one of the strongest teams in the country for an
    institution of its size and it cer- tainly was no disgrace to tie them.
    Swarthmore had an ace in Dudley, their first man. He has been defeat- ed
    only in the Princeton match thi.^ year.

Content: of years. Both Lybarger and Gedrich played hard

    "connect." At one time they had their opponents 5-2 and lost the set, 7-5.

    but tightened up and

Heading: won

    taking the first set, alternated with his man, winning two out of three.
    Captain Brandt and Koch played together in doubles and after a hard fight

Heading: won
Content: the match in straight sets. The next match will be with Sus- quehanna at
    Selinsgrove next Satur- day.

Heading: TENNIS
Content: For the first time in the past two years a really interested crowd at- tended
    the tennis match which wai played last Friday afternoon witli Swarthmore.
    The fact that tlie stu- dent body are behind their represent- atives even in
    the most minor of minor sports certainly shows a spirit worthy of
    commendation. It was an honor for our tennis team to tie Swarthniore because
    of the latter'.-' ^ast Kecord. They have defeated U. fit P., Lehigh, Army,
    and other large institutions of repute. The fact that

Heading: we
Content: were able to tie them in the re- cent match was in a large measure due to the
    support from the sidelines which shows that while our tracli and baseball
    teams are

Heading: away
Content: we will support what we have and do it well.

Heading: ANNUAL
Content: 

Heading: SURVEY
Content: IS

Heading: MADE
Content: The cla.s.s in advance Bacteriology

Heading: made
Content: its annual survey of Spruce

Heading: Run
Content: on Friday and Saturday. The work, though under the direct supervision of Prof.
    Rice, was done practically alone by class teams.

Heading: Th
Content: .' class was organized into different groups, having a definite part of the
    arrangements for the trip to care for and see that all preparations pertain-
    ing to the departure were completed in time and order. The media group
    consisting of Harry Thomas, chairman in charg<<\ Miss Mackereth, Miss
    Dodson, Mr. Crowl, Mr. Schultz.

Heading: (Herman
Content: D.), Mr. T. A. Salaczynski. Mr. Roller, had charge of the preparation of all me-
    dia for the work in the field. The glass-ware group: Miss E. Weidmer.
    chairman, Miss

Heading: Anna
Content: F'air- child Miss Effie Miller and Miss

Heading: K.
Content: Giover had charge of the preparation and sterilization of all glassware needed
    in the field and by the media s;roup. Sustenance group; Miss C. Cas- ner,
    chairman, Mis.s Unger and Miss Swan, on whose shoulders rested the "eats"
    question both in the form of cold lunches and hot meals. Transportation:
    William Wallace Lewis, chairman. Stewardson. aide. . Hvating plant: Harold
    Miller, chairman,

Heading: V.
Content: Evans, aide.

Heading: On
Content: Friday morning the class left Lewisbiug at 6:30 and arrived at Spruce

Heading: Run
Content: 

Heading: Dam
Content: about 8 a. m. Here after noting the points of interest, the first samples were
    taken and the first plates poured. Here the party divided into throe
    divisions, two pushing up stream, one on either side, getting samples and
    one-third taking the truck and Ford.i on to camp. At noon the tliree groups
    united at the point where the pipe line crosse.^ Spjuce Run. The lunch was
    served, dfter which the party pushed on to Hagfrstown. At this point the
    final plates for the day were poured ami then began the tramp over the

Heading: moun
Content: tain through Black Bear

Heading: <<ap
Content: to Davis' camp, "Hot D>g. '

Heading: When
Content: the highest point in the gap was reached those of the party

Heading: who
Content: Hixti not y<<t had their fill of climbing- >>^ere taken to a point still higher
    where to a good advantage the sur- rounding country could be viewed Mud
    enjoyed. Ivheft

Heading: camp
Content: was reached the sus- tenance committee proved their end of the preparations was
    fully taken care of.

Heading: The
Content: following was served

Heading: "Hot
Content: dog," baked potatoes, frie.l ham, fried eggs, baked beans, bread uid butter,
    coffee. After each had vaHhed his eating utensils and rested I bit the
    Kir!;*, under the direction of lls/virgina Walton, chaperone of hP trip.,
    and .Nelson Davis. Jr., with several other of the

Heading: men
Content: as "aides, went to the Forest House where prep arations had be.n

Heading: made
Content: for them to spend the nighf.

Heading: A
Content: wonderful inci- dent here occurred "for those

Heading: who
Content: remained at camp." Bef.re the ,(de. ha.l reached

Heading: ramp
Content: Nature began to show her sympathy U>i lliose wlio had been jraliaut and In bo
    doing drenched those "poor babes In the wood. " "Hot Dog!"

Heading: On
Content: Saturday morning a "Whip- poor-Will " sounded the rising note at 4 a. ni. All
    hands were on deck at one cabin by four-thirty, except Evans, and due to
    applied force, soon

Heading: ALL
Content: were busy in some duty or other. Davis soon had a roaring fire go- ing and

Heading: Thomas
Content: soon had the

Heading: "ham-
Content: wliat-am" sizzling. Soon after six the girls arrived at

Heading: camp
Content: and breakfast, consisting of fried ham, fried potatoes, fried eggs, coffee,
    sassafras tea, bread and but- ter, wa.s served. Here it was noted that ail
    domestic talent was not con- fined to the Domestic Science depart- ment.
    Soon after breakfast the party broke

Heading: camp
Content: for the completing of the bacteriological survey work. Follow- ing the old Culp
    railroad after cross- ing the mountain for setting-up ex- ercise, the party
    reached Spruce

Heading: Run
Content: .Shanty at the headwaters of Spruce

Heading: Run
Content: about ten o'clock. At this point the final plates were poured and all put in
    order for tlie ascent of San-i Mountain. With Miss Walton in the lead and
    .setting a goodly pace, the climb, very difficult at times, was

Heading: made
Content: with all reaching the top. Here a second dim!) was afforded those

Heading: who
Content: still had the Inclination.

Heading: On
Content: the top of Sand Mountain stands a steel towei used by the forest rangers as an
    out look post

Heading: when
Content: on watch for fore;<t rtrvs. The ascent to>>the top is

Heading: made
Content: by climbing a steel ladder and the girls proved equal to the task for their
    names appeared on the register which is found in the cupolo. This point was
    the greatest height to which some ambitions had gone but It was noticed that
    during the return to

Heading: camp
Content: other heights had not yet been reached and friendly hands picked the dainty lady
    slippers and bestowed them to the rightful sex. At

Heading: camp
Content: a delightful lunch awaited the liungry crew. Here again baked pickles, fried
    beans and scrambl'-d potatoes with bread to

Heading: dear
Content: the

Heading: way
Content: and coffee to wash away the traces (if hunger, were thoroughly enjoyed by all.
    After duly putting all things In order the class started on its home- ward
    journey about 3:30 p. m. At the Forest Hou.se all were loaded into the Fords
    and truck and after a shouting farewell to those about, the jolly crowd
    rolled homeward. During the journey

Heading: homeward
Content: the truck needed more air and here again Miss Dodson supplied the needed ar-
    ticle with her un-tire-ing efforts.

Heading: Much
Content: might be said concerning undi- viduals but as Evans can vouch. "It knocks the
    spots out of city life." Under the able direction of Profes- sor "Jack "
    Rice and the efficient chaperoning of Miss Walton,

Heading: whom
Content: the crowd vote on being real .sports, the trip was considered as a huge suc-
    cess, both in experience gained and fun enjoyed. Selah

Heading: W.
Content: Suttnii iiuul.' a bu.inc s trip to Harrisburg over the week-end.

Heading: Omar
Content: E. Dewald, '23, spent the week-end visiting friends in Jersey Shore.

    Creek.

Content: this point the party -brushed- tho.r

Heading: wav
Content: up the valley .passing peak aft.v p.-uk until tliey reached the old Buf- falo
    Trail. Here the party had lunch und then pushed ahead to McCall-s

Heading: Dam.
Content: Leaving McClal'B

Heading: Dam
Content: and follow- ing a trail along the mountain, de-

Heading: scnding
Content: 

Heading: now
Content: and tlien into the val- ley for information regarding the .ourse of streams, the
    party forged ahead to Black Gap. where

Heading: camp
Content: was pitched for the night.

Heading: The
Content: following morning found the party on its last lap and well on its

Heading: uay
Content: 

Heading: when
Content: the sun showed its tirst ravs over the mountain tops. At no'o<< the party had
    reached its des- tination at the springs of Tunis. Here the pedometers
    averaged nearly forty-ttve miles, which distance had been covered with
    sleeping and eat- ing e(iuipment. After resting a short time, the partv
    started on its

Heading: homeward
Content: jour- nev." arriving at Yankee

Heading: Run
Content:

Content: at "the htad of the Fourteen Mile Nar- rows about two o'clock. At thin point the
    party was met by Harold Miller and were brought to Lewis- burg by Ford. The
    three days' tramp showed a registrv of approximately fifty mil'-s covered,
    which, according to Thomas. **with a ton on a man's back is no

Heading: mean
Content: distance between two points. The weather was ideal and the in- formation

    department, and especially so

Content: <* .J The cast for the Senior class play, * Seven Keys to Baldpate," has been
    (hosen and the play is

Heading: now
Content: well under way. The play is a mystery farce and one of George

Heading: M.
Content: Cohan's r reatest stage successes. It consists ot two acts, every line of which
    is 'hrouded in mystery and plots and "ounter-plots. Chairman

Heading: H.
Content: LeRoy Heller has teen working hard to

Heading: make
Content: this the best play ever given in Lewisburg by amateur talent. Because of the
    large amount of talent in the class of 21, both male and female, it is .sure
    to be a huge succeas. One of the most prominent features will be the
    uppearance of Miss .Martha Leiser in the lead. Miss Leiser will appear as
    "Mary Norton," a newspaper report- < r; and tlie play will be centered on
    her and on

Heading: H.
Content: 

Heading: LeRoy
Content: Heller. These two prominent stage artists have ap- peared in the lead together
    in

Heading: many
Content: plays during their four college yean^ and this will be their final play at
    Bucknell. .Miss Leiser's

Heading: home
Content: is in Lewisburg nd she is a daughter of

Heading: Howard
Content: Loiser.

Heading: Even
Content: before entering Buck- nell and while still in high school ^he attracted great
    attention by her marvelous acting and pleased every- one with her great
    ability. During her college career she has taken prominent parts in
    practically all Frill and

Heading: Frown
Content: and Cap and Dag- ger plays

Heading: and
Content: 

Heading: many
Content: other plays that have been given In Lewisburg. This epring she had the honor of
    being chosen as

Heading: May
Content: Queen, an honor she also had while in high school.

Heading: H.
Content: 

Heading: LeRoy
Content: Heller, whose

Heading: home
Content: is 5n Reading, has al.so attracted

Heading: much
Content: attention

Heading: by
Content: his marvelous ability during his four years here. This is his fourth year as a

Heading: member
Content: of Cap and Dagger, In -which he took a prom- inent part, playing the lead in a
    great

Heading: many
Content: of that society's successful pro- ductions.

Heading: The
Content: rest of the cast have appeared frequently in productions here and all possess
    ability to fulfill their parts in great style. This will be the last chance
    to see these art- ists together at Bucknell.

Heading: The
Content: play is being directed by

Heading: Hack"
Content: Gibson, which further in- .=ures it as a success. It will be giv- en in

Heading: Commencement
Content: Hall. All seats will be reserved and will be placed on sale at Heiser's

Heading: Drug
Content: Store on Wednesday of this week. Seats will also be sold the evening of hte pre-
    sentation on the "Hill." starting at seven o'clock

Content: advertising Is out and the '* novel large posters are attracting

Heading: much
Content: attention. Special scenery is to be had for the production and this is being ob-
    tained from the Ameliagrain .studio of Philadelphia. The costumes and wigs
    are being obtained from the Charles D. Christy Co., of

Heading: New
Content: York City.

Heading: The
Content: story begins in

Heading: New
Content: York City. William Hallowell Magee, a novelist, played by Heller, makes a bet
    that be can write a twenty-four thousand word story in twenty-four hours,
    providing he has absolute se- clusion.

Heading: The
Content: friend with

Heading: whom
Content: he makes the bet, owns the Baldpate Inn, In-the mountains, and gives him the key
    to the inn, telling

Heading: him
Content: it i^ the only key, and as the inn is un- occupied, he can find seclu.sion
    there.

Heading: Magee
Content: arrives at the'inn in the even- ing and finds the caretaker,

Heading: who
Content: ha.-i

Heading: made
Content: arrangements for his coming.

Heading: He
Content: proposes to start work

Heading: when
Content: he is interrupted by a crook,

Heading: who
Content: opens the door with a kep and puts some

Heading: money
Content: In the inn safe. After a .scuf- fle, Magee succeeds in locking him in

Heading: a
Content: room.

Heading: was
Content: the dinner given at the Lewisburg club on Tuesday evening.

Heading: May
Content: 17, by the faculty of the Uni- versity In honor of Professor William

Heading: Emmet
Content: Martin, A. M.. L.

Heading: H.
Content: D., and Professor William Cyrus Bartol,

Heading: A.
Content: M., Ph. D.,

Heading: who
Content: have been attached to the faculty for fifty and forty years respectively. Seldom
    has the club lieen decked in such gala attire as it was on Tues- day
    evening.

Heading: The
Content: huge Bucknell flag was hung at one end of the ball room

Heading: and
Content: an Aemrican flag at an- other, while garlands of pine and leaves were' used for
    further decor- ation. The tables were arranged in a hollow square, the
    toastmaster and speakers of the evening, with their wives, being seated at
    the head table. The color scheme of the tables was orange and blue, which
    was carried out by the use of orange and blue candles. At each plate was
    laid a white carnation and bouquet.^ of the carnations were also to be found
    on the tables. The blest^lng was asked by Rev. John T. Judd. Treasurer of
    the Uni- versity. Immediately following the blessing. Registrar Clark
    announced that

Heading: CLEAN
Content: 

Heading: POLITICS?
Content: 

Heading: A
Content: great deal of hot air has been blowing around during the last few months about
    "cleaning up college politic.-^." The cla.ss of '23. first as usual in any

Heading: new
Content: 

Heading: movement
Content: ha.<

Heading: made
Content: a forward st.^p in this direc- tion. The-manner fo *23's last <^^lass election
    w.u epoc making. Last Thursday afternoon at 4.30 the Sophomore claas.s
    elected the editor and busine,>s

Heading: manager
Content: of next year'.s L'agenda. offices which. In the opin- ion of many, are the most
    important in a college course. The only public announcement of this meeting
    was given at Chapel Thursday morning, at whi-h time, less than half the
    Sophomore

Heading: men
Content: are present.

Heading: No
Content: notice whatsoever appeared on any of the bulletin board.s. The suppo.sition is
    that election was

Heading: managed
Content: in this

Heading: way
Content: in order to eliminate the possi- bilitv of any framedup combination coming
    prepared to carry off the election. The point to be established in this
    inference, however is that no college r;roup had any informa- tion other
    than the chapel announce- ment. Whether the idea was "clean politics" or
    politics otherwise is a matter which everyone

Heading: who
Content: is inter- ested must judge from the facts of the case. If the decision Is
    "clean," well and sood. If it is "otherwi.se" some acti)n .should be taken
    in the matter of future elections.

Heading: A
Content: good suggestion is a ruling which will require a three-day notice of any
    election and an announcement in both sections of chapel. A. Sophomore.

Heading: ASOCIAnON
Content: 131

Heading: W^
Content: 39th St.

Heading: New
Content: York City. Advisory Deoartment. In order to accomplish the purpose of the.se
    articles more than tlie bar*' statement of historical dates is need- ed.
    Somethnig of the humorous, something of the personal element is needed to
    get real insight Into the early spirit of Bucknell. The ar- ticles printed
    are cho.sen with this object in mind. The first is written from
    investigation by a present stu- dent, the seocnd by tlie only living

Heading: member
Content: of the first cla.ss graduated from the college.

Heading: Ye
Content: Old Annals i leaf through the tjld annaJ.s of, the University of Lewisburg with
    a feeling of

Heading: awe
Content: and respect, touched occasionally by a tingle of humor. The

Heading: awe
Content: and respect Is due no doubt to the picture gallery therein of the sturdy
    burghers

Heading: who
Content: laid the foun- dation of this university. As I write, the stern, .set face of
    one of the fathers of knowledge lies before

Heading: me
Content: and his eyes are glaring angrijy at

Heading: me
Content: because he knows I

Heading: am
Content: wondering whether barbers and lawn-mower were luxuries in his time. As for the

Heading: humor
Content: in the annals well, ligures

Heading: AUE
Content: humorous if

Heading: we
Content: allow them to tell their tale. The worthy book slates that tuition in the
    collegiate department is. thirty dol- lars per year and room rent seven
    dollars and a half per year. 1

Heading: am
Content: wondering if the professors of that period were retired bankers or train
    robbers.

Heading: Then
Content: again, student-s are admonished not to bring any pocket

Heading: money
Content: with them so that they

Heading: may
Content: not be tempted to riotous living.

Heading: And
Content: then to drive

Heading: home
Content: the Importance of proper morals, each student, whether tie will or no, was a

Heading: member
Content: of the , Society of Moral and Religious In- (|uiry." Our worthy Baptist found-
    ers were evidently conservatLsts in , religious matters. i But

Heading: my
Content: purpose is to find out facts : and figures of the founding of our I university
    so I turn back to the first 'page of the annals and read: "The I
    Northumberland Baptist Association i met in 1845 and resolved to found a
    high school for males, another for females, a college, and also a theo-
    logical institute.

Heading: The
Content: charter of the university at Lewisburg was signed on February 5, 1&46, by the
    governor of Pennsylvania. Stephen

Heading: H.
Content: Taylor was elected principal of the school and on October 5 of the same year,
    classes were organized in the base- ment of the Baptist church until the
    completion of the building. The fac- ulty consisted of Stephen

Heading: H.
Content: Taylor. A. M.. profes.sor of mathematics and natural philosophy; Rev. George R.
    Bliss, professor of Greek language and literature; Geofge

Heading: H.
Content: Ander.son. A. M.. professor of Latin language and literature; Isaac

Heading: N.
Content: Loomis,

Heading: A
Content: M.. principal of the Academy; Alfred Taylor. A.

Heading: M..
Content: tutor of English lan- guage and elocution; and

Heading: Norman
Content: Ball, principal of the primary de- partment. In 1848 the academy building was
    completed and plans were

Heading: made
Content: for the building of main college. In 1850-51. on the motion of Han. James
    Buchanan, afterward presi- dent of the United States, degrees were conferred
    upon the first class presented for graduation

Heading: --
Content: so- mi in number. At that time the attend- ance was as follows: College 61.

Heading: Academy
Content: 117, Female Institute 48.

Heading: making
Content: a total of 226. In 1851-5 2

Heading: Howard
Content: Malcolm be-

Heading: came
Content: president upon the resignation of Dr. Taylor. Forty-five thousand dollars was
    raised for buildings and the Ladles' Institute was moved into the building
    at the corner of Second and St. Louis streets, with Miss Had- assah Scribner
    as principal. In 1854-55 the theological depart-

Heading: ment
Content: was established and the first class, two In number, graduated from the
    institute.

Heading: REMINISCENCES
Content: moved with

Heading: my
Content: father to a point near Rus.selvllle. Here I becanje Interest- ed in the study of
    Latin. Later I studied Greek for several years under the direction of

Heading: my
Content: father, completing In this

Heading: way
Content: Xenophon'.j Anabasis and

Heading: much
Content: of the

Heading: New
Content: Tes- tament. In 18,j4. having united with the Beulah Baptist church at the age
    of fiixteen, I attempted to preach in vai;ious places. In 1847 I noticed a
    movement had been for .some time on foot to establish the "University at
    Lewisburg. " I

Heading: made
Content: arrange- ments to go. and reached our Stat capital by rail. I remembered a part
    of a lesson in Olney's Geography lik-j this:

Heading: "What
Content: is a canal?" Answer:

Heading: "A
Content: canal is an artificial channel filled with water, for the easy, speedy and cheap
    transportation of good; from one section of the country to another." I
    wanted to see a canal and sail on one; but a fre.shet had put the
    Susquehanna canal out of business and I had to take a stage and travel all
    night. In the fore- noon of the next day the driver stopped at the end of
    the old Market streei bridge and handed

Heading: down
Content: 

Heading: my
Content: trunk. Not liking to leave it here as it was, I could but pick It up and walk
    across. I found the university in a brick church edifice on the sit of the
    present music hall. There were three rooms in the basement. In the largest
    one there were rows of plain red desks at which the students were seated.

Heading: On
Content: one aide the girls, and on the other side, the boys. But our seats faced
    different ways. If we looked around once in a while there was no

Heading: harm
Content: done. Talk about co- education being a tentative matter.

Heading: We
Content: had it

Heading: away
Content: back In 1847 and I was brought up to It and liked it. It was a happy day

Heading: when
Content: the Acad-

Heading: emy
Content: was finished and

Heading: many
Content: of us took our desks on our heads and marched up to the hill the lids of the
    desks clapping us on our march. Still

Heading: we
Content: had the girls on the other side and were proud to consider them our better half.
    Noble girls I believe them to be and felt that their influ- ence was
    salutory. They were forming a Freshman class

Heading: when
Content: I arrived in Lewisburg and I was ascribed a place in it and

Heading: we
Content: were Seniors all the

Heading: way
Content: through college.' Doctor S.

Heading: W.
Content: Taylor was a good and great man. His chair had formerly been mathematics and
    natural philosophy but he was at

Heading: home
Content: everywhere teaching us to demonstrate problems in geometry, unravallng the
    involved sentences of Livy, or scanning the odes of Horace.

Heading: He
Content: had as a.s.sistants his gifted son Alfred and the gentlemanly I.

Heading: N.
Content: Loomis. They were all highly re- gaidej. During

Heading: my
Content: second ye^ar the facu'ty was reinforced by the com- ing of Professor Bliss to
    occupy the chilr of Greek language and litera- ture. Prof .G.

Heading: W.
Content: Anderson that of that of Latin and Prof. C. S. James the chair of chemistry.

Heading: The
Content: west wing was soon completed and

Heading: we
Content: be- gan to feel that

Heading: we
Content: were growing Im- portant.

Heading: Young
Content: 

Heading: men
Content: today looking over the beautiful wooded slopes can scarcely picture the wild
    woods of that time and the boys at intermis- sion wading through the fallen
    leaves ana gathering into heaps the brush that cumbered the ground. After a
    time

Heading: we
Content: were cheered by the coming of some phllo.sophical ap- paratus. Dr. Taylor used
    to take the telescope on his shoulders in the ev- ening and go up to the
    crest where the main edifice

Heading: now
Content: stands and show us the wonders of the starry heavens. But 1851 came and seven
    young

Heading: men
Content: graduated.

Heading: Commencement
Content: Hall was the large upper room of the Academy.

Heading: We
Content: had a beautiful green arch sprung over the platform and a Latin verb "Ducimus"
    festooned above us f we said

Heading: "We
Content: lead the way." That is a day 1 shall never forget. The tender farewell remarks
    of Dr. Tay- lor

Heading: --
Content: his last official act in Lewis- burg

Heading: --
Content: drew tears from every eye. Then the thoughts of parting from each other after
    such long and pleas- ant associations

Heading: moved
Content: us. The

Heading: By
Content: Rev. John Morris Lyons. *51. Bucknell's Oldest

Heading: Alumnus
Content: in Point of Graduation. I was born on January 24. 1828, * little band of seven
    never met again near what Is

Heading: now
Content: 

Heading: known
Content: as Atglen.

Heading: 'And
Content: all that happy party, Chester County, Pa. Early In life I J "Save one, alas are
    dead."

Heading: SIGMA

Heading: ANNUAL
Content: 

Heading: DANCE
Content: i Delta Sigma "stepped out" over | the week-end. Activities began on Friday
    evening with th>> formal at the Lewisburg club. About forty couples danced
    to the music furiiished by Al<\ander's orchestra, from 9. until 2. At 12
    intermission was announced and .refreshments were served. For the remainder
    of the week-end canoeing, motoring and

Heading: many
Content: other diversions were in order. Delta Sig-

Heading: ma
Content: and its guests had an enjoyable week-end. The Improvement on the tennis court of
    the

Heading: Kappa
Content: Sigs is progress- ing rapidly and Is nearing completion. The court had been too
    uneven and was not the best of courts, so it was decided to turn it north
    and south and

Heading: make
Content: a good court out of it. The .site was -;i.i(leil :\;:J a founda- tion of red
    shale put in. Then a layer of cinders was added and the top layer of fine
    red clay has just been added. After rolling and the putting up of back-stops
    and sod- ding of the surroundings, a mighty fine court Is expected. i'AGh.

Content: credit i= due Editor Keech and his staff in present- j ing such a voluminous
    work, covering as it does every phase of the life on the 'Hni." It is the
    very last word in college annuals for the year, and presents an appearance
    really dis- tinctive in character and of the neat- est kind of workmanship
    throughout the publication. Especially fine !.- the photo engraving work,"
    which shows just that touch of the artistic that savors of the best. Th"
    book i^ divided into twelve departments, each cne complete in itself and
    cover ing that particular phase of the in- terest of the students and
    classes, r-nd from cover to cover it is filled v.ith real "flavor" that
    makes the life at college seem

Heading: SAVED

Heading: IN
Content: 1863

Heading: The
Content: 8tudent.s of the Unlvernlty at Lewl.sbuiK "were enrolled as Com- pany A, Twenty-
    eighth ReKJineut/ Pennsylvania Volunteer Mllltla, on the <<lxteenth day of
    June. 1863. and were mustered Into the service of ttic United States a.s
    such for the period during existing emergency from th'-' nineteenth day of
    June, 1S6:;. and they were honorably discharged at llurri.sburg. Pa.. July
    27, 186:5."

Heading: Thus
Content: reads

Heading: my
Content: discharge. But this enrollment and mustering In was ac- complished with some
    trouble. Gov- ernor Curtin and Secretary Stanton could not come to terms.
    Stanton did not wish to enroll any one for a longer period but Governor
    Curtin wished them mustered In for the ex- isting emergency. For

Heading: many
Content: days we camped on Capitol Hill at Har- risburg, until dissatisfaction existed

Heading: among
Content: the members and several under various pretexts wanted to go home."

Heading: W.
Content: J. (Billy) Wolverton got

Heading: R.
Content: A.

Heading: Townsend
Content: to

Heading: mount
Content: a store- goods box and deliver an address. As his voice rolled over the ground-^
    soldiers started up from every blade of grass, and before the address was
    completed Capitol Hill was well filled with those desiring to be mustered
    in. Townsend, on the shoulders o' some stalwart men, was paraded around the
    grounds, and these same

Heading: men
Content: wanted to take him

Heading: down
Content: town but by the intercession of Captain Jones, Townsend was released from his
    captors. Whether this demonstra- tion hud any effect upon the official.! I

Heading: know
Content: not; but after the lapse of thirty-seven years

Heading: my
Content: 

Heading: memory
Content: recall.i events thus: The address was de lievred about 9 a. m.; at 3 p. m. w(i
    were mustered Into the United Statej .service and received our equipments,
    and ut 5 p. m.

Heading: we
Content: marched across the bridge to Sporting Hill, where a con- flict took place and
    tiie Twenty- eighth Regiment was u participant.

Heading: Company
Content: 

Heading: A
Content: (Stiidents of the Unl veralty at Lewisburg) was detailed to proceed n(irth along
    the west bank of the Susquehanna toward.s the western end of the
    Pennsylvania Railroad bridge, and soon after leav Ing Sporting Hill they
    unconsciously ran into iniinent dangjer.

Heading: The
Content: Con federate officers, mentioned above, informed

Heading: me
Content: that they had a perfect

Heading: map
Content: of the Susquehanna river from the Juniata down.

Heading: They
Content: knew where there were fords between Harrisburg and the Pennsylvania railroad
    bridge.

Heading: Company
Content: 

Heading: A
Content: traversed this whole dis tance. While resting on the march, we were Informed
    that the Confed erate forces had left that position only a little while
    before our coming.

Heading: My
Content: Southern friends informed me that they meditated a quick pa.ssage of the river

Heading: --
Content: hoped then to disperse the raw and unarmed troops, burn the capitul city
    iiuickly repa.ss the rivi.T and rejoin their army, but that com- ing of
    Union forces

Heading: and
Content: the supposi- tion that others would follow deterred them from the attempt.

Heading: Company
Content: 

Heading: A
Content: comprised the only troops that pa-ssed along the route.

Heading: From
Content: thei^e facts It Is beyond question that the students of the University at
    Lewi.-i- burg saved the State Capitol In June. 1863 I would like to find the
    place where

Heading: we
Content: halted and received the in- formation and mark it with an ap- propriate tablet
    bearing the Inscrlp tlon: "Here the students of the Uni- versity at
    Lewisburg saved the State Capitol In 1863."
